LabBody: It's time for SUMMER FUN! SUMMER FUN is your guide for places to go and events to see in Southern California.

How many times have you seen something that was clearly wrong go on before your eyes and you said nothing? What if your silence meant risking the life and innocence of someone else? Well, diners at a local cafe got to experience this dilemma firsthand when they overheard a conversation between a 16-year-old girl, Maria and a 40-something man “John” who met her in person for the first time. John told Maria he was also 16 when they spoke online, but when she met him in person, he tried to get her to go with him back to his place to “have fun.” When fellow diners overheard the conversation, they had some crazy reactions to the scene. You have to see this! I was shocked at how the people at the tables nearby reacted. It made me really happy for the state of humanity that people still want to help others. Like one lady who offered rescue for Maria said, “Where I’m from, it takes a village. So your neighbor is your relative. So no, we can’t shut up.” The whole incident of Maria and John meeting may have been a sham with the two actors “performing” for the ABC reality show, “What Would You Do,” but that doesn’t change the severity of the danger that happens everyday. It should be a wakeup call for us all that we can make a difference and when we see something wrong, we should stand up and take action. “I think our parents always taught us,” one of the girls who helped Maria said, “you always step in. You always help someone.” Or maybe Dietrich Bonhoeffer—in the face of Nazis slaughtering Jews—said it best, “Silence in the face of evil is itself evil: God will not hold us guiltless. Not to speak is to speak. Not to act is to act.”

For rising UFC star Conor McGregor, mixed martial arts training starts and ends with control. McGregor’s movements revolve around control of his body, mind, and breath. “If it doesn’t involve balance I don’t think it’s beneficial,” says McGregor. “I do yoga every day. I’m perfecting my handstand, I like the tree pose with a side leg extension and the plank/side plank.” Just don’t expect McGregor to get to yoga class on time. The Irish-born featherweight doesn’t keep a schedule in a traditional sense. He simply wakes up and starts moving. “I’m self-taught, and nothing is set by a clock,” says McGregor. “Yesterday, I did pool work, then went to the gym and did jiu-jitsu rounds, pad work, jump rope, core work, and dead hanging from objects.” McGregor does free-weight exercises such as single-leg barbell deadlifts to build strength and balance simultaneously. His most valuable skill, though, is intangible. “My belief is my best asset, and I have a stronger mindset than my opponent,” he says. When M&F last spoke with McGregor, it was a few weeks prior to the announcement that champion Jose Aldo would drop out of the title fight due to a rib injury. His statement in regards to Aldo at the time foreshadowed a change in opponents. “I’ll enter the contest formless and fearless,” McGregor says. “He’s just a blank face and a new body.” McGregor views his history-making opportunity as bigger than himself. He’s in this game to make his Irish supporters proud. “My coach and team have been with me since Day 1, and I look forward to raising the gold for them.” UFC 189: Conor McGregor faces Chad Mendes for the interim UFC featherweight championship on July 11 at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, Nevada. Check out McGregor's exclusive training camp workout and start training like a fighter now. THE WARMUP Dynamic Stretching Duration: 10-15 min. For the workout: Perform exercises 1A-1C as a circuit, then do the heavy bag and grappling.

SKANEATELES | The Skaneateles Village Board of Trustees plans to release a statement to all village property owners next week to address its position on short-term rental properties within village zoning districts. At the end of Thursday's meeting, the board entered into an executive session for an attorney-client session that Mayor Marty Hubbard said during the meeting was called specifically to discuss the short-term rental issue and the board's response to residents' concerns and opinions. He encouraged residents to continue sending letters and emails to the village hall with their comments on the issue and said the village hall already received a number of letters following a 45-minute public comment session centered on the issue at the board's June 25 meeting. "I'm pleased with the amount of interest and the sincerity of these letters," Hubbard said. "They're well written and well intended." On Friday, the mayor said the whole board did agree to a statement that will be circulated to all village property owners — not just rental property owners — through letter sent via first-class mail. While noting the board did reach a consensus on the statement, Hubbard stopped short of saying all board members held the same opinion on the issue. In addition to property owners, he said the letter will be sent to the local press, the Skaneateles Area Chamber of Commerce, local real estate agents and other interested, pertinent entities in the matter. Hubbard acknowledged the board chose a direct letter rather than an advertisement or legal notice in the newspapers. "I'm very pleased with the village board's efforts on this," he said. "I'm extremely pleased with (Village Attorney) Mike Byrne's efforts in putting this together. I'm very pleased to have a consensus of opinion on how to move forward." The solution to the short-term rental issue, the mayor said, lies in enforcing existing laws rather than writing new laws. He said the front side of the letter will explain that, along with laying out the board's position on the matter. The back side of the letter, he added, will explain how the board plans to administer rental properties in the village and monitor residents' complaints and comments on such properties. One proposed measure in that regard, Hubbard said, is an online system where residents can send concerns about rental properties in a way that separates those comments from other correspondence the village hall receives and highlights those comments to the board more. In other business Thursday, the board voted to transfer the chiller from Austin Park Pavilion to the Skaneateles YMCA and Community Center for use at its second rink, named in memory of Duke Schneider, despite Trustee Jim Lanning's objection and opposing vote. Lanning contended that the chiller is town property that sits on a skid and could be removed from the building. He said the town paid $130,000 for the equipment in 2007 from its emergency fund. Byrne, however, said the chiller is connected to the pavilion's electrical and plumbing systems and, thus, property of the village, which owns the building. He also said the money for the purchase came from William G. Allyn's funding for Austin Park to the village, which in turn gave the money to the town to cover the purchase. While the town can remove items that it owns that are not built into the now-defunct arena, Byrne said the village retains ownership of items such as the chiller and the scoreboard that are connected to the building. By adopting a resolution to approve the transfer, the attorney said the board also declared the equipment surplus. "I just have a different opinion on that," Lanning said before casting his "no" vote. MEETING NOTES. Director of Municipal Operations Shannon Harty said the Department of Public Works is reviewing a sidewalk repair plan and aims to perform the work during the week of July 20. The DPW spent the past week repairing water main leaks, she said. Under the 2015-16 village budget, she said Bartlett will receive $3,450 to clean up the trees and remove dead branches in Thayer Park. Skaneateles Volunteer Fire Department Chief Dan Evans reported that he and Code Enforcement Officer John Cromp plan to meet with officials from the Sherwood Inn to discuss safety concerns. The board learned that portable toilets used to supplement the public bathrooms at the Masonic Temple are working well and the bathrooms themselves are in good condition. Trustee Sue Dove reported the Chamber of Commerce will use signage to direct visitors to available parking areas, such as a town-owned parcel on Fennell Street, during the Antique & Classic Boat show July 24-26. In response to questions from Evans, Harty said she does not know a status of the East Lake Street waterline replacement project and plans to meet with the chief and firefighters to discuss a program for fire hydrant flow testing. Skaneateles Journal Editor Jonathan Monfiletto can be reached at jonathan.monfiletto@lee.net or (315) 283-1615. Follow him on Twitter @Skan_Monfiletto.

DiffbotBody: GC: You won't be surprised to hear I've yet to find it given the amount of choice on offer. All I can do is sit on the fence as I go through the formbook ahead of a bumper day tomorrow, but I'll have to get off it in the morning as I'm on the Morning Line with Frankie Dettori and Brazen Beau's trainer Chris Waller, two excellent guests. Have a great weekend folks, thanks for all your questions. All the best, GC. GC: A tricky one, Pete. I've never quite gone along with the notion that he's a real crackerjack sprinter but there's always a chance that will be wrong. William Haggas seems to be concerned about the undulations, but overall I wonder whether his close third in that King's Stand was quite good enough to win a race like this. Paul Hanagan has understandably looked elsewhere with Muhaarar and it looks a good decision. GC: There's every chance at least one longshot will hit the frame but it's tough to say which one that might be. I can't back Sole Power given he's 0 from 10 over six furlongs and Anthem Alexander shouldn't be able to beat Muhaarar on Ascot running. G Force has plenty to prove and it wouldn't surprise me if Astaire showed up really well at a big price. I realise he's just under two lengths to find with Brazen Beau on Diamond Jubilee form but he showed excellent speed and that might be seen to better advantage given the way this track seems to be riding at the moment. GC: It's really tough, but I think I have to just edge towards Muhaarar. Everything about his Commonwealth Cup romp suggests he's thriving at the moment and he also receives 6lb in weight-for-age from Brazen Beau even though he's just a half year rather than full year younger than the Aussie who was foaled in the southern hemisphere. He'd be my tentative choice to beat the star Aussie raider in exactly the same way his sire Oasis Dream did against Choisir all the way back in 2003. GC: He's drawn 15 of 15 for the second time in a row. Like you, I can't be sure that racing alone cost him at Ascot, but it's clear he ran an excellent race and once again all the vibes from connections have been very positive. You have to wonder if the shape of the race will be against him. He's clearly fast and capable of going his own way, but the stalls are towards the stands' rail tomorrow which means he will be right out in the centre with the other speed horses Danzeno and Astaire drawn well inside him in stalls four and eight respectively. I'd love to see him win as the sport in general benefits from big time International competition but my confidence hasn't increased with the news he's out on a limb again. James: Hi, How much of an impact do you feel the ride Brazen Beau received at Ascot actually had? The trainer said it didn't, I personally agree with that thought. He did race away from the rest of the pack down the near side but if anything he didn't have a troubled passage like he may have done more centrally. James Doyle takes over the ride and his style should suit this racecourse, any thoughts GC? GC: I've had a pretty good look at the race and Bronze Angel each-way is my pick. Firm Decisions is sure to be bang there for a long way towards the stands' rail but Bronze Angel has a tremendous record in these major handicaps and he ran a screamer in the Hunt Cup, travelling powerfully behind a strong gallop and that bodes well. I've no idea whether his outside draw in stall 20 will be a problem, but I'm confident he's fully effective at seven furlongs and he's just 2lb higher than the mark he won off at Ascot last season. GC: And to you, Chris B. The draw really shouldn't be a major concern at York nowadays. The issue of too many good meetings on one day is a more contentious one and I think my ideal choice would be for the July Festival to move back to Weds-Fri. That said people in racing really do seem able to make a negative out of a positive. We'll have ten terrific live races on C4 tomorrow with about £1.2million in prize-money and 100,000 people likely to be in attendance at York, Chester, Ascot and HQ. That's something to be proud of for the sport as a whole so I'll focus on that and let the bureaucrats decide if and when to shift Newmarket back to its former slot. Chris B: Good morning Graham. Packed programme tomorrow and exciting racing but Imo there are too many big meetings in one day. I am at York for the John smiths cup but because of the July cup the limelight has been taken away from York a little bit. I think it should be a standalone meeting. What are your thoughts? Anyway onto the John smiths do you have a strong fancy for the race? I like look of Arab dawn. Is stall 13 ideal or a little wide. I would have preferred a slightly lower draw. good luck to all tomorrow GC: You've summed it up very neatly Mick. So many of these have taken each other on on a regular basis and with so little to choose between so many runners a bit of luck here and there could be very important. However, I would be inclined to turn a blind eye if people start bashing on about the draw. Loads of horses have won from high draws on the round course in recent times and this race last year saw stall 22 beat stall 18 in a surprisingly steadily run race where very little got into it from off the pace. I hope we don't see a similarly tactical race tomorrow and the stronger they go the keener I'll be on Ajman Bridge. GC: Hope so Harry, but not necessarily with Mount Logan. He could be well-handicapped but I'm hoping Ajman Bridge is set for a big run. I am slightly concerned his coming back in trip a little, but he's well-handicapped racing from the same perch as when pipped by Aran Dawn racing over 1m4f at Ascot. It's clearly just too tough to have a major bet, but it looks like Kirby has chosen Ajman Bridge over Mount Logan and I hope he's right. GC: This looks a really tough race but it's also a cracker and we should get a good gallop with Arabian Queen, Euro Charline and Fintry in there. I've nothing negative to say about Lucida. She was slightly unlucky in both the Guineas and Coronation Stakes for different reasons. That said, the French look very powerful here and I'm drawn towards Avenir Certain at a slightly bigger price. She's a dual Classic winner with a really good turn of foot when she's on song and she stayed on powerfully under a very tender ride at Chantilly last time. Faster ground here poses a new question but they have watered overnight and with Soumillon replacing Benoit she should go well. GC: Hope so Ji. I was really impressed by her Queen Mary performance and she acted like a filly who should be effective over six. Fellow Ascot filly Illuminate is clearly the danger, but she's worth watching beforehand given that Richard Hannon has suggested she could get lit up (pardon the pun) in the preliminaries. EA holds several of these on Ascot form and if she reaches the same level today she'll be very hard to beat. GC: They certainly are flying. Resonant showed yesterday that the Braveheart horses just bounce back and bounce back. That said, Rah Rah might be in a bit deep here. The winner Acapulco wasn't drawn far away from her in the Queen Mary and on that line of form she's plenty on to reverse form with Easton Angel. GC: You won't be the only one Tony. That maiden came after C4 had gone off air but this Braveheart filly came with a major reputation and lived up to it and then some. She powered clear with precious little assistance needed from William Buick. Her final time was six lengths slower than Shalaa in the July Stakes, but she recorded by far the fastest final two furlong split of the day in a performance described by Timeform's Simon Rowlands as 'mustard or possibly even hot mustard.' In short, she looks a Pattern race winner waiting to happen and she will have no problem getting further down the line. GC: Good question, Ian. The July Stakes has been won by plenty of horses that have gone on to win more good races, often at Glorious Goodwood, and it's also worth remembering last year's renewal saw Dewhurst winner Belardo and Commonwealth Cup hero Muhaarar get turned over by Ivawood. I'm sure there's plenty of room at the top for more changes among the 2yo colts and Shalaa is bang up there. It was the second best juvenile Timeform time figure (115) behind the Queen Mary winner Acapulco. I'm pretty sure there are a few big stables with good colts that haven't shown their hand yet but Shalaa has the potential to win another big one over six or possibly seven furlongs. GC: I certainly couldn't have found him. As regards Spencer's ride, it was clearly nicely judged but the times certainly don't suggest that he nicked the race in any way in fact, Big Orange went faster than Mr Singh at practically every split until the closing stages and I just think that the winner belatedly blossomed on the sort of wide-galloping course that suits his style perfectly. GC: Depends completely on what turns up, Phil. John Gosden has the best 3yos around but half of them won't be going anywhere near Town Moor. Storm The Stars heads the market at the moment based on his Epsom third and Curragh second. Aidan O'Brien has a posse of possible contenders who could improve before September too, so at this stage Mr Singh should be considered as a smart colt with room for more improvement. But it's hard to argue what he achieved at Newmarket against 90-odd rated horses yesterday marked him out as a potential Classic winner. GC: I think a lot will depend on how he fares if he goes to the Arc. I must admit I haven't taken too much notice of the ratings debate. I saw Frankel had the same rating at the same stage but that side of things make less appeal then they used to. The main thing is we see him as often as possible before he does retire and if he does win a King George and an Arc then he's going to compare favourably with the rest... barring Frankel as a 4yo of course. GC: I'm pretty sure he'll be fully effective over both distances after last week. A bigger field would clearly have been ideal but it was great to see him beat The Grey Gatsby so convincingly in the end and to have an unbeaten Derby winner is a terrific boost to any Flat season. It's a bit depressing to hear his owner making retirement plans already but he clearly sets the bar very high for the King George providing he stays on top of his game. If Jack Hobbs does too we're in for a very special Arc indeed.
LabBody: Racing. /

HOW’s this for an innovative wood shed? Kevin Butler, from Kilmore East, saw the hybrid wood stack/shed near Lancefield recently. If there is one thing a farmer hates is spending money on specialised infrastructure when nature can do half the job for you. Any other neat, quirky or innovative ways of stacking or storing wood out there? There will be a prize for the best.

Apple is reportedly planning to announce a new lineup of iPods as early as Tuesday, July 14. While the iPod nano and iPod shuffle are said only be receiving new colors, the iPod touch will reportedly see upgraded internal components as well. From iGen (translated from French): For the iPod touch however, the jump in the numbering suggests a model seriously brought up to date, and not just because he abandoned the push button for the strap. iPod touch improvements line up with what we've previously heard: While nothing is for certain until Apple shows it off on stage or details it in a press release, my understanding is that the next generation iPod touch will finally leave the A5 processor behind and leap ahead, at least as far as the A7. Talk of new iPods first started last week, when models of iPod touch, iPod nano, and iPod shuffle were spotted in new colors inside iTunes 12.2. Should it come to pass, this will be the first major update that the iPod touch has seen in almost three years. Source: iGen, via MacRumors.

COLUMBIA — When Genie Rogers first came to the Columbia Housing Authority as a volunteer in 1990, she found a mess. "The Housing Authority was in great turmoil," said Phil Steinhaus, the CEO of the Columbia Housing Authority. "There were issues with crime, issues with high vacancy rates, staffing issues and funding issues." Rogers has spent the past two decades making the Housing Authority better. After years of work, the Columbia Housing Authority in 2011 was named to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's list of high-performers, or agency's that earned a 90 percent or higher score in inspections for criteria such as expense management, vacancy rates and rate of occupant turnover. For her efforts, Rogers was honored Monday with the 2015 Howard B. Lang Jr. Award for Outstanding Volunteer Service to the city of Columbia. "I feel very strongly that we all owe a debt of responsibility to this community that we live in," Rogers said. "Columbia is a wonderful place to live, and I think one of the reasons that it's so unique is that so many people answer the call to participate in the process. That's what ... also makes it a high quality place to live." Steinhaus said he met Rogers in 1993 while she was a chair on the Boone County Community Services Advisory Commission; Steinhaus was the city staff member assigned to the commission. He left his job with the city and came to the Housing Authority in 2006 — on the suggestion from Rogers. "I've always been amazed what a hard worker Genie is," Steinhaus said. "She's always just been inspiring to me with her service and dedication to the community. ... It's been a pleasure to work with her." In her more than 35 years in community service, Rogers has also worked with the Boone County Community Services Advisory Commission, where she ultimately spent 12 years; the Central Missouri Humane Society; and the Columbia Cemetery Association, among other organizations. "I have enjoyed the things that I've done tremendously," Rogers said. "I feel like every single volunteer role I've played has been incredibly beneficial to me. ... I just hope that I was a change agent ... in the lives of the people who were affected by some of the things I did and the policies I helped to create." The Howard B. Lang Award includes a monetary prize, which Rogers has decided to give to the Columbia Housing Authority's Moving Ahead youth program. She said the program has lost a large portion of the funding it used to receive from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. "I didn't know about the $1,000 until about a week ago. I was stunned," Rogers said. The Moving Ahead program provides after-school activities, tutoring and food for local children. Supervising editor is John Schneller.

Vroom boom. If the July 4 pyrotechnics merely whetted your appetite, more is planned Friday night at Chateau Raceway in Lansing, where a fireworks show follows a night of modified stock car racing. The track is five miles north of Austin off U.S. Highway 218; take the Lansing exit.

LabBody: Early errors did in the Winston-Salem Dash as the team lost 4-2 to the Potomac Nationals Friday night at BB&T Ballpark. Winston-Salem committed two errors in the top of the first, which led to the Nationals taking a 3-0 lead off Dash starter James Dykstra. The first two runs were scored with two outs and the bases loaded when catcher Omar Narvaez made an errant throw to third trying to pick off Narciso Mesa, and the third came on a double by John Wooten; all three runs were unearned.

DiffbotBody: Iraqi Security Forces engage and prematurely detonate a charging ISIS SVBIED. That may be the fastest I have ever seen a piece of crap Humvee move. Suicide car bomb attacks are a consistent and effective tactic employed by ISIS forces. With the amount of captured armored vehicles the Islamic State has in their possession, it makes it easier for them to get huge payloads of explosive material through Iraqi defensive perimeters to inflict maximum damage. For this reason, the U.S. is delivering thousands of AT-4 rocket launchers to Iraqi Security Forces to mitigate the threat. ~Will

DiffbotBody: The Hacking Team fallout continues, with Dutch member of the European Parliament Marietje Schaake asking for a European Commission (EC) investigation into the outfit. Schaake wants the EC to decide whether Hacking Team broke various embargo rules by selling products to repressive regimes (she name-checks Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Egypt, Ethiopia, Kazakhstan, Morocco, Nigeria, Russia, Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Uzbekistan in this blog post). She singles out a sale to Sudan as a possible violation of “UN Security Council Resolutions 1556, 1591, 1945, 2091 and 2138”, and that the sale “would also violate Council Decision 2014/450/CFSP of 10 July 2014 concerning restrictive measures in view of the situation in Sudan”. Her questions for the European Commission, posted here, are: 1) Does the Commission believe Hacking Team has violated EU sanctions regimes? 2) Has the Commission been informed of any prior authorisation given by the Italian authorities that would allow Hacking Team to export its products to Sudan or Russia, and is the Commission aware of a ‘global authorization’ that was given by the Italian authorities to Hacking Team that authorised the company to export its products freely in all countries of the Wassenaar agreement? 3) Has Hacking Team ever asked DG FPI any question regarding its interpretation of the EU sanctions regime against Sudan or Russia? An unfavourable finding would open up a new world of pain for the Italian surveillanceware outfit. ®

A 132-year-old banknote from First National Bank of Moline will be auctioned Saturday in Greenville, S.C. Manning Garrett, president and owner of Manifest Auctions, said by email that a South Carolina woman found the $5 banknote while cleaning out her late husband's World War II locker. He said it's in good condition and is expected to sell for about $5,000, although it could be worth up to $10,000 because of its scarcity. That scarcity is what makes banknotes from smaller towns such as Moline the most sought after by collectors, he said. National banknotes were issued from 1863 to 1935 to any bank in the country that held a national charter with the federal government. They were printed in Washington, D.C., and mailed to local banks to be signed by a cashier and president of each bank, Mr. Garrett said by email. Bids for the banknote will be accepted by phone at 864-520-2208 or online at ManifestAuctions.com.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi is scheduled to meet state Chief Ministers next week to discuss the land bill in an attempt to break the deadlock over the policy, government officials said. The Modi Government is determined to push through the land bill that seeks to exempt land purchases for certain industrial, housing and infrastructure projects from requiring the consent of 80 per cent of landowners. Opposition parties have staunchly resisted the bill, calling it 'anti-farmer'. Lawmakers in the Upper House of Parliament, led by the Opposition Congress party, have repeatedly blocked the legislation. To build consensus, the Government has introduced several amendments to the bill and formed a parliamentary committee to examine compensation clauses and resettlement of farmers. Modi has asked the panel to submit its report at the beginning of the upcoming session, but the committee has appealed for more time. Modi has called the second meeting of the governing council of the National Institution for Transforming India (NITI) Aayog for July 15, about a week before the monsoon session of Parliament is set to begin. The meeting will have "many items on the agenda," economist and NITI Aayog member Bibek Debroy told Reuters. But the focus of the meeting will be the land bill, according to two senior sources with knowledge of the arrangements. The monsoon session is expected to be a tumultuous one, with the contentious land, labour and GST bills on the table, and simmering political scandals threatening to disrupt proceedings.

ROCKFORD — Joey Watts appreciates an audience. "I love the crowd. I like people clapping for me," he said. Marcus Smith, arguably the best young golfer in Rockford history, stole Watts' crowd for an hour and interrupted a Watts-Kyle Slattery playoff. But in the end, Watts got his crowd back. And the Boys Stateline Golf Championship. Watts birdied the final hole to force a playoff with Slattery, then birdied the second hole of a playoff for both the overall title and the 17-18 age division crown. Watts, who plans to play for Rock Valley College after finishing a couple of credits this summer at Harlem, bombed a 320-yard drive on the 508-yard, par-5 second playoff hole, then two-putted from 45 feet for the winning birdie. "I just let it rip all day," said Watts, who shot 71-70 for a 1-under-par 141 at Ingersoll. "I figure the closer I can get to the hole, the less chance to hit bad shots from a shorter distance." It was another runner-up finish for Slattery (70-71), who has taken second behind Kevin Flack in the three major adult tournaments so far this year (Atwood, Ballard and Mauh-Nah-Tee-See Match Play). "I give it my best every time, but it kind of stinks to get second," said Slattery, a Boylan grad who will be a freshman at Southern Illinois-Edwardsville this fall. "I just missed putts all day. I made a bunch of pars, with two birdies and two bogeys, so it was kind of a slow round. I made six birdies in two rounds. I have to get that close to 10." Smith, a 13-year-old eighth grader at Winnebago, won the 13-14 age division by 30 strokes. Officials stopped the playoff after Slattery just missed a 20-foot birdie putt on No. 1 when word came that Smith was four strokes back with six holes to play. They planned to resume quickly, but Smith immediately birdied 13 and 14, leaving him two strokes behind with the easiest four-hole stretch on the course yet to play. But Smith missed an 18-foot birdie putt on the 118-yard par-3, then made bogey on the 294-yard par-4 when he drove into a green-side bunker and bladed his sand shot over the green. "I started putting too much pressure on myself after the two birdies in a row," Smith said. "If you asked me how I made the birdies, I can't say. You just have to hit the shot when you have to do it, and I did it. But I messed up on the short par 4." Needing an eagle on 17, the 5-foot-4, 110-pound Smith blasted his drive 280 yards and was pin high to the right in two shots. But his 50-foot eagle chip stopped 15-foot short and his birdie putt lipped out, stopping Smith's fist pump in mid-pump. "I honestly didn't think I was going to hit it that far," Smith said. "I guess it was just super adrenaline, excited but nervous at the same time." "I have to give him props," Watts said, before going back to play another round of golf with his dad. "He's playing out of his shoes. He's probably going to win it the next five years." Other age group winners were: Alex Klein for ages 15-16, Braden Hogan (son of eight-time Men's City champ Jamie Hogan) for ages 11-12, Cooper Watt for ages 8-10 and Dillon Nebiu for ages 5-7. Matt Trowbridge: 815-987-1383; mtrowbridge@rrstar.com; @matttrowbridge.

You may know how train a dog but did you know your dog is also training you? Dogs are more than our cute companions. They’re our roommates, our children, our best friends who bring us a unique perspective and remind us to enjoy the little things in life. There’s truth to the saying: My dog taught me everything I need to know. Meet Gus Gus, a French Bulldog, NYC salon mascot and open-minded man about town who imparts life lessons despite his love for drinking directly from the faucet.

DiffbotBody: A team of researchers from MIT have discovered a way to automatically restore old, poorly performing software to fresh code. It turns out software and fruit have something in common: they both can rot. But while a banana that’s been sitting out too long can’t turn fresh again, old software code that no longer functions like it once did can be revitalized. A team of researchers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the university’s computer science and artificial intelligence laboratory have discovered a way to automatically restore old, poorly performing software to fresh code, MIT said this week. This is a big deal for companies that might spend thousands of dollars on developers to restore old software that may not work as efficiently as it once did. Often times software programs written several years ago no longer function properly on the latest computers and hardware, explained MIT Professor Saman Amarasinghe in an interview with Fortune. The reason is because software has to be tailored to work for computers. Each time hardware technology advances and the performance of machines increases, a software program needs to get rejiggered to accommodate the changes. Typically, coders spend a lot of hours going through the program’s software to make changes, add more lines of code, and add algorithms that ensure that the software works efficiently with the hardware specs of the day. However, each time a programmer tweaks the software and adds new code, the program steadily becomes more bloated. Additionally, the algorithms and extra code used to match the software to current hardware specifications can often become invalidated as the next-generation gear launches into the market. Coders can have a difficult time removing all the extras, which leads to a program that experiences what is known as software rot. Once the code is rotten, the program as a whole can be slow as molasses and even unresponsive when you try to get it up and running. This is where the MIT researchers come in. The MIT team developed a software system called Helium that basically scans the rotten software, discovers the most crucial lines of code that the original programmers developed to make it function, and then builds a revised version of the program that works with the hardware specs that the MIT team wants it to match. What used to be a month’s long process, the MIT researchers claim can now be cut down to an hour. Amarasinghe explained that MIT tested out its Helium system with some engineers from Adobe ADBE -0.57% who were looking for ways to make the over-two-decade-old Photoshop program run faster and process images more quickly with the advancements in modern hardware tech. Whereas Google and Facebook have been running software that might be as young as three years, Adobe and other companies might have programs or applications that haven’t aged too well as the years have gone by, Amarasinghe said. In this case, the Adobe engineers wanted a way to make Photoshop run better without having to spend the traditional man-power needed to do the job. MIT claims that when they used Helium to revise Photoshop, the program’s performance increased by 75 percent. Say goodbye to the slow loading times for your favorite vacation pictures you want to make more colorful. As of now, Helium is not quite ready for primetime and it could be a few more years before it’s ready for widespread use, Amarasinghe said. Adobe was only testing out Helium and is not going to be using it in its products as of now. Also, while Helium can restore older code, it currently only works on image-processing software like Photoshop, because getting a program to display an image is a relatively easier task compared to other more complex software, he said. Still, if Helium pans out, Amarasinghe said it could have a lot of benefits to businesses. The healthcare industry, for example could save a lot of time having to upgrade their image-processing software for medical devices like X-ray machines as the hardware advances. Subscribe to Data Sheet, Fortune’s daily newsletter on the business of technology.

I visited with Steve Clark during a tour Wednesday of the massive, state-of-the-art Woodward Inc. factory and office complex after a ribbon-cutting ceremony there. He's the guy who was in charge of finding property where the $2 billion-a-year company could build a 450,000-square-foot-plant to make aircraft fuel-system components. Clark is a broker with Dickerson & Nieman Realtors. The deal he spearheaded paved the way for one of the biggest building projects — $250 million — in Winnebago County history, one expected to add more than 700 good jobs by 2021. Clark told me about the number of property owners he dealt with to make the 70-acre-or-so deal in Loves Park: about a dozen. I asked why the Subway sandwich shop at Forest Hills and Harlem roads in Loves Park was still there. After all, a car lot, a dog-grooming parlor, an antiques store and some houses were razed. He said Woodward had acquired the Subway property, and the building will come down in a few years when the retailer's lease expires. But three houses a few yards to the east of Subway remain on the north side of Harlem at the corner of Forest Hills. Otherwise the stretch to North Perryville Road is occupied only by Woodward. The owners didn't want to sell, Clark said. That afternoon, I stopped to talk with one of them about the holdout. Patricia Board, 82, was sitting in a lawn chair in her driveway as her daughter, Melanie Esklor, mowed the lawn. Board owns two of the houses, separated by a driveway and a bit of grass. One is where she grew up. The other is a three-bedroom ranch built in the mid-1950s by her husband, who has since died, on property that once housed a lumberyard. The lumberyard land also was where Board rode her Shetland pony when she was a preteen. And it was home to Pat's Root Beer Stand when she was a teen. She and other youths her dad hired served root beer floats and burgers during summer for years. That was until she started dating Wayne Board, whom she married years later. Her dad closed the stand, saying his daughter "has lost interest," Board said. "We were 'in the country' then," she said, as car after car passed. Her mother's brother owned a grocery nearby, and her aunt lived where the Clinton family lives now, right behind Subway. "I love it here," Board said. "I've lived here all my life." Even if she had been offered more money than she was for the houses, "I don't think I would have sold." Dan Clinton didn't sell to Woodward because "it was a really low offer. ... I'm not going to lose money on my home." Clark told me when I called him Thursday that Clinton's house is "very attractive, but an over-improvement for the neighborhood." Since 2010, Clinton and his family have lived in the 100-year-old residence they gutted and renovated. Clinton has always lived in the Harlem Road area. "We're not ready to move yet." Woodward was founded in 1870 in Rockford. It moved its headquarters to Fort Collins, Colorado, several years ago and has employed about 1,500 people in Loves Park in recent years. The company considered locations for the new plant in other states before deciding to build here. Production at the new facility is expected to start within a few months. Clark said Woodward is still interested in buying the Board and Clinton properties. He said the intent is to make the Harlem-Forest Hills corner "parklike, to enhance the setting." Time will tell. Georgette Braun: 815-987-1331; gbraun@rrstar.com; @GeorgetteBraun.

DiffbotBody: BEMIDJI—A Cass Lake man arrested in a Wilton burglary has been sentenced to three years in prison. Nathaniel Houle, 19, was convicted of felony first-degree aiding and abetting burglary and sentenced June 30 in Beltrami County District Court to 42 months in the Minnesota Correctional Facility in St. Cloud. Houle was credited with 175 days time served and ordered to pay a $50 fine. Houle was arrested with Brett King, 21, and Paige King, 18, both of Bemidji, in December after the three were identified as the people who were involved in an armed home invasion. Brett King was sentenced in May to seven years in prison for felony first-degree burglary in possession of a dangerous weapon and two counts of felony second-degree assault. Paige King was sentenced for felony first-degree aiding and abetting burglary to four years in the Minnesota Correctional Facility in Shakopee. Houle pleaded not guilty in March and withdrew his plea in May resulting in a guilty plea entered in court.
LabBody: BEMIDJI—A Cass Lake man arrested in a Wilton burglary has been sentenced to three years in prison.

“On the occasion of the inauguration of Metrorail, why don’t you write something on rail heritage?” asked my good friend, K. Saravanan. It’s well-known that the first railway line of South India was from Royapuram to Arcot and that the train was flagged off on June 26, 1856 by the then Governor of Madras, Lord Harris. The Metro had its inaugural run in the 210th year of the Railways’ debut in Madras, starting off on June 29, 2015. The Madras Railway Company (MRC) began its work in 1853, when a team of three — George Barclay Bruce, Chief Engineer; Edward Smalley, Agent and Major T.T. Pears, Consulting Engineer, took charge. Construction proceeded at a brisk pace thereafter, Bruce designing the Royapuram Station and much of the civil structures. The arrival of the first four steam engines, each weighing 13 tonnes, was quite an event, for they were the heaviest consignments till then to be delivered at Madras. These “ponderous masses of iron”, all made at Glasgow, arrived on board the ship Haveling on June 13, 1855. The Governor, a number of gentlemen and a “fair sprinkling of ladies” proceeded to the Royapuram beach to witness their offloading. There was no harbour then, and the ship was docked two miles at sea. The engines had to be hoisted by cranes from the ship, lowered on to a waiting raft and then rowed ashore. The process of offloading took a day for each engine, and by Monday, June 18, all four were safely on the beach. How they were taken to the railway tracks is an unresolved mystery. By 1856, there were 65 miles of operating track. The railway earned 5,196 pounds sterling in the first three months of operation — 39, 903 passengers contributing to 3,101 pounds out of the total revenue. The Metro has seen that many passengers on the first day itself! Like the Metro, the railway took forever to build to its final length of 450 km. In the initial days, it was criticised, as beginning nowhere, running through nowhere and ending nowhere, for Royapuram and Arcot were relatively unknown destinations. Bruce was more or less the E. Sreedharan of his times, for he completed the 65 miles of the Madras railway line in record time. But his health broke down in the process and by December 1857, he returned to England. Being an active Freemason, his brothers in the order gave him a grand farewell, an event presided over by the Chairman of the MRC, Robert Stephenson. Back home, Bruce had a long and illustrious career, and eventually received knighthood. The MRC offices at Royapuram can still be seen as sad ruins from the over bridge. The station, now the oldest surviving terminal in the Indian subcontinent, also stands, though threatened with demolition. In a way, it is the forefather of all other rail transport in the city — the Southern Railway, the suburban system, the MRTS and now the Metro.

DiffbotBody: If you are at Chicago's Midway Airport or on board a Southwest Airlines (NYSE: LUV) flight in the days ahead, don't be surprised if you see a lot of smiling Southwest flight attendants in your midst. Midway is Southwest's largest hub, and home base for many of the carrier's flight attendants. Late last week, the executive board of Transport Workers Union Local 556, who represent more than 13,500 Southwest flight attendants altogether, voted to approve a tentative new contract, which over the next several weeks will be presented to the full membership to ratify. A spokesman for Local 556 today said the vote on the new contract should be completed by the end of July. If, as expected, the contract is approved by the full union membership, Southwest flight attendants would, according to Local 556 President and lead negotiator Audrey Stone, "continue to be the highest paid in the (airline) industry through 2019." The new contract also would be retroactive to 2013 when negotiations began. A spokesman for Local 556 said the contract does include pay raises for flight attendants, who in turn would agree to work rule revisions in exchange for the higher pay. Full details of the tentative new collective bargaining agreement will be released soon, the Local said. Southwest's tentative new contract with its flight attendants, however, still leaves the low-fare behemoth without new contracts with three major units in its workforce — pilots, mechanics and ramp agents who handle baggage and other crucial plane servicing functions at the gate. Southwest flight attendants were in negotiations for two years on their new contract. But ramp agents, who are growing increasingly restless, have been without a new contract for some four years. A large group of ramp agents recently picketed Southwest's annual meeting, and ramp agents who were unhappy about the excruciatingly slow progress of contract talks are believed to have been a key factor in the historic Southwest Airlines meltdown at Midway Airport in early 2014 that left 16 Southwest planes filled with passengers stranded on the tarmac for hours. The recent picketing and other rumblings about labor unrest at Southwest may have prompted Southwest CEO Gary Kelly to speed up efforts to get new contracts with all of the various unions who comprise his airline's workforce. Any major concerns about possible employee strikes could cause Southwest customers to consider booking flights with competitors instead.

Late last week, the executive board of Transport Workers Union Local 556, who represent more than 13,500 Southwest flight attendants altogether, voted to approve a tentative new contract, which over the next several weeks will be presented to the full membership to ratify. A spokesman for Local 556 today said the vote on the new contract should be completed by the end of July. If, as expected, the contract is approved by the full union membership, Southwest flight attendants would, according to Local 556 President and lead negotiator Audrey Stone, "continue to be the highest paid in the (airline) industry through 2019." The new contract also would be retroactive to 2013 when negotiations began. A spokesman for Local 556 said the contract does include pay raises for flight attendants, who in turn would agree to work rule revisions in exchange for the higher pay. Margo Martindale is joining The Good Wife as a campaign operative who will go "toe-to-toe with Eli Gold" (Alan Cumming) in Season 7, CBS announced Thursday. Martindale will recur as Willa Eastman, who's successfully championed underdog presidential candidates in Iowa and who "hides her intelligence and cunning under a fake, folksy charm," according to CBS. Lest we forget, in the Season 6 finale, Peter (Chris Noth) told Alicia (Julianna Margulies) that he's been asked to run for president to be a viable VP candidate. So, will Willa be on Team Florrick or a rival's? "Every year we look for a character and an actor who can go toe-to-toe with Eli Gold and make him blink," showrunners Robert and Michelle King said in a statement. "So we were thrilled when Margo Martindale agreed to play Willa Eastman. Her ability to mix comedy and drama is unparalleled. And we can't wait to see how Margo and Alan deal with each other." Martindale previously recurred on The Americans, but left the show due to scheduling conflicts when she landed a role on The Millers. (She returned for one episode last season after The Millers was abruptly canceled.) Martindale also won an Emmy for playing Mags Bennett on Justified. As previously announced, Jeffrey Dean Morgan is coming aboard as a series regular and Cush Jumbo has also landed a recurring role. (Full disclosure: TVGuide.com is owned by CBS.) It’s been a year, but the pain hasn’t subsided. Make no mistake: Isaiah Austin still aches to play basketball. A surprise diagnosis of Marfan syndrome altered his career plans in the days leading up to the 2014 NBA draft. Austin admits he still hasn’t completely recovered from that stunning news. “I’m still trying to get past it to this day. I’m surrounded by basketball each and every day, so it’s hard for me not to miss the game,” the former Baylor center said. “I had so much love and passion for it, that it’s hard for me not to miss it. It’s just a daily process. Seeing these people, they’re definitely the type of people that are helping me get through it.” The people to which Austin was referring were the dozens of Baylor fans who turned out Friday for a pair of book signings for his new autobiography, “Dream Again: A Story of Faith, Courage and the Tenacity to Overcome.” He wrote the book with the hopes of inspiring people. In the end, he has drawn his own inspiration from the fans, who were lined up at the Baylor Bookstore long before the first signing session even began Friday. “Seeing all the smiles on their faces,” Austin said. “People are lined up to get my autograph, and I should be the one who should be shaking their hand and getting their autographs, because they are my support system. I really wouldn’t be here without them.” The soundtrack of a dribbling basketball has pulsed all throughout Austin’s life. His uncle Isaac played 10 years in the NBA, and the 7-foot-1 Isaiah appeared destined for a pro career as well. At Baylor, he hounded shooters as an uncharitable rim protector, rejecting 2.4 shots per game over two seasons. He also displayed a smooth outside touch, setting himself up for a potential future as a “stretch four” in the NBA, or in layman’s terms, a power forward who can shoot the ball from the outside. Even before his Marfan diagnosis, Austin had toyed with the idea of writing a book someday. He suffered a severe eye injury as a middle school student after being struck by a baseball. He eventually lost all sight in the eye and had to be fitted for a prosthetic. Occasionally, he’d talk with his mother Lisa about chronicling his journey in overcoming his eye injury, and how his faith helped him persevere. “It started when I had my eye surgery,” Austin said. “My mom always told me something great was going to come of it. She always talked to me about relaying my story and my testimony to as many people as I can. We talked about writing a book, and then once I found out about Marfan syndrome and with everything that was going on, we just thought it was the perfect time.” Austin said his first call was to Baylor coach Scott Drew. He figured his old coach would provide some astute direction, and he was right. Austin eventually agreed to a publishing contract with Simon and Schuster, and worked with author Matt Litton on the project. However, he discovered that writing a book isn’t like making a layup. More like a full-court hook shot — blindfolded. “(It took) patience. Being able to tap into all your feelings in the past, sitting there at night trying to remember each and every last detail,” Austin said. “Just describing things. Sometimes I’d have to get on the phone with Matt for three or four hours, just talking to him about my life. “It’s been amazing, and I’m glad it’s over with because it took forever. It really did take forever. It was a stressful, stressful six months, but it was fun. I’m glad the outcome is becoming great.” The future tantalizes Austin, 21, with promise, but he remains uncertain about which direction he may travel. He plans to finish his degree at Baylor — he’ll start his senior year in the fall — and expects to help out again with the men’s basketball team as a volunteer assistant, as he did last season, though on a more limited basis. Coaching intrigues Austin. He also intends to continue his advocacy for the Marfan foundation. He has been the disease’s most visible spokesperson since his diagnosis last June. Then there is the promise of a job offer from NBA commissioner Adam Silver, once he completes his studies. That’s not a bad backup plan. For now, the gentle giant is both gracious and grateful to be able to share his story — especially with those enthusiastic Baylor fans. “Baylor Nation is basically my backbone. God is my foundation, and Baylor Nation is my housing,” Austin said. “So I know that I can’t go wrong with them, and I promise them that they’re not going to go wrong with me by supporting me.”

ELKHART — In a continued effort to promote walkability and attract visitors to the businesses around Cassopolis Street, the city of Elkhart will add new sidewalks, lighting and trees to the area around Northpointe Boulevard. Because this is area gets a lot of visitors, the city is working to make it more attractive, said Leslie Biek, right-of-way engineer. “We’re trying to get (visitors) walking around to nearby restaurants and helping to revitalize the area,” Biek said. The addition of about 4,140 linear feet of new sidewalks, lighting and trees will go from Northpointe Boulevard to C.R. 4 on Caravan Drive and on David Drive to S.R. 19 and back to Northpointe Boulevard. On the map below, the red is where sidewalks, lighting and trees will be added. The black is where sidewalks already exist. This project is a continuation of development the city has been doing with the Caravan Drive Sidewalk and Lighting project, Biek said. However, it’s not as extensive as work they did in 2013 with the addition of a roundabout at Northpointe Boulevard and Caravan Drive. They aren’t even touching the roads. “It’s more of a light enhancement,” Biek said. The Board of Public Works approved the plans at its meeting Tuesday, July 7. The construction estimate for the project is $437,000, which will come from the Cassopolis TIF fund, Biek said. The Redevelopment Commission has already appropriated funding. About half the cost — $200,000 — of the construction estimate is the 21 lights, Biek said. They are looking for cheaper lights in the style of those already on Northpointe. Bids will open at the beginning of August, and Biek said she expects construction will start in early September and be done by the end of October. “I don’t think it’ll take longer than a couple of months — the only thing that might linger is the lights. We’ll get all we can done by the end of October and have the lights installed whenever they arrive,” she said. This area is a big part of current development in Elkhart. This fall, construction for a new Holiday Inn Express will begin on land adjacent to North Pointe Plaza, and the owner of the hotel, Praful Palan, praised the city’s effort to improve the area, according to previous reporting by The Elkhart Truth.

The Kidd Kraddick Foundation, which include radio hosts J-Si, Kelly Rasberry and Big Al Mack, teamed up with Todd Graves of Raising Canes to host a Kidd’s Kids tour of the gigantic tree house built in Graves’ backyard. Kidd’s Kids is a foundation with a goal to provide children, who have a chronic or terminal illness or are physically challenged, with adventures.

Unlike a lot of viewers and critics who took to social media to gripe like old grandmas, I found the sophomore effort of HBO’s crime drama “True Detective” pretty much instantly compelling. It’s not funny, the masses whined. I miss McConaughey and Harrelson, they said. There’s too much going on, they moaned. If you simply wanted a repeat of season one, why bother tuning in? Better to just rewatch that mesmerizing Louisiana-set first season than to bother with a new story I say. I hope I’m not coming off as a smarter-than-thou d-bag elitist. I loved season one as much as the next admirer of Southern Gothic drama. I was just open going into season two to a new setting, new characters, a new tone, a new world. And as any film buff worth their salt knows, SoCal is about as good as it gets for crime fiction. I couldn’t wait to see what they cooked up. And by and large, I’m diggin’ it. But where I’m really diggin’ it is in those inspired touches that smack of David Lynch meets James Ellroy: the dream sequence with Velcoro and his cop father that began episode three; the Bel-Air mansion that houses a mayor’s drugged-out European trophy wife; the apparently insatiable sexual appetite that one Vinci City Manager Ben Casper left in his wake. It’s pulpy, it’s juicy, it’s weird. And I like it. So, Mr. Pizzolatto, if I may, leave the by-the-numbers portrait of the repressed homosexual cop behind. Give the girl with daddy issues routine a rest. Embrace the darkness. It’s what you do best.

Call it a case of life imitating art imitating life. Waco singer-songwriter-handyman Wes Cunningham is back performing onstage at the World Cup Café, where he will be Saturday night. Five years ago, he was there acting in the indie movie “Sironia,” whose plot mirrored his life in some ways. And in his pre-”Sironia” life, he worked to create that café, helping lay the red-and-white tile wall that frames its kitchen window. The café, an outgrowth of Mission Waco’s multiyear effort to revitalize the neighborhood near the corner of Colcord Avenue and North 15th Street, is experimenting with opening on Saturday nights this summer. Mission Waco executive director Jimmy Dorrell — a longtime friend of Cunningham and his wife, Emilie, who have lived in that neighborhood for more than a decade — called up the musician to ask if he would perform on some of those Saturday nights. It didn’t take much to persuade him. “It’s a blast to come up here and play,” the 43-year-old Cunningham said. “It’s really casual and informal.” Casual enough that friend and Waco pedal steel player Tim Jenkins has joined him, along with Emilie, on the small corner stage in the café’s Fair Trade Market. The room, with its walls hung with handcrafted art and items from around the world, was rearranged several months ago to accommodate tables and seating, and has worked as a meeting space of sorts, Dorrell said. “People who used not to drive through this neighborhood now play bridge here,” he said. The café has expanded its menu for Saturday nights, adding entrees featuring chicken, pasta, fish and beef with appetizers, salads and desserts. More than 70 people attended the first Saturday night dinner last month. Included was an Austin couple celebrating their third wedding anniversary, who requested the Cunningham song to which they had danced at their wedding. Succeeding weeks have seen crowds averaging around 40 people, with Waco musicians Evan Klaras and Bob Scott playing when Cunningham couldn’t. Back on stage. The Saturday night gigs — he also is scheduled to play July 18 — put Cunningham back performing in the public’s eye, something he admits he hasn’t done much of in recent years outside of playing at Mission Waco’s Church Under the Bridge on Sundays. He writes for a “well-heeled rock band” in Austin, which he can’t name publicly, and composes for the occasional videogame and soundtrack. Music is only one piece of a life that finds him repairing and renovating old homes — a sort of solo “fixer-upper” — and raising three boys, ages 11, 8 and 6, with his wife. It’s a different life than the music-driven one the Baylor University graduate pursued in the 1990s, signing with major label Warner Bros. He stepped away when its emotional and spiritual cost became too high. That decision proved the right one. “I am totally happy here,” he said. That story proved a framework for the 2010 film “Sironia.” Texas-based director Brandon Dickerson used a screenplay that Dickerson, actor-playwright-Baylor theater instructor Thomas Ward and Cunningham collaborated on while all three lived in Waco. Cunningham not only wrote and performed the songs in the film, but also starred in it, playing the lead character of singer-songwriter Thomas Fisher. In the film, which screened at the Austin Film Festival and the Dallas International Film Festival, Thomas moves with his wife to the small Texas town of Sironia after months of soul-sucking frustration with the merciless music business in Los Angeles. Personal peace. A smaller, slower life in Sironia proves frustrating, too, until the musician finds a personal peace with deeper values in life that, eventually, help him reconnect with his music. The movie, the DVD of which is sold at the Fair Trade Market, won praise at film festivals and cities where it screened, but Cunningham confessed he was a little disappointed it didn’t open more doors for creative work. Still, the lessons that the fictional Thomas learns are the two that Cunningham acquired years earlier in coming back to Waco, helping get World Cup Café started and raising a family: “It’s not going to be OK — It’s OK right now,” he said. “And, my motto: ‘Do the work, show up and leave the results to God.’ ” There’s another lesson found when he played at Church Under The Bridge and realized he wasn’t under pressure to please an audience or maintain a professional career — a lesson his World Cup Café audiences come to realize: “Church Under the Bridge totally freed me,” he said. “I realized I love to sing.” ----- If you go. What: Wes Cunningham and friends. When: 5:30 to 8 p.m. Saturday. Where: World Cup Café, 1321 N. 15th St. Admission: Free.

WILTON — The renovation project at the Comstock Community Center continues on schedule and on budget, with Sept. 1 as the target date for completion of Phase 1, according to several officials associated with the project. Construction work on Phase 2, which includes the west wing and the café, will begin in September and should be completed by the end of January 2016, said Stephen Giametta, project superintendent from Turner Construction. One of the biggest recent developments at Comstock since Phase 1 began on March 9 was the removal of the old “monster” boiler, and the installation of new, smaller, twin boilers that will work much more efficiently, Giametta said. “We had to destroy the monster to get it out of the basement,” Giametta said. “It was so big we had to take it out in pieces. (The boiler room) is being re-vamped, and it’s like a chess game. We’re putting in new switch gear and panels, and we’re constantly reworking the system so we can install the next part.” Giametta said there is a method to this seeming madness. “We need to maintain existing service and still build the new system to maintain minimal service to the occupants,” said Giametta, who has been with Turner Construction for 15 years. “That’s challenging.” Comstock Community Center did not have a sprinkler system, something this renovation will correct. “We heard about a new sprinkler system, and the sprinkler pipe connects from the outside line into the boiler room,” Giametta said. “The pipes run down these tunnels, with no lights. We had quite a few guys crawling in and out of these tunnels for months — not days — months.” Judy Zucker, chairman of the Comstock Renovation Building Committee, wishes everyone could see the old building, as it is being retrofitted for the 21st century. “It takes a bit of imagination when things are stripped down and going to be re-built,” Zucker said. “We’re taking a building from the 1950s and transforming it. We’re making (Comstock) new and up to code.” That was also Giametta’s focus as he talked about installations and materials. “There’s a new sprinkler system being installed, when the building currently doesn’t have one,” Giametta said. “Pipes are being put in now. A good way to put it is out with the old and in with the new, new, new.” One of those new additions will be the walls of the classrooms — high-impact gypsum that Giametta described as mold and mildew resistant. Zucker talked about the heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) unit that will be “all new, for the old wing.” “The unit on top of the building has been replaced,” Giametta said. “It’s a new roof-top unit. We’re using existing duct work because it’s been deemed acceptable.” With no ceiling panels in place, Giametta was able to point out the “snake trays” — long wire baskets that follow the hallways — to hold crucial wiring. “(The snake trays) will hold data wires,” Giametta said. “The new electrical wiring will run in the walls.” With boiler removal, sprinkler pipes and wiring issues, it came as something of a surprise when Giametta said his biggest challenge was walls. “The biggest challenge is the condition of the existing walls,” Giametta said. “Some corners are not exactly square, not plumbed. We’ve overcome these issues. To date, these are issues you’d expect in an older building. Don’t get me wrong. It doesn’t make the overall job any easier. But we’ve overcome all of the issues so far.” The gymnasium will get an overhaul, including an addition that will make sweaty athletes happy. “There will be air-conditioning in the gym for the first time,” Zucker said. “People who use it will appreciate that.” Giametta said that, other than the installation of ductwork and sprinkler piping, the gym will remain largely the same, with a composition floor and appropriate striping. “We didn’t change any footprint of the building,” Zucker said. “The gym will be the same size.” New glass and upper and lower exterior — and interior — panels are making the windows much more attractive and energy efficient, Zucker said. Inside, the panels will be hidden by shelving and heating units, and the exterior panels are a muted shade of pewter. A new bathroom has nearly been finished on the lower level near the arts and crafts room, with new wall and floor tiles, and the arts and crafts room itself has new flooring and cabinetry. New flooring will be installed throughout the lower level during night hours the weekend of July 10 through 12, Giametta said. “Every room is being made safer, healthier and up to modern codes and standards,” Giametta said. Zucker added that handicap accessibility is a crucial part of this entire process. One section of the Center that is not as far long is the main entrance/lobby area, which is planned to be expanded and modernized, Zucker said. “There will be a vestibule, and the office will be protected from the elements and other things,” Zucker said. “There won’t be leaves blowing into the lobby.” Giametta talked about the steel canopy over the entrance, and the efforts it takes to put such a structure in place. “There is a lot of coordination between concrete pouring, plumb lines, string lines,” Giametta said. “In general, this high level of coordination to get sub-contractors on the same page is nothing out of the ordinary, but it involves concrete, masonry and brick work. It’s fair to say the main entrance will be the last segment completed. This is a full renovation.” Zucker expounded on getting 30 to 35 workers per day on the same page. “We have 17 major trade contracts, and some of them have sub-contractors,” Zucker said. “You can imagine the scheduling. We’re on a very ambitious timetable, but when we put in a new fire alarm system, a new sprinkler system and all the other measures, people will be safer.”

ORMOND BEACH – When Jill Aversa spotted an egg in the window of a craft store in the early 1970s, her life took a turn and she developed a new lifelong hobby. “It looked like black marble with a picture in the marble,” Aversa said. “It’s scratch carving. You dye eggs with natural dye like onion skins… use an exacto knife and cut a design into the egg. The cutting takes the dye away.” She signed up for an egg art class and has been creating egg art since. “Once I took the class, I was hooked,” she said. She fondly remembers her first egg creation. “It was a two-door jewel box. It’s absolutely hideous, but I keep it,” she said. She then followed that class with an oil painting on eggs class, where she met friends who are still friends today. Aversa created more than 80 eggs, taught classes for 15 years in egg art and won a multitude of ribbons. She was featured in magazines and accepted two international awards. She was invited three times to be one of the two United States representatives to the Randstad Foundation International Egg Exhibition in the Netherlands, where she twice received the sole international award, which was selected by popular vote. Aversa’s eggs are varied. Some have individually placed Swarovski stones, others have shells cut away with a dental drill while others are adorned with hand-painted paper flowers, dried kale or fungus. Music boxes and jewelry boxes are among the mix. “Most people have a specific type of egg. I’m known as the creative one because I don’t have a specific style,” she said. “Most of mine have to do with animals because that is my passion.” Aversa said she can spend up to six months creating one egg. “I have all these ideas in my head. It’s just a matter of working it out,” she said. “The possibilities are limitless.” Although Aversa no longer travels to share her skill, she does help friends interested in the art. Also, she currently has an egg under construction.

The Midland Chamber of Commerce has received its national accreditation from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Chamber officials announced the accreditation at an event Tuesday. The Chamber board has worked closely with the staff since last fall to achieve this milestone. Though more than 7,000 chambers of commerce exist in the U.S., only 3 percent (just more than 200 chambers) are accredited. This achievement highlights the Chamber’s dedication and commitment to be the best resource possible for Midland’s business community. “In 2014, our board of directors worked diligently to develop a strategic plan for the organization. This document gives a clear framework to achieve the Midland Chamber’s vision of, ‘Creating the best business climate on the planet,’” President and CEO Bobby Burns said. “To further our mission, the board has been invaluable in guiding our chamber to examine all areas of our programs and events. This, in turn, allowed us to pursue accreditation. We are pleased to announce that we are now a member of such a small and prestigious group.” Accreditation is the only national program that recognizes chambers for their effective organizational procedures and community involvement. To receive accreditation, a chamber must meet minimum standards in their operations and programs, including areas of governance, government affairs and technology. This extensive self-review can take six to nine months to complete.

Repair work on the bridge that connects Southwest Morris Avenue with 26th Street is set to begin Monday. The city is replacing the bridge because its timber structure is rotting, said Josh Tacchini, project manager for the city of Corvallis' Public Works Department. The timbers will be replaced by pre-cut concrete slabs and the roadbed will be redone in a project that will cost $1.3 million. Nearly 90 percent of the money comes from an Oregon Department of Transportation grant, with the city required to match the remaining 10 percent from its street fund. The work will force the closure of Morris at 26th for the duration of the project. Morris Avenue traffic will be routed onto Grove Street and from there to Western Boulevard. Travel lanes will be shifted on 26th during most of the construction but two-way travel will be maintained. At times there will be just one northbound lane available with a detour routing southbound traffic via 15th Street and Western to Philomath Boulevard. Residents will receive 48-hour notice before any driveway closures, Tacchini said. Access to residences will be restored at the end of each working day and on weekends. Business access within the project area will remain available. The current bridge has a weight limit of 10 tons. The new bridge will not have load restrictions and also will include bike lanes and a sidewalk for pedestrians. The bridge reconstruction project is scheduled to be completed Sept. 25, with bridge rail and landscaping work continuing into late October. School at nearby Oregon State University begins Sept. 24. “It’s not ideal to be ending when we are ending,” said Tacchini, who noted that because the original project cost estimate of $900,000 grew to $1.3 million, an ODOT review was required that delayed the start of work by four weeks. The construction work will be continuing during the first two OSU home football games at Reser Stadium on Sept. 4 and Sept. 19, with a third game set for Sept. 25. Tacchini noted that because 26th Street is closed on game days the project should have minimal impact on football traffic or congestion. Contact reporter James Day at jim.day@gazettetimes.com or 541-758-9542. Follow at Twitter.com/jameshday or gazettetimes.com/blogs/jim-day.

It has been amusing to watch the brands — the PGA, NBC, Macy’s, NASCAR, Univision, Serta — flee Donald Trump after his xenophobic remarks. Who even knew the Donald had a line of mattresses featuring Cool Action Dual Effects Gel Memory Foam? But there is one entity that can’t dump Trump, no matter how hard it tries: the GOP, because Trump is the Republican Party. One big Republican donor this week floated to the Associated Press the idea of having candidates boycott debates if the tycoon is onstage. Jeb Bush, Lindsey Graham and other candidates have lined up to say, as Rick Perry put it, that “Donald Trump does not represent the Republican Party.” But Trump has merely held up a mirror to the GOP. The man, long experience has shown, believes in nothing other than himself. He has, conveniently, selected the issues that Republicans want to hear about — or at least a significant proportion of Republican primary voters. He may be saying things more colorfully than others when he talks about Mexico sending rapists across the border, but his views show that, far from being an outlier, he is hitting all the erogenous zones of the GOP electorate. Anti-immigrant? Against Common Core education standards? For repealing Obamacare? Against same-sex marriage? Anti-abortion? Anti-tax? Anti-China? Virulent in questioning President Obama’s legitimacy? Check, check, check, check, check, check, check and check. Does anybody suppose Trump really cares about illegal immigration (which helps his construction interests by suppressing wages) or about defending traditional marriage (he’s had three)? And we don’t need to suppose: We can look back at what he did and said in 1999, when he was flirting with a run for the Reform Party presidential nomination and I accompanied him on a swing through Southern California. I flew on his 727 with the winged “T” on the tail and the mirrored headboard on the bed, and I learned all about his prospective platform: progressive on social issues such as gays in the military, for campaign finance reform and universal health care, in favor of more regulation, opposed to investing Social Security money in the stock market. Most of all, he preached tolerance — contrasting himself with Pat Buchanan, his rival for the nomination, who had made statements considered anti-Semitic and anti-immigrant. Buchanan at the time had been talking about criminals entering illegally from Mexico. He said other politicians were afraid that “if they speak out against illegal immigration and they speak out against the crimes that are being committed, suddenly they’ll be considered insensitive, or they say, ‘We might lose the Hispanic vote.’” Trump back then issued a statement saying he hates intolerance because in New York, “a town with different races, religions and peoples, I have learned to work with my brother man.” I accompanied him as he underscored the point by touring the Simon Wiesenthal Center’s Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles. “He seems to be a racist,” Trump said of Buchanan. Now Trump is the one talking about Mexico sending us drugs, crime and rapists. His shift is hardly surprising given his audience — and his competitors. Scott Walker talks about self-deportation, Graham talks about ending birthright citizenship, Ben Carson blames illegal immigrants in part for the measles outbreak, Rand Paul describes as lawbreakers those who were brought to the United States illegally as children, and even relatively moderate candidates such as Bush and Marco Rubio have hardened their immigration positions. Ted Cruz actually praised Trump. Trump’s position also closely follows those that came from Arizona in 2010 when then-Gov. Jan Brewer and other Republicans attempted an immigration crackdown. They spoke about illegal immigrants on the border as a source of beheadings, kidnappings and police killings. The previously tolerant Trump may be a phony, but he’s no dope: He recognized that his name recognition would take him far if he merely voiced, in his bombastic style, the positions GOP voters craved. The mogul’s broader basket of issues is also in tune with those of a slate of candidates who have compared homosexuality to alcoholism (Perry), likened union protesters to the Islamic State (Walker) and proposed elections for Supreme Court justices (Cruz), and who virtually all oppose same-sex marriage and action on climate change. It worked. Trump placed second in national polls by Fox News and CNN, virtually guaranteeing him a place in the first debate, on Aug. 6 — unless the GOP persuades Fox News, the host, to dump Trump. That would be hard to justify. Trump may be a monster, but he’s the monster Republicans created.

Comedian/Cubs apologist Bill Murray took time out during his round Wednesday at the John Deere Classic to tout his beloved baby bears — who hold a commanding nine-game deficit over the St. Louis Cardinals in the NL Central. During some banter with the crowd, Murray gloated about the Cubbies' sweep Tuesday of a doubleheader. Murray referred to the Redbirds as, "The hated Cardinals, Satan's messenger on Earth."
