Amber Heard loves minimal designs that are majorly sexy. Particularly, single-toned figure-hugging pieces with thigh-high slits or open backs. But she can just as easily work an elegant Stella McCartney pantsuit or Zac Posen ball gown.Take a look at her top 25 red carpet fashion moments to see what we mean.

DiffbotBody: The trio of brothers running Sunshine Market in Lynnwood, at the corner of 212th Street SW and 44th Avenue W, are serious about their fruits and vegetables.They stand behind their products, support local farmers and try to be there for their customers nearly every day of the year, 9:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sundays and until 8 p.m. Monday through Saturday, said Noor Almtowaq, 29. And they'll stay open later if a customer drives in at closing time, he said.He's the eldest brother and the driving force behind the purchase of the stand, which they opened in September 2013.“Noor's the heart of the entire business,” said 26-year-old Alex.Yet Noor now works at Microsoft, finding time mainly on weekends and some nights for Sunshine Market, and it's Alex who's hooked on produce.“He has so much passion for the business,” said younger brother Josh, 22. “It's like he fell in love with produce.”Alex agreed and said he's not likely to fall out of love anytime soon either. In fact, he's searching for a site for a second, bigger store where he can expand the selection. He dreams of a string of stores offering both conventional and organic produce. He said there's a science to understanding how fruits and vegetables work — “for example, potatoes hate light, bananas love heat, asparagus loves water” — and in understanding how to sell produce.“When you put tomatoes, basil, eggplants and ginger next to each other,” he said, “it's a guarantee you're going to sell them all.”He's always been interested in how things work. Younger brother Josh said Alex was the kind of kid who was forever taking things apart and putting them back together. He studied at Edmonds Community College and earned an engineering degree from the University of Washington, because he wanted to understand the technology behind materials like concrete.“I'm an inventor and my imagination was limited because I didn't understand the materials, so it limited me,” Alex said. Understanding materials “grew my imagination,” he said.The brothers didn't start out planning to go into the produce business.“I didn't even know what cilantro was, to be honest,” Josh said.Prodded by Noor, they were just looking for a business. And they liked the Lynnwood location. Perched on a hilltop at a busy intersection with three corners anchored in Mountlake Terrace, the site overlooks a Lynnwood business district and streets leading to the Alderwood Mall and I-5. It's housed a produce stand at various times in the past, as well as a coffee stand, sometimes both at once. But there were few, if any, improvements to the building and nothing seemed to last for long. That changed when the Almtowaq brothers took over the site. It was Alex who almost singlehandedly rebuilt the building, doing everything the city would let him do by himself. He redid the electrical and plumbing, built the shelves and an awning for shade. He installed new siding and garage doors that can slide up to open an entire side of the building. “He built this whole entire building all by himself,” Josh said. “He's really smart. I used to come down and watch him.”Todd Hall, planning manager for the City of Lynnwood community development, said the brothers made “significant modifications” to the building and their business is apparently running smoothly.“Since they've come in, we haven't had any complaints or anything,” Hall said. “It seems to be going really well.”The brothers said they made a lot of mistakes and their first customers didn't expect Sunshine Market to last long.At first, they didn't have proper coolers and their produce wasn't being sprayed with water to keep it fresh. So Alex installed coolers and bought the software for a state-of-the-art sprinkler system. “My spinach now lasts two weeks,” he said. “I won't leave it in the store two weeks, but it lasts two weeks. When I first opened, I couldn't even get it to last three days.”Customer Kainitra Crammer, who lives in Bothell but works near Sunshine Market, said she loves the freshness of the produce. She can put it in her fruit bowl and it won't attract fruit flies because it's not spoiling right away, she said. “It's not the grocery store's produce,” she said, “and you can clearly tell, because of the way it lasts.”The brothers order from independent local farmers and smaller outfits like Peterson Fruit Co., a family-owned business in Mukilteo. Often it's a customer request that brings a new product into the store. That's how the brothers started carrying raw milk from Jackie's Jersey Milk in Bellingham. They started out selling 18 bottles a week and now sell 90.They also sell fresh goat milk, which is even harder to find; theirs comes from Lucky Hook Farm in Moses Lake.“People drive from like, Arlington and stuff, just to come buy it,” Josh said.They also sell organic eggs from Stiebrs Farms in Yelm, fresh every three days, he said. And duck eggs, which he described as “a very rich egg” beloved by Asians. Another big seller is their raw honey, purchased from a beekeeper with 46 beehives ranging from Mill Creek to Walla Walla, Josh said.“It is like, the best honey out there,” he said, adding, “We believe 110 percent in our honey.”There are also familiar items like chocolate milk from Twin Brooks Creamery in Lynden, coconut water, Bulgarian feta cheese and Beechers Cheese. Other jarred and canned products give a nod to the brothers' Middle Eastern roots. There's olive oil from Lebanon and Tunisia, coriander from Pakistan, Turkish figs, dolmas and cornichons, tahini paste and dates.Although they consider themselves Americans, the brothers fled with their family from Iraq in 1992, in the wake of the first Gulf War. Aided by Red Cross and United Nations workers after crossing into Saudi Arabia, the Almtowaqs made their way to Washington state, living in Everett for a time and then Lynnwood. His family history may explain in part why Alex has studied philosophy and history and seems just as prone to discussing Plato, Socrates and Galileo as he is to talking produce.Indeed, the conversation at Sunshine Market seems to be part of the customer service.“One of the coolest things here is being able to meet with the brothers,” said store regular Doug Clark, maneuvering through the market in his wheelchair. “And since I'm disabled, they actually have excellent customer service.”He's also partial to the produce, he said.“I've gone up to the Yakima fruit stand, just to compare prices and quality,” he said, “and I just turned around and came back here.”Retired media-arts teacher Claire Beach, of Edmonds, called Alex's impassioned explanations his “TED talks,” referring to the short, powerful talks made popular by the Technology, Entertainment and Design conferences.She chatted with Alex on a recent visit, but that didn't distract her from the produce, which she said has helped her recover from a serious illness. She's been following an anti-inflammatory diet, including cutting down on carbs, and has lost 40 pounds and regained her vigor, she said.“This is the first time in my life I'm eating what my body wants,” said Beach, adding that she grew up in the South. “I was raised in Betty Crocker Land.”Customers like Beach are inspiring, Alex said.“When people come back and they tell you they feel better, healthier, stronger — it's a good feeling,” he said. “It keeps you going.”He could be making a lot more money as an engineer, but said he doesn't like sitting behind a desk.“Engineering is a hobby,” he said. “It's something I do because I love it.“But selling produce is different. You're selling something that feeds the entire world.”

SOMERSWORTH — The Greater Somersworth Chamber of Commerce will hold a public information session for anyone interested in learning about the Chamber's annual tour of China. More than 400 people from Maine, New Hampshire, and Massachusetts have journeyed to China with the Chamber since 2009. In the past, the nine-day, seven-night trip flew out of JFK. This year travelers will be departing from Boston on March 25, 2016. The Chamber's information program will be held on Tuesday, July 29, at 6 p.m. in the Somersworth City Hall on High Street. The all-inclusive price for the journey is $2,399 per person, based on double occupancy and includes round-trip international and domestic airfare, taxes included; 5 and 4-star hotels; three full meals each day; English-speaking tour guides; and admission tickets to all the scheduled tourist attractions. Tours include Beijing, Shanghai, the Great Wall of China, the Forbidden City, Tian en Mien Square, a tea plantation, silk factory, and much more. There is also an optional tour of the renowned Terra Cotta Warriors. Attendance at the information session is open to anyone interested in learning more about this adventurous trip to China. For more information, contact the Somersworth Chamber at 603-692-7175 or visit the Chamber's website to download more details and to sign up for the information session at www.somersworthchamber.com.

The Texas Sea Grant College Program at Texas A&M University has awarded $33,000 in research funding to 23 graduate students at three Texas A&M University System institutions. The students will be given the funds from the Texas Sea Grant's Grants-in-Aid of Graduate Research Program, which is intended to promote scientific excellence and achievement by providing small grants to graduate students enrolled at A&M's flagship in College Station, branch campus at Galveston and the university at Corpus Christi.

A sign denoting property as its future site and a circulating post from a resident’s blog have the community wondering: Has McKinney ISD already made up its mind – and budget – on a new athletic stadium? The site, on the southeast corner of Hardin Boulevard and McKinney Ranch Parkway, is certainly decided. On it sits a sign that reads “Future site of McKinney ISD Stadium” above the district’s official logo. Curtis Rath, who in May ran against and lost to McKinney ISD school board incumbent Stephanie O’Dell for the Place 6 seat, this week wrote on his online blog, at rathpack.me, that the district has approved a $60 million, 12,000-seat stadium for the property. His blog shows documents from the district for the “multi purpose stadium,” featuring “cost opinion and alternative development options” and dated Oct. 17, 2014. Two different options – north side and south side sites – each provides estimates for a 12,000-seat stadium to open in 2017. The south side structure is projected to cost $57.3 million; the north side, $52.4 million, according to the documents. But, district officials said the scope and cost of the new stadium are far from finalized. The cost estimates and renderings – also shown on Rath’s blog – are “no more than conceptual drawings and numbers that were necessary when considering a future site for a stadium,” said McKinney ISD spokesman Cody Cunningham. “A stadium was not approved by the board, nor was a budget for a stadium,” he added. “The District has taken no additional steps at this time other than to secure a site adequate in size for a future stadium and parking.” Despite that explanation, Rath said the deal is all but done. In his post, which was quickly shared via email and social media, he writes, “There was no public announcement, hearings, discussion, citizens panel or any public hint, that the district, was even considering a new stadium.” Upon seeing Rath’s post, residents took to social media to respond. Some voiced displeasure with such a stadium, saying it’d be a waste of taxpayers’ money. Several mocked neighboring Allen, comparing the potential McKinney stadium to Allen’s Eagle Stadium, the nationally recognized $60 million project shut down this past year because of structural faults. After about 15 months of repair work, the facility reopened last month in time to host Allen ISD’s graduation ceremony. “Let’s just hope they don’t use the company that built Allen’s stadium,” commented Jean Seiler-Bonifacio on the McKinney Watchdog Facebook page, which shared Rath’s blog post. On the same page, Patti Waugaman Stephenson posted, “Our kids DO NOT need a ridiculous stadium like Allen’s! We need better quality teachers and a better education.” McKinney Watchdog posted Rath’s blog only to spur discussion; it has not taken a side on the new stadium to this point. Yet, some are in favor of a new stadium, even one as large as presented in the documents shared by Rath. Also in a Facebook post, Paul Elkins stated: “The students in this town deserve to have a nice stadium like everyone else. They have got a lot of years use at Ron Poe. That stadium is very old and no parking. I support building a new stadium. Our kids deserve it.” All three McKinney ISD high schools play their football games at Ron Poe Stadium just east of U.S. Highway 75 and south of White Avenue. The new stadium would sit a few miles from Allen’s Eagle Stadium. Cunningham said the decision will go to voters. The district plans to form a Citizens Long-Range Facilities Planning Committee that would develop a bond program to recommend to the school board. “Ultimately, McKinney ISD voters would decide if a bond were approved or not,” Cunningham said. While there hasn’t been any official public announcement or hearing on a new stadium, school board members have discussed the possibility. Lynn Sperry, who was re-elected to the board in May, said then that a new stadium was a topic of conversation in light of the district’s continued expansion. “While a stadium is certainly a need, there are other pressing needs as well, such as campus renovations, technology, safety and security improvements and new schools to accommodate future student growth,” Cunningham said. Stay tuned for updates on the new stadium discussion moving forward. For local news updates, follow Chris Beattie on Twitter.

After failing to report safety problems, Forest River will now pay major settlement. Forest River RV has agreed to a settlement with a penalty of up to $35 million after federal regulators say the company didn’t properly report safety data and recalls on some of its recreational vehicles. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Thursday, July 9, announced the agreement following a nine-month audit of Forest River’s reporting of safety data to the administration as required by the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1966. This was part of the agency’s ongoing efforts to improve reporting compliance, said Gordon Trowbridge, communications director for the NHTSA. “We’ve been trying to proactively go through all of our data to look for holes that might indicate problems,” Trowbridge said. “This was a product of that effort.” EnviroFest returns to Wellfield Botanic Gardens in Elkhart. The exhibitions at the event are all related in some way to the environment or sustainability, with vendors showcasing recycled artwork or environmentally-friendly pest control and lawn care among other things, Elkhart Environmental Center director Ericka Popovich said.The Elkhart Wood Showcase, for one, will exhibit some of the art and furniture their woodworkers have made using logs. The Tumbleweed Jumpers will perform at the event from 5:30 to 9 p.m. with a few breaks here and there. South Bend Beer Werks will serve drinks at the event’s beer and wine garden, offering wine from Easley Winery. They’ll also be brewing an exclusive beer for the event, Popovich said. Ecstasy, cocaine and gun found by Middlebury police during traffic stop. Eric Michael Veldman of Granger, 23, and Jamie Michele Appleman of South Bend, 20, were arrested Wednesday, July 8, near the intersection of Warren and State Streets in Middlebury, according to a press release from the Middlebury Police Department. Both Veldman and Appleman are being held in Elkhart County Jail. Veldman’s bond is set at $7,500, while Appleman’s is set at $3,000. Potawatomi Zoo adding zip line, carousel, giraffes, penguins and more attractions in $37 million expansion plan. Seeing wild animals up close isn’t an everyday experience in northern Indiana, but soon people will have a chance to zip line over alligators and feed giraffes at the Potawatomi Zoo. Those are just two features that are part of the $37 million master plan announced by zoo officials during a press conference Thursday, July 9. Marcy Dean, the zoo’s executive director, said the plan to renovate and add exhibits and animals is a “revitalization” for the zoo, which opened in 1902. She could hardly contain herself while announcing the plans Thursday. Five Points Auction fire in Edwardsburg results in heavy damage, no injuries. Though no one was injured in a structure fire at Five Points Auction in Edwardsburg, Mich., firefighters said two of the business’s buildings were heavily damaged in the Thursday morning blaze. Six fire departments were called to the fire at 19659 U.S. 12 in Edwardsburg at about 11:30 a.m. Thursday, July 9. The two buildings damaged in the fire were beyond repair, according to Southeast Public Safety Authority Fire Chief Michael Holdeman. “The east building is a total loss, and the west building has enough structural damage that it is a total loss as well,” Holdeman said.

The Netherlands international was officially unveiled as the club's newest signing on Friday, and has rebuffed comparisons with the Real Madrid and Portugal superstar. New Manchester United signing Memphis Depay has rejected comparisons to Cristiano Ronaldo, but is planning to excite fans of the club.United boss Louis van Gaal previously compared Depay to Lionel Messi due to his ability to score goals from the wing."He's a goalscoring winger and there aren't so many of them in the world," Van Gaal told MUTV in May. "[Lionel] Messi is one of those."But Depay has acknowledged he still has plenty of work to do before he is considered among football's elite."I don't want to say I can be like somebody as that, but I think I can excite the fans," he said at his official unveiling. However, Van Gaal believes Depay has the confidence to shine at Old Trafford."I think he's one of the few highly-talented boys of his age," Van Gaal said. "He's full of confidence, as you can hear, but he also knows there's a difference between the Premier League and the Dutch league."He's full of confidence, he'll say what he's thinking."Depay was officially unveiled as a United player on Friday, having completed his £25 million move from PSV Eindhoven, and is set to join the club on their pre-season tour of the United States. The Netherlands international scored 28 goals in 40 appearances in all competitions last season.

Schedule of events. Kalama's birthday party, July 10-12. Free admission. Friday. 9 a.m.-5 p.m.: Tall ships arrive for viewing at Kalama Harbor. Noon-5 p.m.: Model train display at the Community Building. 9 a.m.-4 p.m.: Flea market at Hendrickson Mall. 7-11 p.m.: Grease street dance, beer garden on Main Street. Saturday. All day: Geo cache, history hunt through town, walking tour of historical homes and historical artifacts (police station) 8 a.m.: Breakfast and 5K run registration on Main Street. 9 a.m.-6 p.m.: Run on Main Street, flea market at Hendrickson Mall, tall ships at Kalama Harbor. 10 a.m.-5 p.m.: Model train display at the Community Building. 2 p.m.: History of Kalama pageant at Kalama High School. 4 p.m.: Giant strawberry shortcake at Kalama High School. 7 p.m.: History of Kalama pageant at Kalama High School. Sunday. 1 p.m.: Salmon feed, barbeque with games, award presentations and time capsule at Marine Park. Kalama is turning 125, and this weekend’s celebration is going to taste like strawberry shortcake. To celebrate its birth, the town is throwing a three-day birthday bash packed with a car show, pageant, salmon bake, tall ships, a flea market and more. Its birthday cake will be comparable to the 5-inch deep, 5-foot wide and 16-foot long strawberry shortcake baked in 1928. To top that off, overlapping with the birthday bash is the week-long Kalama Fair. Kalama was a bustling site for the lumber industry even before it was technically settled. The 1850 Donation Land Act, which granted land to men and married couples, helped develop Kalama and the towns around it. Though many consider Ezra Meeker its first settler, the little town was formally reincorporated in 1890 after Washington became a state. Most people believe it is named after John Kalama, a Hawaiian from Maui who traveled to Washington to work for the Hudson’s Bay Co. In 1870, the first spike of the Northern Pacific Railroad’s western terminus was driven into Kalama, and the population boomed. Between 1872 and 1922, it was Cowlitz County’s seat. At the time, the town consisted of four hotels, four stores, two groceries, three saloons, one brewery, one printing office, two shoe shops, one barber shop, two churches, one machine shop, one public school and the Masonic Hall. The Imus family’s arrival in 1889 revived the town after Northern Pacific moved its headquarters to Tacoma and the population plummeted. The town later flourished from the cannery, mill and power industries. The ebb of the fishing industry and the move of lumber mills to Longview after World War I calmed the Kalama economy, which later concentrated on shoreline industries to bolster it. Kalama also flourished as a farming town and was especially important for strawberry growers, creating celebrations like the first Strawberry Festival in June 1939. Kalama claims a touch of celebrity fame when Elvis Presley supposedly slept at the Columbia Inn Motel on Sept. 4, 1962, and when the vampire romance series “Twilight” was filmed in part at Kalama High School. Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft also visited in 1903 and 1911, respectively, for 15 minutes each. Last month, it was discovered that wrestling icon Kurt Angle had a tumour in his neck, and was taking a break from the ring. Thankfully, he has now had it removed, and is recovering well. Posting a selfie from his hospital bed, Kurt said: My doctor and his team! Dr Jho, thank you for your continued assistance in keeping me healthy and strong. I’m very grateful. My recovery starts now. Nothing will keep me from what I Love to do. GOD continues to Bless me each and every day. Thank You to all of the fans for your incredible support. Much Love! Hopefully he will be back in the spandex soon. Just don’t tell him that he sucks…

At least 16 artists will display their works as part of the Elkhart ArtWalk from 5 to 8 p.m. Wednesday, July 15, throughout downtown Elkhart. A number of cubist and realist art and media will be on display at the Midwest Museum of American Art at 429 S. Main St., which is free between 5 and 8 p.m. Visitors can also borrow a framed art print, much like checking out a book, from the main branch of the Elkhart Public Library at 300 S. Second St. All that’s needed is a library card, and the prints have to be returned after six weeks. Children can also catch a ride on the NIBCO Express children’s train at the New York Central Railroad Museum at 721 S. Main St. They can also draw on the sidewalk using chalk as part of the museum’s “Art on our Walk” activity. Goshen dance ensemble Troupe Svatura will give a performance at 7 p.m. at Civic Plaza. The Todd Harold Band will also perform from 8 to 10 p.m. as part of That’s Dancing Studio’s summer program. There will also be a number of musical performers all throughout downtown Elkhart.

DiffbotBody: About 10,000 people will no longer have jobs with Procter & Gamble, including 200 at its Cincinnati headquarters or other local offices, after the consumer goods company spins off or splits off CoverGirl cosmetics and 42 other beauty brands to Coty Inc. in a $15 billion deal. Those jobs are expected to transfer to New York-based Coty, whose current brands include Calvin Klein fragrances and Adidas deodorant. The transaction includes P&G’s global salon professional hair care and color, retail hair color, cosmetics and fine fragrance businesses, along with select hair styling brands. “The merger with Coty, a strategic acquirer, will provide an excellent new home for these businesses and brands, as well as for the talented people who are operating them,” said A.G. Lafley, CEO of P&G, in a statement released by the company. While Coty bid $12.5 billion for the P&G brands, the actual value depends largely on Coty’s stock price. Based on Coty’s current stock price, outstanding shares and equity grants, the value of the transaction is about $15 billion. Shares in Coty (NYSE: COTY) plunged more than 6.25 percent this morning, to $29.54, on news that a definitive agreement had been signed with P&G. However, the firm's shares have been on an uptick, ranging from $15.74 to $32.72 over the last 52 weeks. Shares in P&G (NYSE: PG) were up less than 1 percent this morning, to $81.32, over the previous close. The value of shares has ranged from $77.10 to $93.89 over the last 52 weeks. P&G has 118,000 employees worldwide, including about 11,000 in Greater Cincinnati, but both of those numbers were expected to drop even before the deal with Coty. About 2,700 people work for P&G’s Duracell battery division, which P&G has agreed to sell to Berkshire Hathaway in a deal that is to close this year. Those workers, mostly based at Duracell headquarters in Bethel, Conn., and offices in Geneva, Switzerland and Panama, are expected to transfer to Berkshire Hathaway. Separately, P&G expected to trim its office workforce by about 10,000 employees by last month to reduce costs. And I reported in April that P&G plans to eliminate up to 6,000 additional non-manufacturing jobs by June 2017 through buyouts, retirements and not filling vacant positions. That means P&G could have fewer than 100,000 employees by the time the Coty deal closes, which is expected in the second half of 2016 depending on regulatory approval. P&G expects to finalize details of the Coty deal in the coming months, which could involve a split-off or spin-off transaction involving beauty brands such as Max Factor and Wella Professional. The company would prefer to do either a split-off or spin-off as a deal called a reverse Morris trust in which Procter & Gamble shareholders could exchange P&G shares for shares of Coty. P&G shareholders would have the option of exchanging all, some or none of their P&G shares. A reverse Morris trust allows a big corporation such as P&G to unload unwanted assets without paying taxes on gains. Shareholders who participate in such deals also can avoid taxes on capital gains while diversifying their holdings. Such schemes are unusual because the company that buys the brand has to be smaller than the asset it acquires. Coty is reportedly worth $12 billion including debt and equity. By comparison, P&G has a market capitalization of about $220.7 billion based on current trading value. The transaction will result in a one-time earnings gain that P&G expects to range from $5 billion to $7 billion, depending on the final value of the deal at closing. P&G hopes to pay dividends and retire shares worth up to $70 billion over a four-year period from fiscal years 2016-19 through a combination of shares eliminated via the deal with Coty and the sale of the $2 billion Duracell battery brand to Berkshire Hathaway, as well as ongoing share repurchases. “This represents a significant step forward in the work to focus our portfolio on 10 categories and 65 brands,” Lafley said. “We have leading global brand positions in these categories, consumer preferred products and leading brands in the largest markets. These businesses and brands have historically grown faster and have been more profitable than the balance. We expect these 10 categories to grow and create value as we focus the energy and resources of the company exclusively on them.” Market analysts welcomed news of the latest streamlining effort. Lafley had revealed in August of last year that he planned to cut about half of P&G’s 160 or so brands over a two-year period to focus on top ones such as Tide detergent and Pampers diapers. The Coty deal “is a large step in the right direction for the company and shareholders, but they can do more for sure, including perhaps even an actual breakup,” said Ali Dibadj, a market analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., a sell-side research and brokerage firm in New York. “The timing is odd to us after weeks of silence from the company following media reports on such a deal,” Dibadj told me. “Feels a little amateurish in terms of process by P&G.” The deal is positive news for shareholders, said Martha Strebinger, an investment specialist at Truepoint Wealth Counsel in Blue Ash. “Sales may dip in the short term from the loss of revenue of these brands, but long term I think this will benefit P&G shareholders as the company focuses on its core strengths,” Strebinger told me. The brands that P&G will transfer to Coty account for about $5.9 billion in sales, or about 30 percent of its $19.5 billion in total beauty segment sales for fiscal year 2014, which ended in June of that year. P&G has total annual sales of about $83 billion. P&G will retain big-name beauty brands such as Head & Shoulders and Pantene hair care products as well as Olay skin care. “Procter & Gamble stands out as an attractive undervalued investment, and we’d suggest long-term investors consider building a position in the name,” Erin Lash, a senior equity analyst with Morningstar, wrote in a note today for the Chicago-based investment research firm. “However, we don’t anticipate a material change to our $90 fair value estimate, which already took into account the planned brand sales announced last year.” The beauty category “has remained a challenge for P&G, as organic sales have stagnated over the past few years,” Lash wrote. “We suspect the performance in this category could prove lumpy, given the fierce competitive dynamics of the U.S. hair care space, and it will take a few more quarters until we can get a sense whether this improvement is sustainable.” The other brands included in P&G’s deal with Coty are Sebastian Professional, Clairol Professional, Sassoon Professional, Nioxin, SP (System Professional), Koleston, Soft Color, Color Charm, Wellaton, Natural Instincts, Nice & Easy, VS Salonist, VS ProSeries Color, Londa/Kadus, Miss Clairol, L’image, Bellady, Blondor, Welloxon, Shockwaves, New Wave, Design, Silvikrin, Wellaflex, Forte, Wella Styling, Wella Trend, Balsam Color, Hugo Boss, Dolce & Gabbana, Gucci, Lacoste, Bruno Banani, Christina Aguilera, Escada, Gabriela Sabatini, James Bond 007, Mexx, Stella McCartney and Alexander McQueen. Goldman Sachs & Co. acted as financial adviser on the transaction, and Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft LLP acted as tax counsel. Jones Day acted as legal counsel, and Centerview Partners provided advisory services to P&G.

Those jobs are expected to transfer to New York-based Coty, whose current brands include Calvin Klein fragrances and Adidas deodorant. The transaction includes P&G’s global salon professional hair care and color, retail hair color, cosmetics and fine fragrance businesses, along with select hair styling brands. “The merger with Coty, a strategic acquirer, will provide an excellent new home for these businesses and brands, as well as for the talented people who are operating them,” said A.G. Lafley, CEO of P&G, in a statement released by the company. While Coty bid $12.5 billion for the P&G brands, the actual value depends largely on Coty’s stock price. Based on Coty’s current stock price, outstanding shares and equity grants, the value of the transaction is about $15 billion. Shares in Coty (NYSE: COTY) plunged more than 6.25 percent this morning, to $29.54, on news that a definitive agreement had been signed with P&G. However, the firm's shares have been on an uptick, ranging from $15.74 to $32.72 over the last 52 weeks. Shares in P&G (NYSE: PG) were up less than 1 percent this morning, to $81.32, over the previous close. The value of shares has ranged from $77.10 to $93.89 over the last 52 weeks. P&G has 118,000 employees worldwide, including about 11,000 in Greater Cincinnati, but both of those numbers were expected to drop even before the deal with Coty. About 2,700 people work for P&G’s Duracell battery division, which P&G has agreed to sell to Berkshire Hathaway in a deal that is to close this year. Those workers, mostly based at Duracell headquarters in Bethel, Conn., and offices in Geneva, Switzerland and Panama, are expected to transfer to Berkshire Hathaway.

DENVER — A Colorado man says he has broken the speed record for climbing all of the state's 14,000-foot peaks. Denver-based climber Andrew Hamilton says he finished climbing all 58 points over 14,000 feet in the state at 2:21 a.m. Thursday, clocking the whole hike at nine days, 21 hours and 51 minutes. As he descended Longs Peak, a group of friends, fans and family gathered on the trail to celebrate the so-called fourteener's accomplishment. Many tracked his progress through GPS updates on 14ers.com. Hamilton set a grueling pace up and down peaks over his trek, catching only snippets of sleep. Accomplished Vail mountaineer Jon Kedrowski says he does not expect this record to be broken soon.

Margo Martindale is joining The Good Wife as a campaign operative who will go "toe-to-toe with Eli Gold" (Alan Cumming) in Season 7, CBS announced Thursday. Martindale will recur as Willa Eastman, who's successfully championed underdog presidential candidates in Iowa and who "hides her intelligence and cunning under a fake, folksy charm," according to CBS. Lest we forget, in the Season 6 finale, Peter (Chris Noth) told Alicia (Julianna Margulies) that he's been asked to run for president to be a viable VP candidate. So, will Willa be on Team Florrick or a rival's? "Every year we look for a character and an actor who can go toe-to-toe with Eli Gold and make him blink," showrunners Robert and Michelle King said in a statement. "So we were thrilled when Margo Martindale agreed to play Willa Eastman. Her ability to mix comedy and drama is unparalleled. And we can't wait to see how Margo and Alan deal with each other." Martindale previously recurred on The Americans, but left the show due to scheduling conflicts when she landed a role on The Millers. (She returned for one episode last season after The Millers was abruptly canceled.) Martindale also won an Emmy for playing Mags Bennett on Justified. As previously announced, Jeffrey Dean Morgan is coming aboard as a series regular and Cush Jumbo has also landed a recurring role. (Full disclosure: TVGuide.com is owned by CBS.) DECATUR – In 1983, the year Billy Joel released his hit single, “Uptown Girl,” and cast himself as a downtown man unwilling to be overlooked, downtown Decatur was in decline. “Many corporate restaurants popped up in the 1970s and '80s, and people started to go to those,” Andrew Chiligiris said. “Now I feel people want to connect with Decatur and go where they know people care and want you to come back.” Chiligiris is betting on that as the owner of the newly refurbished Lincoln Square Lounge, one of downtown's oldest eateries, and also owner of the building that houses Anna Thai, which opened in June in the spot he renovated three years ago for another Thai restaurateur who didn't stay. The addition will bring the number of restaurants in downtown Decatur to 18, with nearly half of them open five years or less. For the renaissance, many owners credit streetscape improvements that began in 2011 and will conclude this summer with the Franklin Street corridor. In addition to creating more apartments that feed the return to downtown, Chiligiris has not only redone the main bar area and dining room of the Lincoln, he just added an adjoining banquet/overflow room in the space Capital Comics used to lease at 127 N. Main St. The gyro plate and flaming cheese are enduring menu favorites, he said. One block over, a full six dining choices occupy the east side of Merchant Street, but the oldest is Robbies Grille, focusing on salmon and other healthy options. Owner Rodney Powell said each place fills a niche, business has never been better, and that he, like most others downtown, appreciate the freedom they and their employees have to be with their families on Sundays. Those that are open on Sunday include the Lincoln, Pastabilities Italian Grille and the Downtown Cafe. Co-owner John Ninnemann said the cafe serves breakfast and lunch seven days a week but Saturday is better and Sunday's best. “There must be 10 or 12 churches within four or five blocks of here and plenty of places to park,” he said. “We serve traditional American food, and people like it.” Ninnemann and his wife Barbara are looking for a buyer who will keep the Downtown Cafe going. Open since 2006, Doherty's Pub & Pins has become such a popular place for groups to gather than John, Bob and Jeff Hawkins took out the last six bowling lanes last year to create a second banquet room. John Hawkins said customers think the roasted red pepper/smoked gouda soup is the bomb and that downtown has changed drastically since he became the owner of Robbies 20 years ago. “I think there were only three of us down here back then,” he said. “Now the park looks nice, the lighting's good, and you can walk from one place to another, order an appetizer at one, have dinner at another and eat dessert somewhere else if you want.” Paco Greenwell said opening Paco's Sol Bistro in 2010, shortly before Archer Daniels Midland Co. moved 350 employees downtown and the city began streetscape improvements, got his business off to a good start but that his chicken meatloaf and Southwestern eggrolls are what keep people coming back. He said the restaurant is doing surprisingly well after adding lunch on Saturdays in exchange for giving employees two consecutive days off by closing Monday as well as Sunday. As for what would make downtown even better, Brent Sloan of Sloan's Calzones would like to see stores stay open later in the day, Debbie Hill of St. Nicholas Grille wants some dancing, and John Redden of Taproot had been hankering for a coffee shop. Then Dilly's Bakery opened last month at 231 N. Main St., serving gourmet coffee in addition to satisfying a person's sweet tooth in almost every possible way. “There's something to be said for taking a stroll, getting a coffee and going back to work,” Redden said. “I love it that people are coming downtown instead of driving north. We are investing in ourselves again.” Worapot “Addy” Tangmunarunkit and his wife Ratana “Anna” Darawankul, owners of My Thai in Champaign and Siam Terrace in Urbana, said they are looking forward to being part of the mix of restaurants in downtown Decatur with Anna Thai. “We ... have good food and great service, served with a smile,” Tangmunarunkit said.

Baseball. In Palm Beach Gardens last week, the Ocala Fusion 8U team finished as runner-up in the Cal Ripken state tournament. After winning three games to win their pool, the team out of the Rotary Sportsplex beat Ponte Vedra, 11-6, in the semifinals. The boys then lost to Northwest St. Pete, 9-6, in the finals. Two teams from both the American and National brackets advanced to the regional tournament next week, meaning the Fusion are off to play again in Laurinburg, North Carolina. There will be 16 teams from the southeast at regionals. The Fusion will have to finish in the top two of their pool of four teams to make it into bracket play, which starts July 18. The finals are set for July 19. For a donation to help make the trip possible, call Fusion head coach Daniel Quartararo at 537-1834. The players are Cooper Wilson, Caleb Horne, Cameron Florio, Dillon Grace, Robert Kohler, Micah Colon, Rowan Quartararo, Dominic Riddle, Jose Ramos, Dylan Florio, Parker Parrish and Brandon Bowers. Swimming. Marion County will have three representatives at the Y Nationals swimming event in Indianapolis on Aug. 2. The swimmers are Lindsey Cohee and James Tarquin, both 15, and 14-year-old Olivia Taylor. Meredith Ginn, recovering from an ankle injury, just barely missed qualifying.

South Dakota Fair Housing reasonable accommodations for service animals: • Service/companion animals do not need certification. There are no state or national standards for certifying service animals. • An individual may train his or her own service/companion animal. • Service/companion animals are not pets. A person with a disability uses a service animal as an auxiliary aid — similar to the use of a cane, crutches or a wheelchair. • The only qualification an animal needs to qualify as a service/companion animal is a doctor’s note and a reasonable accommodation request form. • Fair Housing laws require that service/companion animals be permitted in rental housing despite no-pet rules. • Owners of service/companion animals should not be charged pet deposits or fees. • A resident with a service/companion animal is liable for any damage the animal causes. • Service animals may be any breed, size or weight. Source: Paul Flogstad, South Dakota Fair Housing.

SILVERDALE — The storefront that once housed a Forever 21 might shock some Kitsap Mall-goers when they walk by it now. The space is now the home of the Kitsap Art SLAM — the acronym stands for Showcasing Local Artists in the Mall — and doesn’t look much like a store any more. It’s a pop-up art gallery, open to any Kitsap artist, though there is already a waiting list to showcase art. Art is displayed on tables and walls and even the floor has become a living art project. Anyone who visits the gallery can grab some sharpies and leave their (non-profane) mark in the space. Susanna De Santos, who started the project and co-sponsored it, said more than 25 artists have had their work displayed, a number that doesn’t count the hundreds of drawings on the floor. “I don’t know whose work this is on the floor, it’s the community’s,” De Santos said. De Santos said works by are all levels of artists are displayed, from children to careers artists. “There’s people in here who have never shown their work to anybody and that’s really cool to be a part of, and hearing people’s stories,” De Santos said. The gallery has been open since June 19 but must be vacated by July 15. After that, the artists hope to relocate to a more permanent location inside the mall. De Santos said she saw the space and asked if anyone would be using it. Since most of it was going to be gutted for a new store, the mall decided to let the group use it temporarily. “It was a perfect match for these local artists to showcase their pieces in a space we had available for a short period of time,” Erin Leedham, Kitsap Mall general manager, said in an email. “The showcase has exceeded all our expectations.” Kitsap Art SLAM has benefitted from several donations — more than 20 mannequins from the Gap and chairs from Mastercuts, for instance. Each artist is painting a mannequin, and the group has coined the term “art-equin.” Artists plan to auction off the art-equins to help fund a more permanent space. Kahlan Crumbliss found the gallery when her and her family were waiting for a table at Buffalo Wild Wings. De Santos asked if any of them were artists. Crumbless’ dad told De Santos his daughter is. De Santos offered to help display her work and Crumbliss agreed, but only for a few days. Crumbliss leaves this week for her freshman year at Boise State, but she has still come into the SLAM to work on projects and paint her mannequin. “It’s just been so much fun and everyone has been so nice,” Crumbliss said. Chris Mendez, a Coast Guard mechanic and another artist on display, found the gallery in a similar way. He was in the mall with his children when he walked by and knew he had to go inside. “It just felt like a calling,” Mendez said. “I just came on in and said, ‘What’s going on?’” Jerry Mattoon, another artist with work on display, had done art in high school but only took it up full-time after he retired. Mattoon and his wife Beanie have a table set up and have been hanging out in the gallery with the other artists. Mattoon said he learned from his first gallery showing that it’s important for artists to figure out what they want to paint. “Paint what you really want to paint,” Mattoon said. “Satisfy yourself first.” De Santos said the project helps the community get easy access to art, considering the location is a prominent one in Silverdale. “It hard to get to places where you can really appreciate art, and where something is going on that’s different in our town,” De Santos said.

DiffbotBody: President Barack Obama is headed to a federal prison in El Reno, Oklahoma, next Thursday, the first trip of its kind for a sitting president. The trip, where Obama will meet with law enforcement officials and inmates, comes as part of his administration's focus on criminal justice reform, Politico reports. While at the medium-security facility, Obama will also interview with Vice for a documentary airing this fall on HBO. Obama is expected to further push the issue of criminal justice next week by commuting nonviolent drug sentences for dozens of federal prisoners. Julie Kliegman
LabBody: Martin O'Malley wants the U.S. to accept as many as 13 times the number of Syrian refugees it currently plans to take in. The former Maryland governor and Democratic presidential candidate called Friday for the U.S. to up its plans to accept between 5,000 to 8,000 immigrants to "at least 65,000 Syrian refugees by the end of 2016." O'Malley cited the photos of 3-year-old Aylan Kurdi, who washed up dead on a Turkish beach after a failed attempt to sail from Turkey to Greece, for stirring his moral obligation to urge Americans to do more to help some four million Syrian refugees. "Americans are a generous and compassionate people. But today our policies are falling short of those values," O'Malley said in a statement. "If Germany — a country with one-fourth our population — can accept 800,000 refugees this year, certainly we — the nation of immigrants and refugees — can do more." As Europe faces an influx of migrants from Africa, Afghanistan, and the Middle East — a record 107,500 migrants entered the European Union in July alone — O'Malley contends that Americans are "not immune from the injustices and tragedies that unfold outside our borders." So far, according to numbers from the International Rescue Committee (IRC) reported by Newsweek, only 1,541 Syrian refugees have arrived in the U.S.

Hyderabad: Minister Pocharam Srinivas Reddy’s driver was allegedly beaten up and injured by film actor Mohan Babu’s security guards in front of the actor’s house in Banjara Hills on Sunday. Local police has taken the attackers into custody. Driver N. Nagaraju told the police that he was standing near Mohan Babu’s house while waiting for his friends. Two men guarding the actor’s house asked him to move away. Nagaraju refused and an argument ensued following which he was beaten up. “Nagaraju was waiting there since the house is a landmark,” said an official from the Banjara Hills police.He said two body guards and two drivers of the actor assaulted him. Nagaraju sustained an injury to his hand. A police team reached the spot following an alert from onlookers, and arrested the four attackers. Police registered a case against the accused for causing injury and criminal intimidation.

LabBody: WILTON — At its regular meeting on Monday night, the Board of Selectmen discussed the process of implementing the $425,000 Main Street grant, more than a year after the Department of Housing awarded the money to the town. “The Bond Commission had not blessed the whole thing, but finally did,” said First Selectman Bill Brennan. “We got the grant in April 2015, and based on the requirements, the money is there. The goal and main focus is to improve safety and quality of life in Town Center.” Aesthetics and safety of the sidewalks and walkways in the area near Starbuck’s off River Road is the focal point. “Brick facing — we want that woven into the entire area,” Brennan said. “We want to be (Americans with Disabilities Act) compliant at the intersections. We will add sidewalks at certain areas.” Part of the plan will include “integrated pavement” across the roadways, where brick-like crosswalks will serve several purposes, according to Brennan. “They give a distinct look, they are visually distinctive, and it calms drivers because they think there may be a bump,” Brennan said. “Georgetown has them.” The first selectman said after requests for proposals went out, Langan Engineering and Environmental Services out of New Haven will design the project. “Langan is in the process of briefing the Board of Selectmen, the Norwalk River Valley Trail and the Chamber of Commerce. We have the $425,000 grant. The town has a portion of in-kind contribution. The request is for the plan to be appropriate. There is not money (in the grant) for plans. We paid for them.” Most of the development will be along River Road, Godfrey Place and around Veterans Memorial Green, according to Brennan. “There’s a long narrow strip of grass that just won’t grow; it’s just weeds,” Brennan said. “That will be excavated for bricks. At the intersections, some are all brick, and each one of the corners will get ADA compliant. This will start to improve the look of the town and integrate designs. Basically, with the direction we’re going, we think we have an accurate plan. We can’t do anything outside the village, and it has to do with sidewalks. We have to pay for the plans ourselves.” Bob Nerney, director of land use management for the town, said he was surprised Wilton even got the grant in the first place. “Really what this program is for is distressed downtown communities, and to be honest I didn’t think we had a chance for it,” Nerney said. “I wouldn’t put us in the distressed category. “We needed to put a good design plan in place,” he said. “I think moving ahead and putting a good plan in place is important. This seems like a very good plan. We’re passing on the ideas to the police department for the crosswalks. It looked for the most part to be in public right of way.” Now the plan must go to the Department of Housing for final approval, then contracts must be sought and signed. It’s already approaching mid-July. “The concern we have is doing this (project) when there’s low traffic,” Brennan said. “We have to get approval from the Department of Housing, then bids and contracts, somewhat sequentially. We’d like to get the street impact before we pave River Road. We have to get (River Road) paved before next winter.” Brennan described this plan as “complementary” and not something is going to alter the landscape. “We’re not putting in ‘vest pocket’ parks,” Brennan said. “We’re not changing a lot of aspects of Town Center. We don’t have a lot of flexibility. What we’re going to do is create a better appearance. If the town looks better, it attracts more business. We had a good application. This will make the downtown more attractive and safer. When it’s all done it will look better and be safer.”

MANILA – Filipinos tend to be loyal to brands they have used for a long time, which is good for companies that have popular brands and bad for those not too popular with the country's fast-growing consumer base. Michaelangelo Oyson, chief executive and managing director at BPI Trade, said sticking to popular brands is a common theme among emerging markets, even in Mexico and India. "The population stick to brands as guidelines for their purchases," Oyson told ANC's "On The Money." Oyson said some of the household names in the Philippines include Ayala, SM, Jollibee, and URC (Universal Robina Corp.). “It’s because they trust them, there is a brand equity, they have brand loyalty. They have a perception that they can relate and trust the brand,” he said. But what does this brand loyalty mean to investors? According to Oyson, a study by JP Morgan found that brand value accounts for one-third of the value of a company. "Part of that is due to the fact that people tend to pay a higher multiple to company they can trust," Oyson explained. "That's why in the case of Ayala Land, for example, they're trading in the price-to-earnings multiple of the high 20s because people trust the brand. Same thing in the case of Jollibee, which is trading close to 40 times PE in the second quarter," he added. Oyson noted that investors in the stck market will have to sift through about 200 names in the equity space, and some resort to brand familiarity. He said it takes a lot of years of guiding customers, and producing high quality product for companies to earn the trust of consumers and investors. He said some brands, however, take a shortcut to building brands by picking "ambassadors" who are well-known to the public and have a good reputation. “They want to associate the trust that the public has on these individuals with the company,” he said. For investors, Oyson said the current market pullback offers an opportunity to buy good brands at a lower price. "You don’t want to buy high-quality brands when stocks are flying. You want to buy when foreigners are selling,” he said. Another strategy is to buy the same brands over and over again because it is hard to time the market. Oyson said because big brands don’t normally have high volatility, they are typically not for trading. To manage downside risk by choosing big brands, Oyson suggests looking at the historical performance of companies over the last 10 years. The top 10 members of the Philippine composite index were there 10 years ago and are still there today, he said.

We've all been guilty of ripping our USB drives out of our computers instead of ejecting them properly, only to receive the judgemental pop up telling us we really shouldn't have done that. But when everything on the USB works fine next time you plug it in, you can't help but wonder: does it actually do anything when you safely eject your disk before removing it? Well, we've done a little background research, and it turns out that it does. In fact, waiting those extra 30 seconds to safely eject could help to properly save your data and software. But the risk really depends on your operating system, and what you're actually doing with your USB drive. As Phillip Remaker explains over at Quora (in a response that now has more than 11,000 views), our operating systems have been programmed to treat our external drives - like USB sticks - like they'll always be there. It expects the files on it to remain accessible indefinitely and this changes the way it interacts with a flash drive. This means if a program on your computer is just reading a file and not actually saving any information to the drive, it's probably not going mess things up too much for the files on your USB stick if you suddenly yank it out. But you do risk confusing your computer, says Remaker. "Symptoms could include: Lost data, corrupted filesystems, crashing programs, or hanging computers requiring a reboot." On the other hand, if you've altered or uploaded new information to your drive at some point, no matter how long ago, things are a bit more risky. That's because our operating systems are too efficient to simply stop what they're doing and save information whenever you tell it to. Instead, most are programmed to do what's known as 'write caching'. Rachel Z. Arndt explains what that means over at Popular Mechanics: "For efficiency's sake, they don't actually write the files you're moving to the disk until there are multiple files to move. Ejecting the disk is a way of telling the computer that it's time to do the writing, regardless of whether the computer deems it efficient. When you remove a flash drive without warning the computer first, it might not have finished writing to the drive." This means that pulling your external drive out without warning could result in the file you just saved being lost forever - even if you saved it hours ago. So how does the "safely remove hardware" command fix this problem? As Remaker explains, the command does the following things: It flushes all active writes to disk. It alerts all programs (that know how to be alerted) that the disk is going away, and to take appropriate action. It alerts the user when programs have failed to take action, and still are holding files open. Of course, modern operating systems are getting better and better and preparing for us to pull the rug out from under them by trying to write and read files as quickly as possible. Windows has even introduced a feature called "Optimise for Quick Removal" that you can select to make sure files are written quickly, rather than by write caching, which is the most efficient way. But you can still never be sure exactly when your computer is done with your external flash drive, and that makes pulling it out a big gamble. Bottom line? "You can remove a disk at any time, but you are at the mercy of how well programs using the disk cope with the sudden disappearance of that disk," says Remaker. So go on and continue living life on the edge, ripping those USB drives out with abandon if you really don't have the 30 seconds to spare. But just remember what's at stake next time you're saving precious information (say, the new Game of Thrones episode...legally downloaded, of course) onto your USB drive. H/T: Gizmodo.

A convicted sex offender is wanted on charges of kidnapping and sexual battery after drugging and raping a woman in the Orange City area, an official said. The 20-year-old woman said she met Jason Minton on Monday and agreed to go out with him for dinner that evening, Volusia County sheriff's spokesman Gary Davidson said. The woman said Minton, 39, instead took her to a bar where he bought her several drinks. After leaving the bar, Minton took her to his home in the 200 block of West Minnesota Avenue home and forced an unknown pill down the woman's throat, Davidson said. As the incapacitated woman faded in and out of consciousness, she realized Minton was sexually battering her, Davidson said. Eventually, Minton climbed off of the woman who then ran to her own home and was taken to a hospital by a relative. Minton has not been seen since Monday night, Davidson said. He is about 5 feet 8 inches and 170 pounds with brown hair and brown eyes. Records show Minton was convicted in 2006 of principal to lewd assault/sexual battery on a victim under the age of 16 and failing to register as a sex offender. Anyone with information is asked to contact the Sheriff's Office or call Crime Stoppers at 1-888-277-TIPS (8477).

About once every nine months, I make my shout into the canyon that is inexplicable Internet behavior. I never expect universal change, but if I can make one person understand that their behavior is baffling, well, it makes a difference to that person, doesn't it? Almost daily over the last couple of weeks, I've seen different people respond to posts on the Herald & Review's Facebook and elsewhere with three baffling words: “This is news?” There's one time I find this attitude, albeit not that phrasing, appropriate: In response to fresh posts about years-ago celebrity deaths. If someone posts a fond farewell to Peter Falk as though he's just passed, it's OK to point out that news is four-years-old. And even then, I try to keep in mind the mindset and Internet presence of the poster. For some, Falk's death (or Jane Russell's, or Anne Francis') could easily have escaped their notice. More often, the remark comes on an offbeat or fun story. A couple of years ago, a post on our Facebook page about how the price of “Two Buck Chuck” (Charles Shaw wine) going up in price found us being lit up by the Facebook news police. They observed “old news,” “irrelevant,” “not news” and “it must be a slow news day in Decatur.” Any or all of those observations might have been accurate. But more accurate was each person took the time to give their very public and very pointed opinion via social media. It was important enough as “not news” that they felt compelled to point it out. I suppose I should instead think about the hundreds or thousands who saw that headline and clicked through and smiled, or thought “Big deal” and shrugged and moved on. But I can't help thinking about the others, like the ones who go through the trouble of registering on our website just to respond to a story with a comment of one of two words. Punishable offense? Not by any stretch of anyone's imagination. Baffling? Indeed.

ORLANDO | Every year there is a player who looks too good for the Orlando Pro Summer League. In the weeklong league ruled by unproven rookies and unheralded journeyman, Magic forward Aaron Gordon played just three games — but he might have staked claim to that title in limited action. Gordon did a little bit of everything, averaging 21.7 points and 11.7 rebounds per game for Orlando, leading the league in both categories. But individual success doesn't trump team success — even in the summer. "I'm very happy with the work I've shown in my game," Gordon said. "We lost too many games here, and that's really what it comes down to; we lost too many. I'm just looking at the team to improve and to continue to get better and come back ready for training camp." While he played in just three games this week, Gordon was impressive from the start. The second-year forward pulled down a summer record-tying 18 rebounds in the Magic's first game, and continued to do a little bit of everything in the ensuing games. Point guard Elfrid Payton and this year's No. 5 overall pick, Mario Hezonja, also showed potential this week, though they each played only two games. When Gordon, Payton and Hezonja played, the team finished 1-1, but otherwise was 0-3. "Aaron had a good week, obviously," said new Magic head coach Scott Skiles. "Mario got to get his feet wet with the NBA-type competition. Guys are just trying to get used to the staff and the kinds of things we expect. It's been a good week so far." After putting together an impressive all-around effort in the summer league last season, Payton piled up 13 assists in two games this time around. Hezonja, whose European season just finished last month, shot just 38 percent from the field but scored 26 points in a pair of games. His dunk over Oklahoma City center Richard Solomon on Monday was one of the week's top plays. "Really comfortable because I know almost everything — media, practice," said Hezonja, who finalized his contract with the team Friday. General manager Rob Hennigan announced the deal Friday. Terms were not disclosed. "The summer league, though, all of this professional stuff, I'm used to doing it now for nine years," Hezonja said. OTHER ROOKIES. With the Magic's big trio only playing together the first two games, it opened the door for former second-round picks Devyn Marble and Tyler Harvey. The duo played well on Thursday. Harvey led the way with 24 points and five assists while Marble chipped in 22 points and grabbed seven rebounds for the Orlando Blue team, one of the Magic's two summer teams. The citizens of Rochester missed out on a big celebration this year, which they have come to expect on the night before the Fourth of July. Over the years, the Rochester Fairgrounds have been the place to mark Independence Day in the Lilac City, with the annual fireworks bringing many in the community together. This year, though, residents had to look outside of the city to have a real celebration. According to city officials, Rochester fireworks have historically been put on by a volunteer organization. Previously, the fireworks have been organized by the Rochester Jaycees. When the Jaycees decided years back that they could no longer do it, the Journey Baptist Church stepped in six years ago and began organizing the event. It is clear how beneficial and the Night Before the Fourth event has been to the community. Through leadership of the church, the celebration not only benefited the eventgoers, but also Gerry's Food Pantry; those at the event were encouraged to bring donations of nonperishable items for the pantry. The patriotic annual event has also featured participation by the Ancient Order of Hibernians bagpipers, the Rochester Veterans' Council, and Spaulding High School Jr. ROTC, among other local organizations. That is, until this year. Community Service Coordinator Lisa Ball, of Journey Baptist Church, said the church would not be doing fireworks this year to focus on other projects. Whether a new organization will step up to the plate to organize the city's fireworks remains up in the air. Samantha Rodgerson, who works as the executive assistant to the city manager and City Council, recently said that the city of Rochester does not traditionally fund the fireworks display, and spending public dollars on the celebration would require City Council approval. We hope that the city will not have to seek that route to ensure a great fireworks celebration to mark Fourth of July in future years. Rather, our hope is for another volunteer organization to step up and organize the event, just as Journey Baptist Church did six years ago. And it is good to remember the amount of planning that needs to go into such a project. As Ball said in a recent interview, making the celebration happen is "very labor-intensive," and requires around nine months of planning and more than 300 volunteers. This is why we hope that efforts to bring next year's celebration, through a volunteer organization, will begin as soon as possible.

A: Growing up in south Oklahoma City, I remember receiving a chuckle at the local Lions Club as a high school junior when I told them my plans were to become either a CPA or an airline stewardess. I eventually chose my college major based solely on the fact that my two older brothers were accounting majors. I began my career as an auditor and am now a financial adviser and Certified Financial Planner. Q: What drew you to financial planning? A: I most enjoy working with clients to help them realize their financial aspirations and understand risk/reward tradeoffs in investing. Q: Talk about the accounting profession in Oklahoma. A: In Oklahoma and across America, the accounting profession is one of the best areas of opportunity for young people. The demand for accounting services remains strong, and accounting remains one of the most respected, trusted and dynamic professions. Q: In your term, what are your top goals?

score box. Doubledays 13. Muckdogs 1. The Auburn Doubledays bats' exploded for 14 hits as they beat Batavia 13-1 at Dwyer Stadium on Friday night. Auburn snapped a three-game losing streak with the lopsided win. Thursday night's scheduled game at Falcon Park was postponed to Aug. 15. Jefry Rodriguez (1-2) earned his first win of the season, fanning eight batters, allowing two hits and just one earned run in six innings. In relief, neither Grant Borne or Tommy Peterson allowed a walk or run. For the Muckdogs, Jordan Holloway suffered the loss in four innings of work, walking six and giving up three earned runs. Auburn began the game hot, scoring twice in the first inning and once in each the second and third. They piled on extra runs at the end, with three each in the final two innings. Centerfielder Andrew Stevenson extended his hitting streak to seven games, with two hits and two RBI. Nearly every Auburn player had a hit, with designated hitter Ian Sagdal going 2-for-4 with four RBI and second baseman Max Schrock going 3-for-6 with two runs and an RBI. David Kerian also went 2-for-3 with two RBI. Auburn (8-11) returns home on Saturday for the first of three games with Staten Island. Copyright 2015 Auburn Citizen. All rights reserved. DENVER - Carlos Gonzalez hit three doubles, Nolan Arenado had three hits for the second consecutive night and the Colorado Rockies beat the Atlanta Braves 5-3 on a rain-soaked Thursday at Coors Field. Troy Tulowitzki singled to extend his hitting streak to 21 games -- longest in the majors this season -- for the Rockies, who dealt with another weather delay at home. Jace Peterson had two hits and two RBIs, and Chris Johnson had three hits for the Braves. A rainstorm came through two pitches into the bottom of the first inning and sent the players and fans scurrying for shelter. The delay lasted 2 hours, 6 minutes, and ended the night early for both starters. David Hale, the scheduled starter Friday for Colorado, took over for Kyle Kendrick in the second but left with one out in the third with a mild left groin strain. Hale (3-4) went 1 2-3 innings to get the win.

DiffbotBody: Get ready to bump up your traditional fishtail plait with Emma's messy, textured do. Celeb hair stylist Nikki Lee softly French-braided two sections of the actress's hair across the back of her head in a diagonal direction. Below that, she took two more sections and knotted them together, then joined the knot and French braid together with a rubber band. To finish the look, she spritzed on Oribe Dry Texturizing Spray to hold the style in place. This braid may just be her "crowning" style moment of the summer! Victoria sported a major plait across her forehead, leaving the rest of her locks down. To nail the look, done by hairstylist Laura Polko, simply divide hair into two sections (top and bottom). Then braid the top half from the back and bring it across your forehead, pulling at the section closest to your hairline to create a messy, undone look. Secure with pins on each side and you're done! NORTH LITTLE ROCK, ARK. Bruce Maxwell drove in Chad Pinder twice, but the efforts from the designated hitter and shortstop were not enough for Midland Friday night on the road, as the Arkansas Travelers completed a three-game sweep and downed the RockHounds 3-2. Arkansas (44-40, 8-7 second half) held Midland (44-41, 9-6) to just four hits in each game of the series, including Friday night’s contest. Maxwell and Pinder accounted for each of those four hits Friday. Pinder singled before crossing home plate on an RBI single by Maxwell in the top of the second, then history repeated itself in the seventh, as Maxwell’s base hit scored Pinder again. But the Travelers scored two runs in the bottom of the eighth, on top of a run scored in the sixth, to pick up the win. The RockHounds will now travel across the Natural State from North Little Rock to Springdale for a three-game series against Northwest Arkansas (44-40, 4-10).

Drought, craggy sidewalks, bikes, public safety, Mideast peace, gender and race issues, politics – if it’s in the news right now, The Times’ Opinion section covers it. Expect to read about a broad range of issues in our newsletters, focusing on the most pertinent, discussed topics of the day. Expect to read pieces that challenge your own opinions or, if you agree with the article, add complexity to or present a novel take on an issue. Expect smart writers, thoughtful contributions from readers and encouragement to participate in ongoing discussions. While the Opinion newsletter features mostly editorials, Op-Ed articles and columns, reader engagement is a key component of what we do. If you have any suggestions for our newsletter, please let us know. I’m Paul Thornton, The Times’ letters editor and a California native and lifelong resident. I learned how to read partly by sharing the morning L.A. Times with my grandparents, so this place seemed like a good fit when I started working here as an intern in 2004 and then permanently as researcher for the opinion pages in 2005. In the 10 years since then, I’ve written for the Opinion L.A. blog and the editorial page, worked as a Web producer and edited the letters page. I was raised in Glendale but split my time between Northern and Southern California, graduating from UC Berkeley before coming to The Times. In my job as letters editor, I have developed a deep respect and gratitude for the contributions of our readers, and a keen awareness of how the commentary we feature can affect the discussion on a topic. I hope to reflect that in our newsletter.
