What ever did we do without the SEC Network during the Southeastern Conference football media days? Straight out of the last hurrah for the first “SEC Network Takeover” — Texas A&M is featured Saturday, followed finally by Vanderbilt on Sunday — the league’s channel turns its attention to what the SEC’s followers love almost as much as the games in the fall on the gridiron themselves. Bring on coaches, players and talking heads chattering on about said upcoming contests ... and babbling on some more. Since the SEC Network debuted last August and almost immediately went into covering football games, this is perhaps the next premiere that has been most anticipated, as the fancy separate logo would indicate. As team representatives and the reporters that cover them gather for four days in Hoover, Ala., the SEC Network will have it all on lockdown. Starting at 11:30 a.m. Monday with new SEC Commissioner Greg Sankey’s opening address, the SEC Network will be there with coverage with its “SEC Now: 2015 Football Media Days Special,” which is hosted by Dari Nowkhah and Joe Tessitore and runs that initial day until 4:30 p.m. On Tuesday and Wednesday, it airs from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., and on Thursday, 9 a.m. to noon. Analysts and guests joining Nowkhah and Tessitore will be Greg McElroy, Booger McFarland and Marcus Spears. It’s during these windows that the coaches’ press conferences will air, along with interviews with the coaches and players who were selected to attend. For Missouri, as Tribune beat writer David Morrison has noted on his blog and Twitter, that means Coach Gary Pinkel and quarterback Maty Mauk and center Evan Boehm — media days vets both — and cornerback Kenya Dennis, the newcomer to the Hyatt Regency Birmingham-The Wynfrey Hotel, will have their time in front of the press corps starting at 1 p.m. Wednesday. Dennis also will be the MU athlete featured in additional coverage on the SEC Network via the league’s “Beyond the Field: Stories of the SEC” initiative, which focuses on a player from each team with “a compelling story outside of his athletic endeavors.” “The Paul Finebaum Show,” both on the SEC Network on TV and ESPN Radio, will originate from Hoover, too, kicking off at its regular start time of 2 p.m. on the latter and, on the former, 4:30 p.m. Monday, 3 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday and 2 p.m. Thursday. SOUND FAMILIAR?: Fans of Missouri basketball anticipating a down-and-dirty battle for 2017 recruit Michael Porter Jr. of Tolton can look to Fayetteville, Ark., for clues on how to handle a similar fight to keep a top prospect close to home and, in the process, away from powerhouse SEC rival Kentucky. Like Porter — rated the No. 2 recruit in 2017 by ESPN, Rivals and 247Sports and No. 3 by Scout — Bentonville, Ark.’s Malik Monk is a consensus top-10 prospect in the Class of 2016. On Friday, CBSSports.com’s Gary Parrish noted that while there are many compelling recruiting stories this coming year — including ESPN’s No. 1 and 2, Harry Giles and St. Louis’ Jayson Tatum, teammates on the recent USA Under-19 world-championship squad, possibly being a package deal — none has his attention more than Monk’s. “For those who don’t know: Malik Monk is a 6-foot-4 guard from Arkansas who doubles as the younger brother of Marcus Monk — a former football and basketball player for the Razorbacks who, more recently, spent time working as what amounts to a graduate assistant in Mike Anderson’s program,” Parrish wrote. “He now helps run the Arkansas Wings summer program for which Malik Monk plays. And did I mention that their cousin is Ky Madden, who averaged 9.7 points last season for an Arkansas team that made the NCAA Tournament. “Simply put, Malik Monk’s ties to Arkansas are endless and strong.” But enter John Calipari, who is dangling the glitz and glamour of the Wildcats and the surest path to the NBA in front of Monk. “Mostly every day fans tell me to go to Arkansas,” Monk said. “But there’s no pressure at all.” “I believe the first part of the quote,” Parrish wrote. “But I’m not buying the second part at all. Because, let’s be honest, the pressure has to be extraordinary, doesn’t it? I mean, can Malik Monk really leave home and endure what would be an intense backlash? And can Marcus Monk really let his brother leave the state when he A) played at Arkansas, B) previously worked with Arkansas, C) lives in Fayetteville and D) now helps run the Arkansas Wings? “That’s what John Calipari is up against here.” Sure, but with Cal’s track record, all that easily could mean squat. And if Monk does stick with the Hogs, nobody pities Big Blue.

To take up less space on their Mac hard drive, some users opt to move iTunes backups externally. I wrote a Mac Help piece about this quite some time ago and still get mail regularly. What happens when you don't want to use an external drive to back up your iOS devices anymore? Well, no panicking: It's easy to undo. AK writes: "I read your article about storing iPhone backups on an external drive I tried that and it worked flawlessly. But what am I supposed to do to revert back the changes and make backups to be stored locally again? Carrying an external hard drive everywhere is a real pain." So here's the deal: You need to delete the Backup symbolic link you created as a result of following those directions. Creaitng the symlink is a bit of a pain because it requires some command line trickery in Terminal. Fortunately, rectifying the change is much easier: It's something you can do from the comfort of OS X's graphical user interface instead. To do so: Open the Finder. Hold down the Option key and click on the Go menu. Select Library. Click on Application Support, then click on MobileSync. Delete the file labeled Backup. That's the symbolic link you created, which goes to the external drive. iTunes should now resume normal local backups of your iOS devices unless you tell it otherwise.
Category: Eye candy, Fuego.

Bethenny Frankel is back on The Real Housewives of New York and while her former frenemies, Kelly Bensimon and Jill Zarin, are not back on the show with her, she can easily find someone to bicker with. Frankel didn’t hit it off with Heather Thomson or Kristen Taekman, but during the dramatic final dinner in Turks and Caicos, she managed to fly under the radar. According to a new Bravo report, Bethenny Frankel is now revealing that she actually thought the cursing dinner was hilarious. The drama was reaching an all-time high with these ladies, but since Bethenny wasn’t involved, she found it funny and entertaining. “The cursing dinner was hilarious. It should be called the hypocrite dinner. Heather can curse all she wants and literally DOES NOT curse more than anyone including Luann, Sonja and Dorinda,” Bethenny points out, adding, “These women are all full of SH--. They all curse like drunken sailors. Ramona doesn't cop to her words, her actions, or her sex life. Why would she cop to her words?” Of course, the episode continues next week with the dramatic conclusion to the dinner. But even though Kristen isn’t Bethenny Frankel’s closest friend, she did add some comic relief to the final dinner. And apparently, Taekman’s actions made Bethenny laugh throughout the episode. “My favorite moment was Kristen grabbing for the wine. That was physical comedy, and I'm not sure if you heard but when Dorinda was leaving the restaurant like a hot mess, you hear in the background Sonja saying "what kind of vodka was that?" Lol, I enjoyed this scene,” Frankel adds. It will be interesting to see how the women deal with one another during the Real Housewives of New York reunion, which filmed in New York yesterday. What do you think of Bethenny Frankel calling out her co-stars?

Brazos Valley teams will be on both ends of that spectrum when play begins Thursday in Division II (smaller schools) at Veteran’s Park and Athletic Complex.

Carlos Arturo Torres Tovar of the Umeå Institute of Design helped create an ingenious prosthetic that can be modified—all that's needed are some LEGO bricks. Called the IKO, the design comes with a four-fingered (non-LEGO) hand prosthetic. What makes it different from other prosthetics is that the person using it can remove the hand and construct whatever he or she desires out of LEGO bricks to replace it, leading to infinite possibilities. It is designed to help with the psychological aspects of needing a prosthetic, which is something that is often overlooked. In a video promoting the new invention, the designer works with a Colombian boy named Dario. The goal was to make a playful experience for Dario, one that would allow him him to create, explore, and be a typical kid. It's hoped that the prosthetic will make it easier for kids to interact with other children while breaking down barriers that might stand in the way of confidence. Check out the video below for more: [h/t Gizmodo]

Basic cadets compete at Field Day Air Force basic cadet trainees compete in a variety of different athletic competitions during Field Day Friday, July 10, 2015. Field Day marks the end of the first half of basic cadet training. Members of the Demons basic cadet squadron sprint down the field during the log relay during Field Day competitions Friday, July 10, 2015. Basic cadets in squadrons A through H competed in a variety of athletic events from a guerrilla relay to tug-of-war to determine the top squadron of the Class of 2019. The athletic event marks the end of the first half of basic cadet training. Michael Ciaglo, The Gazette

Ariana Grande is apologizing for her donut store disaster, again. The singer posted a four-minute apology video on Thursday talking about being "disgusted" after seeing herself on the security footage. In the video, Grande says she wants to be better for her "babes" and apologizes for her "disappointing" behavior. "I never want to be anything but a positive influence on my babes or my loves or anyone who pays attention to me for that matter," Grande said. "So, I feel like I let ya'll down." Earlier this week, TMZ released a security tape of the star behaving badly in a California donut shop. If you haven't seen the video, it shows Grande licking a donut that does not belong to her then yelling, "I hate Americans. I hate America," when a worker walks out with a tray of donuts. Grande originally submitted an apology to Us Weekly citing her healthy eating advocacy as the reason behind her outburst. --- Follow Alyssa Pasicznyk on Twitter Download the newsnet5 app:

When the temperature soars, gardeners typically outdoor work early or late when it’s a little cooler. This reduces the chance of various forms of physical injury and emotional defeat. The same consideration should be given to plants. Certain practices need to be performed when the environmental conditions are right to reduce plant damage. Pest management is a big one. If you plan to treat a plant for a pest, check the label for the recommended temperature ranges for spraying. Spraying a plant at 2 p.m. in 90-plus temperatures can bring a plant to its knees. These conditions can cause leaf burn at the very least. Also, make sure the pest is truly harmful and at a population high enough to cause significant damage. Choose a pesticide that is easy on the environment and will give good control. If a foliar spray is warranted, spray early or late in the day when the wind speed is low. Make sure the plant has been well watered and isn’t suffering from heat, drought or other forms of stress which can worsen the damage. While it isn’t exciting, reading the label and following directions can help avoid plant damage and environmental damage. Foliar fertilizing is another activity to avoid in the middle of a hot, sunny day. If the plant is pest, heat or drought stressed, give it time to recover before fertilizing. Fertilizer isn’t a cure-all for stressed plants, in fact, it can actually cause more stress. If using a dry granular fertilizer, make sure the soil is moist before applying and follow with a good irrigation. Using a herbicide on weeds? Make sure they are stress free and avoid the middle of the day spray. Weeds need to be healthy and stress free for a herbicide to work correctly. If the soil is dry and the conditions are hot, dry and windy...wait for better conditions. Stressed weeds can’t take up the herbicide properly so it is often wasted time, money and effort. Trenching, digging, and other repair or construction activities around the root system of plants should be avoided during the heat of summer. Fall, winter and spring are much better times to disturb the root system if that has to happen. Roots grow laterally in the soil, not straight down. So even if you are digging away from the trunk or stem of a plant, if it is inside or near the dripline you can be damaging the roots. If it’s just a few roots it shouldn’t cause significant harm, but if it involves a good deal of the roots, then wait for better conditions. Sprinkle irrigation is another activity that should be avoided in the middle of the day, especially if the irrigation water is high in salts. This harmful practice can lead to yellowing, leaf browning and defoliation depending on the plant, irrigation water quality, temperature and humidity. In addition to causing leaf damage, day time sprinkler irrigation is more prone to drift and evaporate. So, give your plants a break by sprinkle irrigating during the early morning, late evening or nighttime hours. Find re-leaf for your plants by timing your cultural practices to coincide with good growing conditions. >> Debbie Frost is a local horticulturist specializing in regionally appropriate horticulture, garden.frost@gmail.com. >> Debbie Frost is a local horticulturist specializing in regionally appropriate horticulture, garden.frost@gmail.com.

At E3 2015, not only was there a significant increase in the number of women presenting games at the expo's big press conferences, but the games themselves saw more playable female characters come to the fore. Here's a look at the biggest games with the biggest female names attached to them. A note on how we decided which games to include: we only picked games whose playable female protagonists are unique characters unto themselves. This means games where you have the option to play as a male or female version of the same character, such as Mass Effect: Andromeda, Fallout 4, and Call of Duty: Black Ops III, aren't included. However, games where a choice between a male and female player exists with those two protagonists being unique and separate characters, are included. Though DICE is being quite heavy-handed in its positioning of Faith as "a catalyst for change" (geddit?), it's interesting that the developer has made the character powerful and self-sufficient without allowing her to even pick up guns this time around. In Mirror's Edge Catalyst, Faith fights on her own terms. Emily Kaldwin in Dishonored 2. Daughter to Dishonored protagonist Corvo Attano and Empress of the Isles, Emily Kaldwin is a playable character is Dishonored 2 alongside her father. Not only will choosing to play as her offer unique perspectives on each mission, but she has an entirely new set of otherworldly powers that are separate from Corvo's. There is little else that's more badass than fighting robotic dinosaurs with a bow and arrow, but that's daily life for Aloy in Horizon: Zero Dawn. We see her training, crafting, and ultimately hunting her mechanical prey with agility, guile, and a variety of different arrow types. Her dialogue suggests she belongs to the game's oldest, more advanced tribe. Lara Croft established herself as a strong-willed survivor in 2013's Tomb Raider reboot. With that origin story complete, we're now going to see her transformation into her eponymous role in Rise of the Tomb Raider. While a survivor is always on the back foot, this time around Lara seems more of the active adventurer: smarter, and more experienced. Jewel in ReCore. A new IP from the creators of Mega Man and Metroid Prime, ReCore follows a character named Jewel and her robotic dog companion, who is trying to help her bring humanity back to the game's planet. Jewel must explore the planet's sand-swept surface and dark underground vaults while retrieving robotic cores to activate new companions. Evie Frye was announced as a playable protagonist when Assassin's Creed: Syndicate was revealed, but it wasn't until E3 2015 that we actually saw her in action. In contrast to her brawler brother, Jacob, Evie offers more stealth-focused gameplay, and her missions take a more investigative tone than the street-level fist-fights we saw previously. Senua in Hellblade. Developer Ninja Theory is exploring mental health and psychosis through Senua, the main character of the studio's new game, Hellblade. You'll explore the depths of Senua's mind as the symptoms of our own mental issues are represented in the world itself, or heard through voices in her head. Those representations will become more literal as the game progresses.

Sidekicks rarely shine when thrust into the spotlight, but what about a few hundred of them? The Minions, having been the best part of the two previous "Despicable Me" movies, have swarmed the screen in "Minions." As candidates for center stage, they are seemingly ill-suited. Slavishly — if rarely competently — devoted lackeys, they're underlings by both definition and verticality. They don't speak intelligibly, which, to be fair, isn't a bar all of Hollywood's leading men reach. Instead, they talk in a bright babble that belies their fondness for colorful phonetics. "Banana" and "piñata" are their kind of words. Their unsuitability for the lead role, or just about anything else, is much of the fun of "Minions," a happy henchmen overload that largely succeeds in its simple mission: More Minions! Directed by Pierre Coffin (who co-directed "Despicable Me" one and two and voices the Minions) and Kyle Balda, "Minions" begins in fine form. The little yellow ones are already humming the Universal theme as the film begins. With Geoffrey Rush narrating, we get the history of the Minions, which stretches back across eons and begins with them — a curios early mammal — literally walking out of the sea. But the evolution stops there. For thousands of years, we see, they've been letting down their evil masters, from a Tyrannosaurus Rex accidentally tipped into a volcano, to Dracula, whom they excitedly wake with a birthday cake and wide-open blinds. The Minions have their own Ice Age, however, ending up leaderless in Antarctica. After a few hundred years, the joy of snow ball fights beginning to dim, three of them — Kevin, Bob and Stuart — set out on a quest to find a new supervillain to idolize. Soon, they're on their way to Villain-Con, a riff on Comic-Con only a convention celebrating the likes of Scarlet Overkill (Sandra Bullock), an evil world-conqueror in a beehive. The trio inadvertently wins a job in Overkill's entourage, and they're soon enmeshed in her plan to take the British throne, along with Overkill's inventor, Herb (Jon Hamm). There are, it should be noted, more ambitious seats of power to set one's diabolical sights on. But this is 1960s Swinging London, a colorful if over-familiar backdrop, and the goggle-wearing Minions could just as well be chipper Mods. The irreverent slapstick unfortunately gives way to the kind of action set pieces that have now even corrupted children's movies. The bombast, though never serious, is still loud enough to, for too long, drown out the best thing the movie has going for it: The chuckles and squeaks of the Minions. It also makes it harder to hear the other key sound accompanying the Minions: the laughter of children. What are the Minions but stand-ins for kids? Mumbling half-understood words by the mouthful, they plunge headlong into any task, usually wielding a dangerous object they shouldn't. Nothing makes them double over like a good pratfall, and they will insist on a goodnight kiss or bedtime story. Teaming and relentless, they will melt the heart of any guardian, even a supervillain. Coming on the heels of Pixar's "Inside Out," an emotional wallop that most knocks out misty-eyed adults, "Minions" is a different beast. This one's for the kids. "Minions," a Universal Pictures release, is rated PG by the Motion Picture Association of America for "action and rude humor." Running time: 91 minutes. Two and a half stars out of four.

They were searching for a four-door, black Buick with tinted windows, which was believed to be headed toward Kennedy Plaza with four people inside it.

The World Cup victory by the U.S. women’s soccer team was the latest feel-good moment in the evolution of women’s sports. Interest, whether measured by live attendance or TV viewership, has never been higher. The U.S. team’s 5-2 win over Japan unleashed a celebration by the players in Vancouver, and in myriad places across the country where viewing parties were the rage. While showcasing the players’ athleticism, skill, teamwork and determination, the World Cup also put a spotlight on a larger point:

By CASSIDY SWANSONNew Hampshire Correspondent. — As the first small, commercial lending bank to open in the United States in six years, Primary Bank, set to open on July 28, is attracting national media attention.Kayla Tausche, co-anchor of CNBC’s “Squawk Alley,” was at Primary Bank, located in the Route 101 Plaza, on Thursday morning to talk with chairman Bill Greiner about his newest business venture.“It’s not every day you see someone get the gumption and drum up the support within the community to actually build an institution,” Tausche said. “It’s very unique.”Greiner and his partner, Primary Bank’s President and Chief Executive Officer Bill Stone, are preparing to open the bank after exceeding their startup capital goal of $25 million by an additional $2 million.“It’s a big deal because since ’09, you’ve had 1,300 banks that have been bought out or merged,” Greiner said, adding that most closures and mergers are a result of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010. “If that continues unabated, you’re going to be left with just big banks, and that’s not good.”Greiner, who is a stakeholder in the Great New Hampshire Restaurants group and a real estate developer, decided to get into the banking business after Citizens Bank, whom he worked with previously, announced they would not be providing loans in markets where the value of commercial real estate loans is under $20 million.“That’s pretty much taking you out of New Hampshire. There’s maybe 10 of those a year in our state,” Greiner said. “As that continues to happen, nobody comes in and backfills that. Who’s going to service the $2.5 million guys like me?”Greiner says he hopes Primary Bank will fill that void left by larger banks.“A $300,000 loan or line of credit means nothing to a $10 billion bank. It means everything to a small, community bank,” he said. “And there’s more relationships that go with a small loan like that, so I think that’s the real opportunity.”Tausche said the opening of Primary Bank is “a sign of confidence in the economy.”“The fact that there is demand in a community like this, for people to be taking out new loans, means that there’s a lot of confidence about small business in any given economy,” Tausche said. “We frankly hadn’t seen that for several years.With low interest rates in place for so long, the prospect of creating a profitable bank has seemed less promising, Tausche said.“I think there were not a lot of people who were willing to take that leap, because they weren’t sure that there community would borrow from the bank, and they wouldn’t be able to make money from it,” she said. “The fact that now that’s happening is a big deal.”Primary Bank will be open for business on July 28 with a grand opening scheduled for July 31. For more information, visit primarybanknh.com. cswanson@newstote.com

Other recipients of the 2015 award include the executive director of Empower U community health center, Vanessa Mills, Gregorio Millett, the Vice-President and Director of public policy for AMFAR and Janssen Therapeutics. Jussie even spilled the tea about when we can expect his album to drop and what we can expect to hear from season two of Empire. “It’s going to be fun. For ‘Empire’ season two, I’ve been recording with everybody from obviously Timbaland to Jim Beanz and also Swizz Beatz and Ne-Yo so it’s going to be dope. It’s going to be excellent!” In case you lost count, ‘Empire’ is 77 days away. Yes, we are counting down. Way to go, Jussie!
LabBody: According to Hello Beautiful: 'Empire' star Jussie Smollett Honored By The Black AIDS Institute [VIDEO] 2015 has been a breakout year for Empire star Jussie Smollett. Recently Jussie was honored by the Black AIDS Institute during the annual Heroes In The Struggle (H.I.T.S) gala. H.I.T.S pays tribute to Black Americans and the Allies who have contributed in the fight against HIV/AIDS. Previous inductees of the gala include Maxine Waters, Magic Johnson and President Bill Clinton. According to Euroweb, Smollett was overjoyed when he heard the news about the honor. “I got the call from Phil Wilson (President and CEO, Black AIDS Institute) who’s been one of my mentors since I was sixteen. He asked if I would be honored by the organization and I said of course. I love what the Black AIDS Institute has done and all of the lives that they’ve changed. I love Phil and to be honored by him is everything.”

We understand, it’s hard to look at Eagle Square the same. After dancing your heart out there for three days straight during Market Days, the eerie silence of the Concord downtown spot is not something anybody enjoys. It’s like a little piece of us is gone. But never fear, faithful readers, ’cause at 7 p.m. on this fine Thursday evening, the rhythmic sounds of Delanie Pickering will once again take over the Eagle Square grounds, as part of the Concord Parks and Recreation Department’s summer music series. And in order to see this blues guitarist/singer/songwriter it will cost you nothing but some applause, maybe a little toe tapping and a couple encouraging hoots along the way. ∎ ∎ ∎ Also at 7 p.m., Carol Lee Adams will be at Gibson’s Bookstore, as part of its independent author series, to share from her book, Deaf Daughter: From Deafness and Despair to Hearing and Hope. For more info, visit gibsonsbookstore.com. (Email the Insiders at theinsiders@cmonitor.com.)

by Erika Carter 7/10/15. Have you ever wondered how they make those beautiful tomato flowers? You know the ones, you see them on the buffet tables all the time? They’re beautiful, almost like a work of art. Well, to accomplish this you just need a few simple things: A sharp paring knife, cutting board or other flat surface and a medium sized tomato. The key to successfully learning how to make a tomato rose is by using the right tool. A sharp paring knife is essential, as it allows you to control the depth and direction of your cuts. A dull blade will make it virtually impossible to create a pretty tomato flower. You make your cuts diagonally. You cut into the tomato, about 2.5 inches down, all around in a “V” pattern. When that is done, you pull the pieces apart and there’s a beautiful rose. You can enhance this by cutting down a little further. It almost looks like a rose sitting on a lily pad. Even further, you can cut the skin and it enhances the beauty of the flower. Generally, I would buy vine ripened tomatoes because they seem to be a prettier shade of red and of a good size. But wouldn’t this be beautiful to have a sea of tomato flowers made out of heirloom tomatoes, in many sizes and colors. And, of course, they would be delicious. If it is true that we eat with our eyes first, then this would be a virtual feast. SHARE the love and pass it on! Did You Like This Story? Tap Below.

DiffbotBody: The superintendent got a vote of confidence. He deserves the Medal of Honor IN A VOTE of confidence, the School Reform Commission last week said it owed Superintendent William Hite what it called a "performance bonus." It should have been called combat pay. That's the extra pay given to members of the U.S. military who serve in "designated combat zones or hazardous duty areas." That pretty much describes the Philadelphia School District, certainly in 2012 when Hite took over after the SRC fired Superintendent Arlene Ackerman. They were perilous times, certainly for the students in the District. The state has slashed about $500 million in aid, creating a huge hole in the district's budget. A round of layoffs - that would continue for several years - was just beginning. Ackerman, whose imperious style earned her the nickname "Queen Arlene," had a knack for making enemies, so the District had few friends in the outside world, especially among the politicians who controlled the purse strings. Hite was the calm after the Ackerman storm. A Virginian with a courtly manner, Hite began his career as a classroom teacher, rising through the ranks to become superintendent of public schools in Prince George's County, in Maryland. It was a large district, though nothing could fully prepare him for the challenge of running an urban school district in the battlefield called Philadelphia. What he was able to draw upon are character traits that make him a good leader. He has offered a consistency of vision, a pro-child and pro-parent agenda, a genuine belief that every child can learn and a determination about making real change in how schools operate in this city. What Hite also brought to the table was a personality that won over critics. He never raises his voice. He never points his finger to blame. He exhibits patience and forbearance - even in the face of screaming protesters or angry lawmakers. Instead, he has countered with a call for "shared sacrifices" by all parties involved in education in the city to pull the District out of the hole it fell into before he arrived. We can't say he has succeeded, but that failure is due to forces outside of his control. With the notable exception of Mayor Nutter, he has not gotten much from the political class. He's still at loggerheads with the teachers union over concessions he's sought. Financially, the district is no longer under siege but it's still a combat zone. Services are at a minimal level. Resources are scant. This week, Hite moved ahead with changes he had been planning centered on decentralizing power in the district, reasoning that if he waited for needed money to arrive he could be waiting forever. That is called optimism. He has restored the reputation to a system that was so lacking when he arrived. That is called credibility. He has consistently shown grace under pressure, which is one definition of courage. Hite makes a good salary. But, it's no surprise, given his performance, that the SRC wanted to give him a $60,000 bonus. And it's no surprise that Hite turned it down, saying it would be unfair given the district's finances. We call that leadership.

LOVES PARK — A 54-year-old man who has been a substance abuse counselor at Rosecrance Health Network was charged Tuesday with solicitation of a sexual act, and the 29-year-old Machesney Park woman he was with was arrested on prostitution and drug charges. A Loves Park Police officer saw about 4:30 p.m. an item suspected of being used to ingest crack cocaine lying on the front passenger seat of a vehicle in which the two people arrived at the Clayton House Motel, 4800 N. Second St. Police charged Glen R. Hamilton with solicitation and Tara L. Martoglio with prostitution, and possession of cocaine and drug paraphernalia. She also was charged with obstructing identification because she gave police a false name. And because she was wanted for felony theft in McHenry County, she was arrested on the theft charge. Hamilton has been placed on administrative leave, said Judy Emerson, director of communications for Rosecrance. Georgette Braun: 815-987-1331; gbraun@rrstar.com; @GeorgetteBraun.

U.S. Sen. Steve Daines announced that he has signed on as a co-sponsor to a bill permanently reauthorizing the Land and Water Conservation Fund. ‘When you think what it is about America that sets us apart from every other country in the world, it is our public lands,’ Daines said.

TWIN FALLS • Anyone with a burning question for the Twin Falls Police Department can ask away Saturday. Twin Falls Police Department has decided to take part in the national program Coffee With A Cop. “We are trying to engage people outside of situations we usually encounter them in,” Capt. Matthew Hicks said. “As you can imagine we don’t always find people at their calmest.” Coffee With A Cop was founded in Hawthorn, Calif. by Capt. Keith Kauffman and Sgt. Chris Cognac of the Hawthorn Police Department in 2011. Since its inception, these events have been picked up across the country and in Australia and England. Anyone with a question or concern is invited to come have a one-on-one conversation with an officer from 9 a.m. to 11 a.m. Saturday at Twin Beans Coffee Company, 144 Main Ave. “I think it is important in this day and age for people to see officers in this light,” Hicks said. The police department hosts weekly presentations across town but officers wanted a forum that could provide more give and take. “Those tend to be more like speeches, which is great for relaying information but we wanted something more,” Hicks said. The Coffee With A Cop program has a four-hour training that police departments can attend to learn how to better engage the community. Twin Falls officers haven’t attended the training yet but plans to send some in the future. “The reality is this is four hours of the nuts and bolts of all the mistakes we’ve ever made hosting these events,” Kauffman said in a press release. Twin Falls plans to host similar events every two months at different coffee shops around town. “The agenda is decided by the people who come to the coffee shop that day and we talk about what they want to talk about,” Hicks said.

To the editor: The recent road bond election defeat, a patchwork of good and bad projects almost resulting in a huge, blatant waste of our tax dollars is but the latest example of county leaders hooked on spending. However, this is not just limited to the county leaders, as the local county school boards and township are just as guilty from free willing with our hard-earned dollars. And who really benefits from this irresponsible spending of our local treasury and indebtedness? Follow the money. In the road bond case, the “movers & shakers” of the county, along with the “outsiders” (wallets — engineering and consulting companies from Houston who support and get business from them), spent $1.04 million to elect the remainder (two) of a commissioners court that would tip the balance of power on the court in their direction, as well as for this latest road bond election. After a runoff last year for those two (Judge Doyal & Commissioner Riley), plus an insurance win in Jim Clark, they went to work immediately crafting a bond that would eventually give the appearance of favoritism and payback to the aforementioned supporters. People got wise to it and it didn’t work. In fact, it was defeated in a landslide. The people of The Woodlands, as well as 6,000 (38 percent of the voters against the bond) from outside of that community, awoke to give a resounding no. The defeat was so stinging that the judge lost the county vote and Commissioner Riley lost his own precinct (2). With all commissioners and the “who’s who” in the county supporting this patchwork bond, full of pork, it took all of the grassroots’ time and energy to make sure that the word got out about the 60 percent waste in it. What we didn’t have time to pursue, unfortunately, was the litmus test of mega-loans to come throughout the county … particularly the two in this same election cycle: the Montgomery and New Caney ISD bonds. While campaigning in the city of Montgomery against the road bond in early voting, I also had an occasion to talk to 3 of the 4 pro-($257 million) bond candidates running for the MISD school board, as well as the head of the PTO up there. The common theme was “the classrooms are overflowing and you can barely get to classes because the hallways are jammed.” Really. That bad? In the evening between the two days I was out there, I did some quick research. The first red flag that I found, while digging for the true indicator of a bond improvement (capacities — now/future) was that $55 million was going to be spent on operations and maintenance. But shouldn’t this be coming out of the exorbitant amount (nearly half of all of our property taxes go to) that we already pay? Sounds eerily like M&O the in road bonds, too. In fact, projected elementary and middle schools, called for in the MISD bond, barely exceed capacity, if at all in the middle schools’ case — but not for another 10 years. A better case was made for the high school, if you believe the growth rates in the study. Consequently, at least half of the $205 million for the schools (or just over $100 million) could’ve waited five years at the earliest to gauge actual needs then. Seems to be a parallel to the pork in the road bond. If there’s anything the patchwork road and MISD bonds taught us, it is to look under the hood. That applies to both the upcoming CISD and Magnolia ISD bonds, especially when one considers that CISD is already $1 billion in debt and the state has up to a staggering $112 billion in school bond debt. And finally, while on the subject of misallocation of our tax dollars, is the “mounted patrol” in The Woodlands. With the $1.8 million contract for Alpha Omega “greeting/direction” services expiring Dec. 31, headed up by local VP Kathy Scoles (BTW wife of former Oak Ridge Mayor Gary Louie, who was shamelessly shilling for renewal of AO’s contract in the article), the township is going out with an RFP for bidders. Why is an abundance of our tax dollars going to a unique organization like this, that admittedly has no law enforcement capabilities and is mainly found geographically around the Town Center? Shouldn’t the businesses around there, who receive most of the benefit to this, be picking up the tab for the extra “security?” Or maybe even The Woodlands Convention and Visitors Bureau? And how does a business like Costco, miles away, qualify as the article suggested? Not many of our citizens object to leaders spending our tax dollars, if done wisely. However, it’s time that those same old/new leaders sober up from their years of binge-spending. As well, voters should continue looking under the hood of these “needed” projects. Trust ... but verify. John Wertz. Montgomery County Tea Party.

6/28/2015 5:52 PM PDT BY TMZ STAFF let her hair down during NYC's Pride event Sunday at the Dream Hotel ... moments after the annual Gay Pride Parade wrapped. Caitlyn arrived with a few friends and cameras in tow, apparently for her reality show, "I Am Cait." She arrived in time for transgender actress Candis Cayne's performance. They danced, and then Candis toasted Caitlyn ... telling the audience she was honored to know Caitlyn. She then dedicated the song, "Im Every Woman" -- to Cait, who cheered her on. Wave that rainbow flag, girl!

BELLEVILLE — A St. Clair County judge has ordered the Illinois comptroller to fully pay state workers despite the budget standoff between Democrats in the legislature and Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner. Circuit Judge Robert LeChien sided Thursday with 13 public employee unions that sued Comptroller Leslie Munger. Attorney General Lisa Madigan's office argued that lawmakers and Rauner must first approve a spending plan for the fiscal year that began July 1. Madigan's office plans to appeal. The ruling counters a Cook County judge's decision that Munger may pay only some workers covered under federal minimum wage laws. Munger and the unions are appealing that decision. Munger said Thursday's ruling gives her authorization to process payroll, though she adds there'll be "additional legal action." Madigan's office said both rulings make it clear a court battle will be ongoing.

ELKHART — Downtown Elkhart Inc. brings Summer Saturdays back July 11 with several activities throughout the city. An instructor from the Tree of Life Yoga Center will lead yoga classes at 9:15 a.m. at the Wellfield Botanic Gardens at 1011 N. Main St. It’s part of the weekly Yoga in the Gardens classes, which continue through September. The classes are open to people who are just getting started with yoga and those who are experienced with the practice. The activity costs $7 to $10, depending on whether you have a membership. There’s also going to be the Coffee on the Piazza event from 9:30 a.m. to noon at the Ruthmere Museum, where you can listen to live music by Ivory West and The Matchsellers. The event is free. Composer and pianist Dan Tepfer will also hold a recital and reception at 7 p.m. at the Ruthmere Museum. The event costs $50 per person. You can watch the animated movie “Tangled” on an outdoor screen at 7 p.m. in Central Park. Children can also play around the splash pad from 2 to 6 p.m. at the NIBCO Water Park. INOVA Federal Credit Union will give out more than $1,500 in gift certificates to those who share the best photographs taken in downtown Elkhart on social media. All you have to do is share the photographs with the hashtag #Elkhart.
Jennifer Graylock/Getty Images for Kohl's Department Stores.

DiffbotBody: This year we're marking the hundred-day countdown to Best of Phoenix 2015 by sharing some of our favorite dishes at restaurants all over the Valley. Have a suggestion for a dish you'd like us to try? Leave it in the comments section or email lauren.saria@newtimes.com. 58. The Straw at Miracle Mile Deli When it comes to New York-style deli fare in the middle of the dessert, Miracle Mile Deli is about as good as you can do. For generations, this has been a family-run operation serving brisket of beef, corned beef, and matzoh ball soup. This year, the restaurant moved to a new freestanding location on 16th Street — and it serves beer and wine. It's truly a new age for this Valley landmark restaurant. You will experience a food coma if you eat this sandwich, so consider yourself warned. Which isn't to say you should let the prospect of sleeping away the afternoon deter you from ordering the Straw. This sandwich is piled high with pastrami, melted Swiss cheese, and sauerkraut, not a particularly original combination, but satisfying nonetheless. You'll get your choice of breads, and the best option is to get your sandwich served on a hearty onion roll that will actually soak up all the juices from the meat and kraut. For a side, you'll get a kosher dill pickle, of course, and you'll have a choice to stick with the customary offering (French fries) or upgrade to something else. DiffbotBody: San Francisco Sheriff Ross Mirkarimi has deflected blame in the release of a Mexican national now facing murder charges in the Pier 14 slaying by demanding to know why federal authorities returned him to San Francisco to face a 20-year-old marijuana charge in the first place. The answer, it turns out, is that the Sheriff’s Department asked federal officials to do so. Mirkarimi’s agency requested custody of Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez as he was completing a 46-month stint in federal prison in March in San Bernardino County, according to a Sheriff’s Department letter obtained by The Chronicle. Lopez-Sanchez had been deported five times to Mexico and had been imprisoned for illegally re-entering the U.S. The federal Bureau of Prisons alerted the Sheriff’s Department in March that Lopez-Sanchez was going to be released. Mirkarimi’s agency, realizing that Lopez-Sanchez was wanted on a $5,000 bench warrant related to a 1995 marijuana possession-for-sale case, asked prison officials March 23 to hold him and to notify San Francisco authorities “when the subject is ready for our pick-up.” “Also, please notify us if the hold cannot be placed or the named subject is released to another jurisdiction prior to our receipt,” said the letter, signed by Vic Gaerlan of the sheriff’s warrant bureau. Lopez-Sanchez arrived in San Francisco on March 26, and the marijuana case against him was discharged the following day. He was returned to jail, however. Prisoner in legal limbo For the next three weeks, sources with knowledge of the matter told The Chronicle, sheriff’s deputies sought clarification from the department’s legal division on whether to hold Lopez-Sanchez so Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials could pick him up for possible deportation. ICE had requested that the city detain Lopez-Sanchez. In the end, the legal division told deputies they had no basis to hold Lopez-Sanchez, and he was released April 15. He was arrested last week in the July 1 shooting death of 32-year-old Kathryn Steinle on San Francisco’s waterfront, and has pleaded not guilty to murder charges. Mirkarimi’s office did not immediately comment on the letter. It initially scheduled a news conference for Thursday to “set the record straight” on Lopez-Sanchez’s release but called it off late Wednesday “out of respect for Kate Steinle’s funeral services.” In an interview Tuesday on KQED radio, the sheriff questioned why Lopez-Sanchez had been sent to the city. “We’re trying to understand why ICE returned Sanchez to San Francisco on a 20-year-old marijuana possession charge in a city that really doesn’t even prosecute marijuana possession … and knowing that he had been deported and illegally entered the country,” the sheriff said. Freya Horne, legal counsel for the Sheriff’s Department, told The Chronicle on Tuesday that her office had dispatched a private transportation outfit to pick up Lopez-Sanchez. “It seems kind of amazing that after all that time, he was brought back here for that purpose,” Horne said. Joseph Russoniello, former U.S. attorney in San Francisco, said the city’s request to take custody of such an offender was “very unusual.” He said sheriff’s officials could have checked with local prosecutors about the case and opted not to intervene. “They had the capability to examine the status of the file and determine whether or not to pursue the matter or move to cancel or withdraw the warrant,” he said. The Sheriff’s Department letter came to light on the same day that San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee attacked Mirkarimi, saying his decision to cut off even basic communication with federal immigration officials led to Lopez-Sanchez’s release. Mirkarimi has said a 2013 city law designed to protect people without immigration status — a law signed by Lee — mandated the April release after the local charges against him were dropped. But the mayor said the sheriff’s office could have satisfied both city and state law by simply picking up the phone and asking immigration agents to come over and pick up Lopez-Sanchez before the “serious, repeat” felon was set loose. “I’ve sent that message over to the Sheriff’s Department regarding communications with the federal authorities,” Lee said at a news conference. “Do we need to educate somebody on how to pick up the phone?” Lee said Mirkarimi “needs to read the entire ordinance” the mayor signed in 2013. The law prohibits most inmates suspected of being in the country illegally from being held for ICE after their scheduled jail release. The 48-hour holds are known as detainers. No law against discussion Lee said that rather than detaining an inmate post-release, it would be prudent and legal to turn him over earlier. “Nothing in this sanctuary-city law prohibits the officials of the city and county of San Francisco to communicate, to engage in discussion” with immigration officials before a person’s scheduled release, Lee said. The sheriff has said that his department cannot detain someone suspected to be in the country illegally without a warrant or a court order. And records show Mirkarimi cut off nearly all communications with ICE in spring 2014. In a brief response Wednesday to Lee, Mirkarimi told The Chronicle in a text message, “It really looks like the Mayor is running away from the 2013 law he signed into effect ... A law that I and our department adhere to. If he has had a change of legislative heart then he should’ve communicated this to me but then again I haven’t heard from him in three years despite my numerous letters and attempts to meet with him. I think it’s cowardly that he's placing politics before public safety.” Lee and Mirkarimi have butted heads since the mayor tried to oust the sheriff for his highly publicized domestic-violence-related conviction in 2012. Lee’s comments put him in step with federal immigration officials who have insisted that, had they merely been notified about the planned release of Lopez-Sanchez, they would have picked him up and taken him into custody for deportation. They said they had made clear to local authorities in California — including those who have refused to honor post-release detainers in recent years due to civil rights concerns — that they were looking to get such prerelease notifications. But Mirkarimi has limited his department’s cooperation with immigration agents in ways that go beyond the 2013 city ordinance signed by Lee. In May 2014, he announced in a news release that his department “will no longer honor U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement detainers unless they are supported by judicial determination of probable cause” or an arrest warrant. A year later, Mirkarimi essentially cut off the type of communication that federal immigration officials are now seeking. Communication cut off He issued a memo March 13 stating that his staff was barred from giving immigration agents “information or access” to records about detainees — including their citizenship status, their booking and arrest documents, and their release dates. Before that, some deputies had informally called ICE about inmates who might be deportable. But deputies told The Chronicle that the new policy led to a complete stoppage of communication. Virginia Kice, an ICE spokeswoman, said courtesy notifications from San Francisco deputies dropped off dramatically in spring 2014. “By April 2014, it was standard practice for no cooperation and no phone calls,” Kice said. “We were not getting much stuff, over the transom or under the transom, at all. What stuff we were getting was few and far between at the very best.” The mayor said he cannot “order” city officials to communicate with federal officials about inmates who may be in the country illegally. But he said he has sent a strong message to members of the Board of Supervisors and other city officials that there should be cooperation — and direct communication — in serious cases. Jaxon Van Derbeken , Car la Marinucci and Evan Sernoffsky are San Francisco Chronicle staff writer s . E-mail: j vanderbeken @sfchronicle.com , c marinucci @sfchronicle.com and esernoffsky@sfchronicle.com

delivers news, analysis and commentary on the investment banking, securities and fund management industries. It provides breaking and exclusive news and context to fill the void between the nationals and narrowly focused specialist trade press. Financial News, while covering the spectrum of the wholesale financial markets, spans the interconnected fields of Asset Management, Investment Banking, Private Equity, and Trading and Technology. Readers can quickly access the day’s news, breaking analysis of the events, a considered view of trends, expert commentary and analysis or aggregation of world class press sources on the website. They will find top breaking news across the four core sectors and be able to browse new content types, including topics pages, features and supplements, blogs, lifestyle coverage and a twelve year archive and data. In addition, Financial News has long hosted a stable of awards, recognizing excellence in financial services, including Asset Management, Trading & Technology, Investment Banking, FN 100 Women, Pension Funds, Hedge Funds, and more. These annual events bring together some of the most recognized names in the industry, as well as rising stars, for excellence in their strategy and performance.

DiffbotBody: Jared Fogle Jared Fogle Fogle's legal team tells us there's a very good reason we didn't see the feds marching the ex-Subway spokesman out of his Indiana home this week. They say they're confident the FBI raid turned up nothing that incriminates Fogle. It's unclear where the investigation stands -- we reached out to the U.S. attorney’s office, and they were extremely tight-lipped ... not even acknowledging there's a probe. Fact is, Jared isn't in custody ... but the damage has been done -- Subway quickly suspended its relationship with him, and charities have run for the hills.

We believe in Jennifer Lawrence! After spending the day giving Hunger Games fans the latest scoop about the fan-favorite franchise, Jennifer Lawrence and her Mockingjay - Part 2 co-stars hit up Conan O'Brien's show. And because she's a queen who can't resist putting on a good show, Jennifer Lawrence ended up singing Cher's "Believe." After Conan gave the Oscar-winner some light ribbing about the surprisingly popular remixed version of Mockingjay - Part 1's "Hanging Tree," Josh Hutcherson and Liam Hemsworth cajoled Lawrence into belting out Cher's iconic hit. Hutcherson even joined in with some diva moves of his own. Check out the video below! JLaw also dropped f-bombs left and right during the appearance, and thanks to Conan's special swear jar ended up raising $10,000 for charity. Swearing is caring! DiffbotBody: The long, lazy days of summer are perfect for going outside to play. From now through Labor Day, it’s your seasonal chance to soak up some culture at Shakespeare by the Sea, hear a symphony at an amphitheater nestled in a canyon or beat the heat by watching "Frozen" on a big screen at the park. Summer is the time to bust out of the cineplex for a special screening at a uniquely L.A. venue. Catch a Western on an Old West movie set, see a summer classic atop a downtown parking structure, or a Hollywood classic in cemetery for movie stars. Enjoy music of all genres at the region's iconic outdoor venues. From now through Labor Day weekend, concerts and festivals featuring superstars and emerging local talent will be served up alfresco-style throughout Southern California. To be or not to be … if the question this summer is about enjoying classic theater performed outdoors, the answer is obvious. Here’s a guide to where stage companies will be doing Shakespeare and other works in the weeks ahead. From beach volleyball to carnival rides to majestic sailing ships and giant waves of bubbles, there are a bevy of festivals and fairs happening this summer under the sun in Southern California. Dining alfresco takes on a whole new meaning at the region’s summer food festivals. Sample the best of the season at more than 20 events. This summer, experience art in exciting ways, with colorful chalk used to draw temporary sidewalk masterpieces, classic works re-created in still life and beautiful selections of all sorts on display and for sale. More Things To Do

LabBody: WASHINGTON — The gunman charged in the Charleston, South Carolina, church massacre should not been allowed to purchase the weapon used in the attack, FBI Director James Comey said Friday as he outlined a series of missed opportunities and incomplete paperwork that allowed the transaction to take place. The problem stemmed from an arrest of Dylann Roof in South Carolina weeks before the shooting in which police say he admitted to possessing illegal drugs. Under federal rules, that admission alone should have been enough to disqualify him from an April gun purchase. But, Comey said, the FBI background check examiner who evaluated Roof's request to buy a gun never saw the arrest report because the wrong arresting agency was listed on the list rap sheet that she reviewed. The transaction went through after three days because the examiner didn't have enough information to authorize or deny it. "If she had seen that police report," Comey said, "that purchase would have been denied." Comey said he learned about the problem on Thursday night and that FBI officials planned to meet Friday with relatives of the nine victims of last month's church shooting in Charleston. He said he had also directed an internal 30-day review into how the FBI uses criminal background checks in gun transactions. His announcement came within hours of the Confederate flag's removal from the South Carolina Statehouse. Families of the victims attended the ceremony.

SOUTH BEND — Organizers of Bike the Bend, the popular bicycle ride through South Bend and Mishawaka that drew almost 2,000 participants last month, have canceled next year's ride after a rift with city police. Organizers pinned the decision on the dearth of help from South Bend police officers, claiming the local lodge of the Fraternal Order of Police told its officers to avoid helping the event in retaliation to criticism of the officers' assistance last year. Only two South Bend officers ended up working the event last month. In a news conference Thursday at downtown's Seitz Park, organizers — led by founder Yatish Joshi and Glenda Lamont, president of Bike the Bend — said relations with city police are too damaged. Lamont said organizers couldn't "take a chance" that even one injury might happen, especially when 25 percent of the riders are children. They provided a copy of an email in May that South Bend Lt. Gene Eyster, who oversees traffic enforcement, had sent to a Bike the Bend liaison: "You are correct that the Fraternal Order of Police has recommended to its membership to consider not volunteering to work the Bike the Bend event. This request was made based on the disparaging remarks about the professionalism and job performance made by your organization to the City after last year’s event.” But the FOP's president, Sgt. Dan Demler, responded in a statement that few officers chose to help this year because they were swamped since the event came on the tails of the city's big 150th birthday bash. "It’s a matter of choosing personal time over an extra shift," he said. The ride called for almost 50 officers, or about 20 percent of the police force. To alleviate that, Demler said, police had suggested pushing the event to May or the fall. "Bike the Bend organizers showed little willingness to consider the concerns expressed or changes suggested by officers, who have extensive experience serving in a wide variety of events," he said in the statement. All of this comes after an event in June that, by most accounts, went smoothly in its sixth year and didn't see any major injuries, thanks to a surge of volunteers — 125 in all — who stepped up after Bike the Bend put out a last-minute plea for help with guiding cyclists at 26 key intersections in South Bend. The event asked police to block off traffic, which is an unusual request for bike rides. According to Bike the Bend organizers, problems first arose after the 2014 event, as riders and volunteers complained about "serious and careless disregard (by officers) for the safety of riders at seven South Bend intersections." They said the complaints were limited to only a few South Bend officers and didn't apply to officers from neighboring departments. The issues at the seven intersections led organizers to subtract $2,523 from a bill of $10,890 that they reimbursed to the city for South Bend officers' help last year. Bike the Bend has always paid the city for the officers, who earned time-and-a-half wages or compensatory time. In his statement, Demler said that wasn't fair: "Even if one is unhappy with the level of service, when an agreement is made and an employee shows up and performs his or her duties, one cannot decide to withhold compensation. In the planning stages, police officers serve as partners with organizers, not their employees, offering our expertise in promoting public safety to help make an event a success." 'Never say never' Even this year's event was in jeopardy, according to Joshi and Lamont. They said they were ready to cancel after receiving the complaints from the 2014 ride. They alerted South Bend Police Chief Ron Teachman and then-Deputy Mayor Mark Neal in a June 2014 letter, pointing out the riders' complaints about some lax police coverage and a "lack of diligence" by the city parks department to ease safety hazards on the East Bank Trail. They said there had been "inconsistent public safety services in the past" and wrote that the ride wouldn't go on "unless there's a transformation in the City's attitude." They decided to move forward after some police and city officials gave their approval for the 2015 route. It wasn't until May, organizers say, that they heard a rumor that the FOP was discouraging its members from helping. In a news conference at the time, Chief Teachman speculated that officers were merely fatigued from the sharp increase of special events that required police presence this year. Those events had increased from 73 in 2012 to a projected 305 this year, he said. "What's been happening is over the past few years, special events have exploded," he said at that time. "Not all of them can we staff with police officers. It takes a toll on our most valuable asset: Our people and their families." As it turned out on June 14, the ride received help from neighboring police departments: five from St. Joseph County Police, three from the University of Notre Dame, five from the Mishawaka Police Department and six members of South Bend's Volunteers in Policing unit, organizers report. Joshi faults not only the officers but also the city's administration for not forcing South Bend police to cooperate. Mayor Pete Buttigieg's spokeswoman, Kara Kelly, said the city worked closely with Bike the Bend organizers "to try to arrive at a realistic public safety plan, and played an active role to help ensure the 2015 event went forward." Ultimately, though, special events "are a voluntary public safety assignment for officers, and this policy is not unique to Bike the Bend," she said. Kelly also backed Teachman's account, saying, "There’s no question that the rise in special events has played a role in the availability of public safety officers and can put a strain on the system." Would organizers resurrect the ride if the issues can be rectified? "Never say never," Joshi replied. "For this one, we have no plans to come back." Demler, of the police union, said, "We remain open to working with Bike the Bend organizers in the future." Regardless of the annual spring ride, Bike the Bend, as a nonprofit organization, will go on, Lamont said. More than $58,000 has been given back to the community since it began, most recently to help develop the Indiana Michigan River Valley Trail and the LaSalle Trail.

Flag's most dangerous intersections. Intersection. Collisions. S Milton Rd/W Route 66. 39. E Route 66/N Fanning Dr. 27. E Ponderosa Pkwy/E Route 66. 24 N Country Club Dr/N Highway 89. 22 S Milton Rd/W Riordan Rd. 21. S Malpais Ln/S Milton Rd 20 E Ponderosa Pkwy/E Butler Ave 20 N Fourth St/E Route 66 19. E Butler Ave/E Lucky Ln 18 N Switzer Canyon Dr/E Route 66. 17. -- Source: FPD Dangerous Intersections Report 2014. The three-way junction at South Milton Road and West Route 66 was the most dangerous intersection in Flagstaff in 2014. According to CompStat reports compiled by the Flagstaff Police Department, there were 39 collisions at the South Milton Road and West Route 66 intersection last year. “I don’t think it’s news to folks that it is a dangerous intersection,” said FPD spokesperson Sgt. Margaret Bentzen. This year’s most dangerous intersection did not even make the top 10 list in 2013, when South Milton Road at West Butler Avenue had the most collisions. This year, that intersection fell to No. 11 on the dangerous intersections list with 16 collisions. Most of the top 10 dangerous intersections on this year’s list were along Flagstaff’s main drag, which winds across town from South Milton Road to East Route 66 and Highway 89. Bentzen said the large volume of daily traffic on those roads is a major factor in the number of collisions. Red light violations and following too closely are the two most common violations officers see. Citywide, there were 2,125 non-injury collisions in 2014, 74 fewer than the previous year. However, the number of injury collisions rose from 352 in 2013 to 411 in 2014. There were three fatal crashes in both years. --Michelle McManimon. Copyright 2015 Arizona Daily Sun. It’s been a bittersweet summer in the forever-changed landscape of the Keene Pumpkin Festival, as the penalty phase for those charged in connection with the rioting winds through the judicial system. Perhaps the punishments bring some satisfaction to those demanding justice after more than 100 were arrested for their alleged role s in the riots near the Keene State College campus while last October’s Pumpkin Festival was going on downtown.

As Dieter Regett drove through Jasper National Park on Friday, it was “eerily quiet,” not even a squirrel to be seen in an area usually teeming with wildlife. “It was like driving through soup. It was all smokey and it was very smelly — that burnt smell — through the entire area,” Regett said, as he watched a helicopter fly toward a wildfire burning out of control in the Maligne Valley. Around 5,000 hectares large, the fire had forced several campgrounds and trails to be evacuated of visitors. Regett, a driver with Sun Dog Tours, helped Parks Canada Friday morning shuttle staff to pick up cars abandoned at campsites by guests who had been evacuated by helicopter or quad. David Arsenault was playing cards when a helicopter landed in the alpine meadow near his tent at a backcountry campground off Skyline trail in Maligne Valley. Arsenault wasn’t surprised when he was told he’d be evacuated the next morning; he’d seen the smoke. “It was like a big white cloud coming over the ridge of the mountain and it just kind of kept billowing and billowing and getting bigger,” Arsenault said. “Then you realize it’s not a cloud.” Maligne Lake Road, Skyline trail between the valley and canyon, the canyon and hostel, and Jacques Lake trail are all closed. The park is open to visitors but under a fire ban until further notice. The wildfire is moving south, away from the town of Jasper 15 kilometres to the north, park spokeswoman Kim Weir said Friday. “There’s hopefully no risk to the community at this point,” Weir said. Due to favourable weather conditions, the fire remained roughly the same size Friday — its growth slowing considerably — but that could change if weather conditions do. The fire started around 3:30 p.m. Thursday near Excelsior Creek in the Maligne Valley and was burning northwest of Medicine Lake, a glacial-fed lake. Lightning likely struck and smouldered underground until the dryness and heat let it spark a wildfire, she said. It’s being fought using aerial attacks only because it’s too dangerous on the ground. This weekend’s predicted cooler weather and rain should help, she said. Sprinklers have been set up to soak Parks Canada buildings, but nothing was in danger of burning as of Friday night. Though the park is still open, visitors should be aware that an abundance of smoke, caused by an inversion in the valley, could exacerbate the symptoms of some health conditions, such as asthma. Park officials estimate they have evacuated 1,000 people from the Maligne Valley area over the past two days. Crews from Manitoba are expected to arrive on Saturday and Sunday. The devastation of “nature, in all its pristineness,” was obvious north of Medicine Lake, Regett said. The fire had “jumped the road, exploded some of the trees” and knocked rocks onto the road. That destruction of “one of the most beautiful places in Canada” was hard to see, he said. “It makes you feel a little insignificant ... when nature unleashes something like that.” With files from Madeleine Cummings.

With an eclectic mix of renowned performers on the schedule, organizers of the Maudslay Arts Center Summer Concert Series are looking forward to a banner 23rd season. “This is the best lineup we’ve had in years,” said Nick Costello Jr., executive director of the arts center. “It starts strong and it finishes strong, so you won’t find anything that wouldn’t be considered a great concert opportunity here.” Jazz singer Rebecca Parris will open this year’s series on Saturday night at Maudslay State Park in Newburyport with her clear vocals and soulful standards. Accompanied by her jazz trio — including Emmy-winning composer Brad Hatfield on the keyboard — Parris starts her shows with universal narratives like love and loss and moves on from there. “My first concern is the lyric and the story,” Parris said. “All the tunes that are written are universal, all of the standards that I sing, we’ve all been through by the age of 28 or 30. If you look deep into those lyrics, you’re going to find so much of your own life in there.” She’s been training for this role for practically her entire life, having been born the daughter of a church organist and a concert pianist, both of whom wore additional musical hats when necessary. She jokes that she became accustomed to liturgical music in the womb and used to chase her mother around the room singing made-up children’s hymns. But it’s her uncle who truly began her study of music: David Blair McClosky may not be a household name, but John F. Kennedy admirers will recognize him as the president’s campaign voice coach. The founder of the McClosky Institute of Voice and a former opera singer, McClosky walked a 7-year-old Parris down the first steps into opera and bucked her to follow in his footsteps. Parris grew up to study opera at The Boston Conservatory, but she also found herself drawn into the wilds of musical theater and pop. She spent well over a decade singing for various pop bands and even spent a year in hard rock — “I almost killed myself vocally” — but eventually waded into the mellow waters of jazz vocals. “I found myself with material that made sense, that had some depth,” she said, “that had wonderful chord charges and terrific melody lines, brought me back into my theater teaching. ... I could bring everything that I’ve learned over the past 30 years to put into this new music.” With decades of experience behind her, the singer often referred to as “Boston’s first lady of jazz” is planning for Saturday an eclectic affair of jazz standards, Brazilian hits and even a few “goodbye” songs that she’s been preparing in honor of a dear friend who’s leaving for her homeland in Holland. More music is on tap for Sunday afternoon, when Aeterna Trio will return after making its Maudslay Arts Center debut last year. Concerts then continue nearly every Saturday and Sunday night — with the exception of Yankee Homecoming — through Aug. 23. Proceeds from the performances will go to the arts center, founded in 1992 as a nonprofit dedicated to bringing community members, visitors and artists together in Maudslay Park. The concert series and other center activities are funded by a combination of ticket sales, sponsorships (primarily the Newburyport Five Cents Savings Bank), and rentals for weddings and other events throughout the year. “The arts don’t pay for themselves, they never do,” said Costello, whose father, Nick Costello Sr., founded the center with Jim Gaines and former Mayor Edward Molin. “But what the arts do provide is an enrichment to the community and an opportunity for the community to get together and be involved.” The venue is a renovated barn and patio set sitting on an expansive lawn bordered by a stand of Norwegian maples and, of course, the natural beauty of the 488-acre park. Patio seating for 200 puts fans right in front of the stage, just feet from the performers, and lawn seating allows for picnic blankets surrounding the stage on all sides. “It’s hard to explain how intimate it is,” Costello said. “You really can be right there with the performer, even if you’re on the lawn. You sit out there under the stars and listen to great music; there’s nothing like it.” Helping keep the arts center alive for nearly 25 years is a full community of volunteers, including Costello’s parents. Publicists, gardeners and even the carpenters who keep the building together all donate their time, as well. “It has come so far,” Costello said. “It’s been a labor of love to all those people over the years. We would not be where we are if it weren’t for the volunteers.” If you go. What: Maudslay Arts Center Summer Concert Series. When: Saturdays, July 11, 18 and 25 and Aug. 8, 15 and 22, at 7 p.m.; Sundays, July 12 and 19 and Aug. 9, 16 and 23 at 2 p.m. Gates open one hour before the concerts start. Where: Maudslay State Park, Curzon Mill Road, Newburyport. How much: Saturday performances are $25 for patio seating and $20 for lawn seating. Sunday performances are $15 general admission and $12 for seniors. Children under 12 are admitted free. To purchase, call 978-499-0050 or visit www.maudslayartscenter.org. Tickets are also available at the gate. Concert schedule. July 11: Rebecca Parris. July 12: Aeterna Trio. July 18: Hillyer Festival Orchestra. July 19: Beyond the Pale. July 25: Grace Kelly. Aug. 8: The Mystix. Aug. 9: Hal McIntyre Big Band. Aug. 15: Don Campbell Band. Aug. 16: Donna Byrne. Aug. 22: Amanda Carr. Aug. 23: Paul Broadnax & Friends.
