It sounds like wedding bells may soon be ringing for Paris Hilton. The hotel heiress and former A-Lister made her feelings for boyfriend Thomas Gross very clear on Instagram yesterday, sharing an elegant snapshot of the couple. She then captioned it with one, very telling word: Soulmates. Hilton is all decked out in a fur coat and jewels for the photo, unable to keep her eyes off of her dapper businessman. Hilton and Gross have grown very serious in a very short period of time. They only just met in May at the Cannes Film Festival. Paris, meanwhile, took the photograph in London, which is where she’s been for a few days in anticipation of sister Nicky Hilton's wedding. Nicky Hilton and her fiance, banking heir James Rothschild, are set to exchange vows at Kate Middleton and Prince William's Kensington Gardens this weekend. The only question that now remains is when Hilton will join her sister in holy matrimony.
Back to Mobile.

To the Editor: Are you kidding? Jamming up a bunch of 5-story apartments next to our beloved library. Cheesy looking, according to architects rendering appearing in today's the Hour of July 9. Looks like these guys are grabbing the small library parking lot and using the space for entry way to their proposed apartment garage. An eye-sore to me, and I'm glad (if built) I don't have to look at these units every day. By the way, have the city fathers looked into whether other than architects rendering if they have any money to go ahead? Most of these "operators" have pipe dreams thatnever pan out. Another contractor in town is having financial difficulties, too. Woody Strong. Norwalk.

The fight over Oklahoma’s current beer laws has caused Anheuser-Busch, the maker of some of the most popular beers in the country, to withdraw its membership from Beer Distributors of Oklahoma, an advocacy group for beer distributors in the state. The Beer Distributors of Oklahoma (BDO) countered by accusing Anheuser-Busch of laying off employees at the Premium Beers of Oklahoma distributorship in Oklahoma City after purchasing it from the Cresap family three years ago. In a press release issued by Anheuser-Busch, the company said “our definition of and path toward modernization does not align with the Beer Distributors of Oklahoma.” Eric James, senior director for sales and marketing for Anheuser-Busch sales of Oklahoma, did not specify the nature of the company’s dispute with the distributors group. Instead, he specified what the company would like to see happen in Oklahoma. “Anheuser-Busch would like to see cold, single-strength beer available to consumers in Oklahoma,” he said. Currently, Oklahoma law dictates beer sold outside of liquor stores must be no stronger than 3.2 percent alcohol by weight. Beer sold in liquor stores can be stronger but cannot be refrigerated. Oklahoma is only one of five states that require the sale of 3.2 beer in certain circumstances, with the others including Kansas, Colorado, Utah and Minnesota. James said changing that law would give the opportunity for brewers to sell a greater variety of beer, and give consumers more choice. “We feel that, after careful consideration, it’s in our best interest to separate from the BDO,” James said. “This gives us the freedom and flexibility to move forward on our views of modernization.” The Beer Distributors of Oklahoma responded in an emailed statement, saying Anheuser-Busch’s move came as “no surprise.” “With the recent losses of the Monster and Constellation brands, the two Anheuser-Busch owned distributorships in Oklahoma City and Tulsa have been losing market share and struggling to execute in the marketplace while at the same time trying to control costs through reductions in Oklahoma jobs,” the statement said. The BDO statement also accused Anheuser-Busch of selling beer against their own independent distributors in the same territory. The statement also said the BDO believes voters should decide what kind of modernization would come to beer distributors. “The BDO is committed to providing all Oklahomans with their choice of beer, strong or low point, through an open and independent distribution system,” the statement said. The move does not affect the availability of Anheuser-Busch products in the state. Anheuser-Busch, a subsidiary of Belgium-based Anheuser-Busch InBev since 2008, brews brands including Budweiser, Michelob, Rolling Rock, Busch, Shock Top, LandShark, Goose Island, Blue Point, 10 Barrel and Elysian. A push to loosen the beer laws is already under way. Senate Bill 383, put forward by Sen. Stephanie Bice, R-Oklahoma City, would allow single-strength, cold beer. The Oklahoma Legislature sent it to a conference committee before ending the legislative session.

DiffbotBody: Today, it starts to get really real for the more than 13,500 unionized flight attendants that work for Dallas-based Southwest Airlines (NYSE: LUV). Today the flight attendants were — for the first time — presented with the full details of the tentative contract approved last week by the 17-member executive board of Transport Workers Union Local 556, which represents Southwest flight attendants, including more than 1,800 domiciled in Chicago. News of the sudden tentative agreement has exposed deep rifts in relations between flights attendants and their elected executive board and with Southwest management, who now appear eager to get a deal with their largest single group of unionized employees. As of late today, some Southwest flight attendants are still digesting all of the contract's complicated details and getting "educated" about the tentative contract by hand-picked union representatives stationed in crew lounges at major airports throughout the Southwest network. But to some seasoned veteran rank-and-file Southwest flight attendants, the new contract appears a mix of gains and losses. But on whole, many are saying that key losses outlined in the new contract may in fact outweigh the gains the tentative contract does include. One concern expressed in emails to this reporter today from flight attendants who have now seen the full contract is the absence of retroactive pay raises for the two years that Local 556 has been negotiating to get a new contract. Flight attendants will get 3 percent raises in 2015 (starting as soon as a contract is ratified) and in 2017 and 2019, raises that are barely at — or possibly below— inflation levels in some regions, flight attendants argue. In years 2016 and 2018, flight attendants would instead get a 3 percent annual bonus, that would subsequently be taxed at 40 percent. And some flight attendants are upset about the new way vacation benefits will be calculated under terms of the proposed contract — a complicated system that will create a more defined two-tier culture of full-time and part-time employees at the airline. The new contract also calls for longer duty day hours for flight attendants in some instances, rising from 10.5 hours to 12 hours — which was not what many flight attendants were hoping to see in a new contract. But even much smaller things in the proposed contract are being viewed as losses by some flight attendants. They include a new provision that requires flight attendants to report for duty 45 minutes before the schedule departure of flights on Southwest's new — and much larger — Boeing 737-800 series aircraft that seats approximately 30 more passengers than the Boeing 737-700 series model. Previously, flight attendants were required to be at the plane 30 minutes before departure. Southwest Airlines is expected to add many more 737-800 aircraft to its fleet starting next year. One truly veteran Southwest Airlines flight attendant who has clocked well over 30 years with the carrier had this to say today after reading through the new proposed contract: "I have seen enough and compared to our previous contract language to know for certain this is a concessionary contract. Also, even though there is no defined contract language for retroactive pay, it has always been negotiated for our flight attendants going back to the date the contract expired (in 2013 in this instance). There is no retro pay, just a signing bonus (in the proposed contract). The bonus is taxed at 40 percent." Other flight attendants I heard from today point the finger directly at Southwest management, including CEO Gary Kelly, for all the angst the new proposed contract is generating among flight attendants as they prepare to vote on it. Noted one flight attendant: "The negative publicity Gary Kelly is getting in the media is exactly what he wants to sweep under the rug. He thrives on feeling everyone is behind him 100 percent. I really think he has lost contact with the real world." A spokesman for Local 556 did not return a call seeking comment today or provide a copy of the tentative contract agreed to by Local 556's executive board and Southwest Airlines management.

Ken Stabler, who led the Oakland Raiders to a Super Bowl victory and was the NFL’s Most Valuable Player in 1974, has died as a result of complications from colon cancer. He was 69. His family announced his death on Stabler’s Facebook page on Thursday. The statement said Stabler “passed peacefully” on Wednesday while surrounded by family, including his three daughters and longtime partner, who wasn’t named. Raiders owner Mark Davis said the team was “deeply saddened by the passing of the great Ken Stabler.” “He was a cherished member of the Raider family and personified what it means to be a Raider,” Davis said in a statement. “He wore the Silver and Black with Pride and Poise and will continue to live in the hearts of Raider fans everywhere. Our sincerest thoughts and prayers go out to Kenny’s family.” Stabler’s coach with the Raiders, John Madden, said his former quarterback was cool under pressure. “I’ve often said, if I had one drive to win a game to this day, and I had a quarterback to pick, I would pick Kenny,” Madden said. “Snake was a lot cooler than I was. He was a perfect quarterback and a perfect Raider. When you think about the Raiders you think about Ken Stabler. Kenny loved life. It is a sad day for all Raiders.” Stabler was a four-time Pro Bowl selection with the Raiders, leading the franchise to consistent success during the 1970s, including a 32-14 victory over the Minnesota Vikings in the 1977 Super Bowl. The family’s statement said he was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer in February. Stabler’s favorite songs were playing, from Lynyrd Skynyrd’s “Sweet Home Alabama” to Van Morrison’s “Leaves Falling Down,” the family said. His brain and spinal cord were donated to Boston University’s Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy Center to support research into degenerative brain disease among athletes, according to the family. “He was a kind, generous and unselfish man, never turning down an autograph request or an opportunity to help someone in need,” the family said. “A great quarterback, he was an even greater father to his three girls, and grandfather to his two ‘grand snakes.’” The Foley, Alabama, native threw for 27,938 career yards over 15 seasons, which also included stints with the Houston Oilers and New Orleans Saints. During his college career, Stabler led Alabama to an undefeated 1966 season and was chosen the Sugar Bowl MVP after a 34-7 rout of Nebraska. He also ran for a long touchdown on a rain-soaked field during the 1967 Iron Bowl to lead the Tide to a 7-3 win over Auburn. Alabama coach Nick Saban got to know Stabler from golf tournaments and the ex-Raiders quarterback’s stint as an analyst on Alabama radio broadcasts. “I think anyone who had the chance to get to know Kenny would appreciate the great person he was and the pride he had for the University of Alabama,” Saban said in a statement. “I have had the chance to be around some of the best to ever play college and pro football, and Kenny may have been one of the greatest competitors to ever play the game.”

DiffbotBody: View all 5 images in gallery. Throughout the summer, music fills the air in Omaha and people flock to parks and festivals to listen to live performances. Music not only creates a soundtrack for the summer, but it can also be part of your summer reading list. Find these books and more at your local branch or omahalibrary.org. Kelsey Schwenker, library aide at the Millard Library, suggests a book that features a music student whose summer job turns out to be dangerously deceptive. “City of Dark Magic” by Magnus Flyte. This novel involves the mysterious city of Prague, a music student helping to catalog Beethoven’s manuscripts and the suicide (or possible murder) of her mentor. With intrigue, romance and music. What more could you want? Aura Sewell, library specialist at the Abrahams Library, listens to music in a new way thanks to her pick. “Bug Music: How Insects Gave Us Rhythm and Noise” by David Rothenberg. You don’t need to be a bug or music expert to enjoy “Bug Music.” The author’s passion for the topic is contagious. I never realized how many sounds I have been ignoring. Mark Sorensen, library specialist at W. Dale Clark Library, recommends books that explore connections made through music. “The Hum and the Shiver” by Alex Bledsoe. Pvt. Bronwyn Hyatt returns home from Iraq to the Smoky Mountains of Tennessee wounded in body and mind. She’s lost her connection to the songs of her kinfolk and gained a spectral “haint” that warns of tragedy to come. This is a totally unique contemporary fantasy — a love song to Appalachian music and folklore, richly layered, sexy, with a touch of the supernatural dancing just under the mandolin strings. “Bel Canto” by Ann Patchett. A world-class operatic diva, a Japanese millionaire, a youthful translator and a rebel soldier are thrown together in a South American villa when a coup attempt becomes a protracted hostage crisis. Dreamlike, hilarious and heartbreaking, this novel explores the power of music to unite us across languages and battle lines. Patchett modeled the heroine on soprano Renee Fleming. Read along with an album of her singing to complete the experience. Copyright ©2015 Omaha World-Herald. All rights reserved. DiffbotBody: 01 No 1 Sofia Vergara The Modern Family star, who celebrates her second anniversary as the highest-paid actress on television, upped the ante this year with a major salary increase. In addition to the show endorsement deals with Diet Pepsi, Covergirl, Rooms to Go and thyroid medicine Synthroid make her one of the most in-demand spokespeople as marketers hope to capture her high-wattage crossover appeal. Vergara's Kmart-based line of clothing and home goods continues to thrive and is credited with increasing the retailer's market share with the Hispanic community. Vergara is also the executive producer on the forthcoming ABC show Killer Women. Total earnings: $30 million. (Forbes)
LabBody: 18. No 18 Kerry Washington. As Scandal's Olivia Pope, Washington has the distinction of being the first Afircan American actress to play a lead in a prime-time drama since the 1960s--and the Shonda Rhimes show is a certified hit for ABC, averaging 8.3 million viewers each week and earning an estimated $100 million in ad revenue this season. Oh--and Washington's been nom'd for an Emmy. The actress had a banner year: in addition to the success of Scandal she took a lead role in Quentin Tarantino's Django Unchained and starred in Tyler Perry's Peeples. Look for Washington to mount this list in 2014: in addition to a salary increase she'll begin to enjoy earnings off of a unique (and early) syndication deal: starting this fall each episode of Scandal is expected to air on BET no earlier than eight days after its original broadcast. Total earnings: $3 million (Forbes)

The King and Queen of morning television are together again! It was announced on Thursday's edition of 'Today' on NBC that Regis Philbin, who has made guest appearances in recent months on the fourth hour of the program, will be joining the show as a special contributor. The move means Philbin will now be appearing next to former co-star Kathie Lee Gifford on a regular basis. Philbin and Gifford dominated the morning airwaves on 'Live! With Regis and Kathie Lee' from 1985 to 2000 on ABC. Gifford left 'Live' to spend more time with her family in 2000, and Philbin followed suit in 2011. Gifford returned to TV in 2008, as co-host of the 'Today' show's fourth hour alongside Hoda Kotb, and now Philbin, who has made a variety of guest appearances on various shows over the last four years, once again has a permanent gig. Well, sort of. Reeg is set to make at least one special report per month. Gifford, Kotb and Philbin made the announcement today at a bar near the 'Today' set, where the ladies acted surprised to find Philbin behind the bar before the trio toasted the hiring with glasses of champagne. "We are going to let everyone in on our secret," Gifford said to Kotb. "We thought it would be the perfect person to join our motley crew, Regis Philbin," Kotb responded as the crowd cheered. "Regis brings his legendary charm and humor each time he visits 'Today,' said Tammy Filler, the co-executive producer of the show in a statement. "His energy is infectious, and when Regis is around, you never know what will happen." The new job will give the 83-year-old Philbin an opportunity to add to his famous tally. He owns the Guinness world record for most hours in front of a television camera. That said, it should be noted that this move is not just about reuniting two old friends. It's likely that NBC will tap Philbin to step in from time to time for Kotb, who has been spending more time filling in for other anchors during the show's earlier hours. The move adds some stability to a program that has seen some drama with other anchors over the last few years.

DiffbotBody: Share this video Like our page A piece of artwork that asks you not to look at it seems like a strange request, but when being explicitly told "No Eye Contact Allowed," what's the first thing you'd want to do? You would have to look directly into its eyes right? Norwegian artist Erik Pirolt testing this theory at his exhibition in Kristiansand, Norway. His sculpture, "No Eye Contact Allowed," looked simple; a human bust beneath a plexiglass pedestal casing. But if you break the rules and make eye contact with the sculpture, it knows of your disobedience and shoots harmless squirts at your face. The liquid is caught on the glass casing, but when you aren't expecting it, you could swear the head is shooting lasers at you. Do you think you could resist staring directly into this statue's eyes?

EAST BREMERTON — The life of the old East High School gymnasium just got extended by a few more decades. The Legislature allocated $1 million in its capital budget to give the 1950s-era gym off Wheaton Way a new roof. Patches, or "membranes," had been installed to keep the roof from leaking and damaging the hardwood inside, where generations of Bremerton teens from both the high school and later Bremerton Junior High School played. The announcement comes as the property, owned by the school district, is at a crossroads. A group dedicated to childhood health had hoped to develop a youth wellness campus there, and had embarked on an ambitious $18 million fundraising campaign to build out a seven-acre site. But the organization disbanded recently after funds could not be raised to demolish a dilapidated 125,000 square-foot portion of the former school. Still, former wellness campus executive director Patricia Hennessy said the money shows the wellness campus' work was worthwhile. "We're keeping an iconic structure in the community alive for generations to come," said Hennessy, who noted the campus had already put about $250,000 in new lighting and other improvements into the gym complex. Aaron Leavell, Bremerton School District superintendent, said he was thankful to the Legislature and to Hennessy for continuing to work to get the funds despite the wellness campus' disbanding. "I think it can revive some life back into that campus for future planning," he said. "It may even spark future interest for possible development." The Bremerton Teen Center, including a Boys and Girls Club and low-cost dental clinic, continue to operate at the site. "Having access to the gym enhances our programs and provides greater opportunity for teens to participate in sports and fitness programming at the Bremerton Teen Center," said Jinnie Horan, a spokeswoman for the Boys and Girls Clubs of South Puget Sound. And that wasn't all the money the former campus got. Lindquist Dental Center, which operates the dental clinic, received almost $400,000 to pay off their building debt there. Doing so "will allow them to serve more kids," said state Sen. Christine Rolfes, who worked with Hennessy to find funding for the East Bremerton site. Because the wellness campus had dissolved, the money for the new gym roof will be administered by the Kitsap Community Foundation. "Clearly, you can see the need to refurbish it," Rolfes said. "Hopefully with this investment, it will provide 60 years of use to come." Mayor Patty Lent, too, was thrilled at the news. "We're not giving up on possibilities for that space," she said, noting the loss of the wellness campus. "It puts us in position to be a magnet for the next phase of development." Several other organizations also benefited from the wellness campus' disbanding and disbursement of remaining funds, Hennessy said. Sports Beyond, an organization run by local basketball coach Rick Walker, got $2,000 for a scorer's table at Bremerton High School, the Kitsap Fastpitch Association received $7,000 to upgrade fields on the former East High campus. Another $40,000 is going to the New Life Community Development Group, which is building the Marvin Williams Recreation Center in downtown Bremerton.

LabBody: Credit: Jamie McCarthy/Getty. Updated: Friday Jul 10, 2015 | 06:00 AM EDT By: Lena Finkel

Josh Allen’s muscle and hustle ignited the Evansville Otters in the bottom of the third as he and Nik Balog had Lake Erie seeing double on Friday night before at Bosse Field. Allen laced a two-run double to the right-center field gap and advanced to third on the ensuing error by Lake Erie center fielder Austin Prott in the third inning. Shortly thereafter, Allen stole home to increase the Otters’ lead to 3-0 as they went on to win, 8-2. He hit the first pitch off Lake Erie starter Hunter Adkins, a “fastball middle-away,” into the gap. “I knew he wanted to get ahead with the fastball and I kind of ambushed him,” said Allen, who had two hits, scored two runs and reached base four times. With left-handed hitting Dane Phillips at the plate, Lake Erie third baseman Anderson Hidalgo played way off the bag. On the previous pitch, Allen got a huge walking lead. He gave Evansville manager and third-base coach Andy McCauley a signal and McCauley grinned. “He said, ‘You got it?’ I said, ‘Yeah,’ ” Allen said. “He said, ‘Take it,’ and I did.” Allen stole home for the first time as a pro and the first time since playing for Bartow (Florida) High School. McCauley said it marked the first time an Otter had stolen home since Nick Schwaner on June 17, 2012. “Everything has got to be perfect,” McCauley said. “It’s kind of fun and it was rewarding. You’ve got to have it in this game. He was a kid who had kind of been beating himself up.” Evansville, which had four doubles, improved to 31-18. The Otters entered the game one-half game behind Traverse City and Southern Illinois in the Frontier League East Division. Chris Sweeney doubled off the third-base bag — literally — then scored on Balog’s two-run homer in the fourth as the Otters boosted their lead to 5-0. Balog hit a two-run double off the base of the right-field wall in the fifth, increasing the margin to 7-0. “He came up flush,” Allen said of Balog, who finished 3-for-4 with four runs batted in. Balog has driven in runs in seven of his last nine games and has nine RBIs in that span. Making his final start before the Frontier League All-Star break, Trevor Walch (6-3) allowed six hits in seven scoreless innings. Walch is one of five Otters named to the East All-Stars for the game Wednesday at Schaumburg, Illinois. He came in fourth in the league with a 1.77 earned-run average and lowered it to 1.59. “He did not have his best stuff,” McCauley said. “He gave up some hits but not any runs. He battled through his stuff.” Tyler Vail, who is 4-2 with a 4.08 ERA, is set to start for Evansville in the second of the three-game series at 6:35 p.m. Saturday.
The West Flag Little League All Stars took on Winslow Friday night.

The 23rd annual Sunken Garden Poetry Festival, the nationally acclaimed series of outdoor readings on the grounds of the Hill-Stead Museum, 35 Mountain Road, Farmington, is offering something new this year: Sunday afternoon programs. On Sunday, July 12, Marie Howe, who was the 2012-2014 poet laureate of New York State, and poet Ciaran Berry will read. Howe is the prize-winning author of three collections, and her poems have appeared in The New Yorker, The Atlantic, Poetry, AGNI, Ploughshares and other publications. Berry is the 2012 winner of a Whiting Writers' Award and many other honors and the author of the collection "The Sphere of Birds." His work also has appeared in many journals. Zingerz, a trio from the Connecticut shoreline with Dan Bernier, Michael Frishman and Gary Parrington, will perform swing, rhythm and blues, jazz, reggae and more. The festival gates will open at 1:30 p.m.; a conversation with Howe and Berry will be at 2 p.m.; Berry will read at 3 p.m.; Zingerz will play at 3:30 p.m.; and Howe will read at 4:15 p.m. Guests can bring their own seating and food or can buy food and wine there. Tickets are $12 online in advance or $15 at the door; free for those 18 or younger. Information: 860-677-4787 or hillstead.org. Authors Live! The Noah Webster Library, 20 S. Main St., West Hartford, will present a free Authors Live! event Wednesday, July 15, at 6:30 p.m. with novelist Beatriz Williams, whose latest is "Tiny Little Thing" (G.P. Putnam's Sons, $26.95). Set on Cape Cod in 1966, it is the story of a glamorous power couple, the Hardcastles, who are about to enter national politics until all their best-laid plans go awry. Williams, who lives in Greenwich, is the bestselling author of "The Secret Life of Violet Grant," "A Hundred Summers" and "Overseas." Registration: 860-561-6990 or westhartfordlibrary.org. Science Fiction and Fantasy. The Friends of the Simsbury Public Library will host four award-winning New England science fiction and fantasy writers — Elizabeth Bear, James Cambias, Max Gladstone and Brian Staveley — in a free panel discussion Saturday, July 18, from 1 to 3 p.m. at Simsbury Library, 725 Hopmeadow St., Simsbury. Their recent books include a Western steampunk, a sci-fi thriller, an urban fantasy and the second novel in a fantasy series. Registration: simsburylibrary.info or 860-658-7663. Connecticut Authors Trail. The Connecticut Authors Trail, a series of free talks offered by libraries in eastern Connecticut, will present authors who live in the state or write about it. At each event, guests can acquire "passport" guides to the series that offer a chance to win a themed basket. Charlotte Rogan, of Westport, author of the thriller, "The Lifeboat" (Reagan Arthur/Back Bay Books, $14.99) will read on Monday, July 13, at 6 p.m., at Stonington Free Library, 20 High St. Retired Realtor Nancy D. Butler will discuss her books, "Above All Else, Success in Life and Business" (Annotation, $18) and "A Realtor's Guide to Greater Success" ($12), on Tuesday, July 14, at 7:30 p.m. at Waterford Public Library, 49 Rope Ferry Road. Sharon K. Cormier will discuss her books, "Where The Lotus Blooms: Finding Inner Peace Through Mindfulness, Yoga and Meditation" (Self-published, $14.95) and "AFGEs: A Guide to Self-Awareness and Change" (Muse House, $9.95), co-authored with Barbara Harris Whitfield, on Thursday, July 16, at 6:30 p.m. at Sprague Public Library, 76 Main St., in the Grist Mill, Baltic. Cormier is a certified yoga therapist, meditation instructor and workshop leader. Information: connecticutauthorstrail.org. Local Author Festival. The free Avon Free Public Library Local Author Festival, which will run through Aug. 24 at Avon Library, 281 Country Club Road, Avon, continues with Fiction Night on Tuesday, July 14, at 7 p.m. Authors Lisa Acerbo, T. J. Banks, Katy Lee and Kathryn Orzech will read. On Thursday, July 16, at 1 p.m., the library's "All American Summer" programming will present a free talk by John Cilio on the history of American bomber aircraft with an emphasis on World War II. Cilio is the author of "American Airpower: Bombers 1935-1960 Vintage Aviation Photographs from WWII, Korea and the Cold War" (Vintage Flyer Media LLC, $20). Information: 860-673-9712, ext. 235. Authors At R.J. Julia. R.J. Julia Booksellers, 768 Boston Post Road, Madison, will present free talks by authors. All will take place at 7 p.m., except as noted, and reservations are required: 203-245-3959 or http://www.rjjulia.com. On Monday, July 13, the mother-daughter writing team of Lisa Scottoline and Francesca Scottoline Serritella will discuss their new collaboration, a collection of amusing stories called "Does This Beach Make Me Look Fat?: True Stories and Confessions" (St. Martin's Press, $21.99). Scottoline is the best-selling author of mystery novels and co-author with Serritella of humor memoirs. Both are columnists for The Philadelphia Inquirer. On Tuesday, July 14, at noon, a "Books on the Menu" lunch and talk will present store manager Lori Fazio and head book buyer Andrew Brennan discussing books that are hidden gems or literary masterpieces or fun beach reads. The $10 cost includes a gourmet sandwich, cookie, chips, water and complementary wine and a chance to win a $25 store gift card. Also on Tuesday, July 14, neuroscientist Joseph LeDoux will talk about "Anxious: Using the Brain to Understand and Treat Fear and Anxiety" (Viking, $28.95), an in-depth look at the psychiatric disorders afflicting millions of Americans, and current research. LeDoux directs the Emotional Brain Institute at New York University. On Wednesday, July 15, author Sarah Leah Chase will discuss her "New England Open-House Cookbook: 300 Recipes Inspired by the Bounty of New England" (Workman Publishing $24.95), which offers more than 300 recipes. Chase is a caterer, cooking teacher and author who co-wrote "The Silver Palate Good Times Cookbook." She writes a food column for Nantucket's Inquirer and Mirror newspaper and is recipe consultant to Ina Garten. Mark Twain House & Museum Center.

ALBUQUERQUE — New Mexico’s “three strikes” law is weak and doesn’t do enough to take violent criminals off the streets, Gov. Susana Martinez says. While promoting a new law that expands the state’s Amber Alerts to cellphones, the Republican governor said this week she’d like to see a tougher three strikes law in New Mexico and hopes lawmakers examine it next session. Martinez, a former prosecutor now in her fifth year as governor, said New Mexico’s three strikes law is so narrow that no inmate is currently serving a life sentence under it.

Today, many in our culture equate happiness with joy. They’ll tell us “being happy” is one of the loftiest achievements in life. It’s a lie! A lie the left has bought into. The happiness of the left is fleeting and short lived. It is based on circumstances, and circumstances change so much that it’s impossible to depend on them to ever make us happy. The left is angry and filled with vitriol. It seeks happiness at the expense of others. The goal of the left is to demonize, scorn and attack anyone with a view that differs from theirs. In their arrogance and pride they even mock and attack God. The Supreme Court decision regarding marriage will not bring happiness to the gay community. Neither will legalizing polygamy, nor silencing Christians.

COUNTRY singer Sam McClymont is the left-field choice to host the revived reality dating series The Farmer Wants A Wife. McClymont and her two sisters form the highly successful country music trio The McClymonts. She replaces Natalie Gruzlewski on the Nine Network show, which will return to the screen later this year. It’s her first television presenting role. “I am thrilled to be joining Farmer Wants a Wife. I’ve been a fan since it began. The thing that has struck a chord with me, and I think the TV audience, is that the men and women going on this show are genuinely looking for real love. “Being newly married, I look forward to helping these farmers and ladies find that special someone, and hopefully we can add some more marriages and babies to the shows amazing success rate,” she said in a statement. Nine’s new production executive, Stuart Clark, said: “We are thrilled to have Sam on board helping our six farmers on their quest for true love. She’s a country girl, a great musical talent, and the perfect host to guide our famers through the trials and tribulations of finding love on the land.” Production will commence next week on Australia’s most successful reality dating program. With eight marriages and 10 babies already to its name, The Farmer Wants a Wife will return soon to Channel Nine.

What: "42nd Street" Where: Pinewood Bowl, Pioneers Park. When: 8 p.m. July 10-12, 16-19. Tickets: In advance, $10 with Russ's Community Rewards card or $11 without at Russ's Markets; at the gate, $12; children ages 6 to 12 are $5 in advance or at the gate; admission free for children 5 and younger. Dancing was the star Thursday night when “42nd Street” opened at Pinewood Bowl. The cast of 43 grabbed the audience with the opening tap number. Director Courtney Piccoli hoped the production would showcase some of the talented tap dancers in Lincoln, and indeed it did. “42nd Street” tells the story of small-town talent Peggy Sawyer, played by Piccoli’s daughter Liza, trying to make it on Broadway. She gets her big break in a show directed by Julian Marsh, played by Robert Wamsley. Liza Piccoli and Wamsley delivered admirable vocal performances, and Piccoli’s vocals were only outdone by her dancing. Notable performances were also delivered by Jenna Richter-Nasif, making her Pinewood Bowl debut as Anytime Annie Reilly; Brittany Hying as Phyllis Dale; and Halsey Beull as Lorraine Fleming. Bailey West moved from the orchestra pit to the stage and delivered a strong portrayal of aging diva Dorothy Brock. Tim Wisgerhof created an intricate set rich with color and detail. Were those sowers topping the skyscrapers a subtle nod to Lincoln? The stage really came to life at dusk when the audience could fully appreciate the lighting design by John Hansen. The stunning costumes by Maralee Maldavs were showcased on the big dance numbers that stole the show. Though the level of vocal performance did not match the quality of the dancing, and the show lost a bit of pace and crispness after the lengthy intermission, the crowd enjoyed mild weather and an overall robust opening night performance. Courtney Piccoli was honored before the show as she celebrated her 10th anniversary of directing the annual Pinewood Bowl productions. At intermission, it was announced that next year the historic Lincoln venue will present “Seussical.” Copyright 2015 JournalStar.com. All rights reserved. LAWRENCE — City narcotics detectives, working with local and federal authorities, seized about 15 pounds of heroin worth roughly $500,000, two firearms and $350,00 in cash during a drug sweep Thursday. Twenty-three people were arrested. A major arrest in the operation was a Manchester, N.H. man, Alexander Dume-Santana, 35, who was apprehended after an investigation that started on Willow Street, police said. Dume-Santana was driving a GMC Sierra pickup without a license, police said. After pulling him over at gunpoint, detectives found five individually wrapped kilos of cocaine on the front passenger seat of the truck, according to a police report. As a result of Dume-Santana's arrest, detectives then executed a search warrant at a nearby Allyn Terrace address. There, authorities seized two more kilos of heroin, two firearms and $350,000 cash, police said. Dume-Santana was arrested and charged with trafficking more than 20 grams of heroin, reckless operation, driving without a license, providing police with a false name and as a fugitive from justice. Dume-Santana has a outstanding New Hampshire warrant for sale of a controlled drug and two outstanding Massachusetts warrants, according to police records. Seven kilos of heroin weigh approximately 15 pounds. The large amount of heroin yields roughly $500,000 in illegal sales, police said. Dume-Santana initially gave detectives a false name of Nathaniel Diaz-Ramos, according to a report written by a Lawrence detective assigned to the city's Street Enforcement Narcotics Unit. Check back to eagletribune.com for more details on this story and a complete list of those arrested during Thursday's operation. Follow staff reporter Jill Harmacinski @EagleTribJill.

DiffbotBody: Type 2 diabetes may have consequences not only on the body, but on the brain as well. According to a new study, those with type 2 diabetes experienced negative changes in their ability to regulate blood flow in the brain, which was associated with lower scores on memory and cognition tests. "Normal blood flow regulation allows the brain to redistribute blood to areas of the brain that have increased activity while performing certain tasks," said study author Dr. Vera Novak, of Harvard Medical School in Boston in a press release. "People with type 2 diabetes have impaired blood flow regulation. Our results suggest that diabetes and high blood sugar impose a chronic negative effect on cognitive and decision-making skills." The study, published in Neurology, involved 40 people — 19 of which had type 2 diabetes and 21 that did not. The average age of participants was 66, and those with diabetes had been treated for an average of 13 years. The participants were tested at the beginning of the study and then two years later. In addition to the cognition tests, subjects underwent an MRI scan of the brain to observe blood flow and a blood test to measure control of blood sugar and inflammation. After two years, the participants with type 2 diabetes collectively had decreases in their ability to regulate blood flow in the brain, down by about 65 percent. They also scored 12 percent lower on memory and cognition tests than they had two years ago, while those without diabetes scored the same. "Early detection and monitoring of blood flow regulation may be an important predictor of accelerated changes in cognitive and decision-making skills," Novak said. She also added that additional studies with larger sample sets and a more extended follow-up time would be needed to better understand the relationship between blood flow regulation and changes in memory and thinking skills. Type 2 diabetes accounts for 95 percent of diabetes cases in adults, and several studies have shown that regular physical activity and a healthy diet can prevent or delay the onset. Past studies have identified links between the condition and problems with blood flow in the brain, but the effect it has on cognition is only now being investigated. Source: Chung C, Pimetel D, Jor'dan A, Hao Y, Milberg W, Novak V. Inflammation-associated declines in cerebral vasoreactivity and cognition in type 2 diabetes. Neurology. 2015

DiffbotBody: One of the underpinnings of Rick Perry’s long-shot bid for president is that his 14 years of governing a state with a 1,200-mile border with Mexico gives him unique authority on immigration issues. Then, less than a month ago, real estate mogul Donald Trump entered the race with what seemed a few ill-chosen words on the subject and stormed to the front of the crowded GOP pack, his position strengthened by the tragic July 1 shooting death in San Francisco of 32-year-old Kathryn Steinle, allegedly by Francisco Sanchez, a five-time deportee from Mexico who eluded being deported a sixth time because he found himself in a “sanctuary city.”

8. Zeontrez Marshall puts his helmet on during evening practice at Battle High School on Aug. 23, 2013. Marshall had both "RIP" and "TRE" shaved into his hair in remembrance of his cousin Tre'Veon Marshall who was killed this summer in a shooting. Zeontrez Marshall is a freshman linebacker at Battle High School, and football provides an escape from thinking about the slaying and a chance to honor his memory. Mackenzie Bruce/Missourian.

No one can accuse of New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie of not being straightforward — or entertaining, for that matter. Shortly after announcing his bid for the presidency Tuesday at his old high school in New Jersey, Christie and his family were on a plane headed to New Hampshire. The first official stop of Christie’s “Tell It Like It Is” campaign tour was Sandown Town Hall, where he introduced his wife, Mary Pat, and their four children. It was the beginning of a five-day tour that saw Christie travel throughout the Granite State and also to Maine, where he received the endorsement of Gov. Paul LePage. In Sandown, Mary Pat and children Andrew, Sarah, Patrick and Bridget were mentioned on occasion by their outspoken politican. So were Christie’s Irish father and his Sicilian mother, who he credited for making him an “expert at dispute resolution.” When Christie told the audience the country needed to abandon its agrarian-based calendar for a school year, he couldn’t help but point to his children sitting behind him. “Look at those four,” he said, “they aren’t going to till the fields, man.” When discussing the need for reforming the funding of higher education and affording the cost of college tuition, Mary Pat and Sarah suddenly took center stage. Poor Sarah was forced to listen to Dad talk about paying her tuition at the University of Notre Dame and how expensive it is — surely embarrassing for any college student. But that was only after Christie admitted his wife takes home a bigger paycheck than he does. “Do I what I did,” he said. “Marry a very successful woman.” Stumping in Salem. Like MaryAnn’s Diner in Derry, Tuscan Kitchen restaurant in Salem is quickly becoming a popular campaign stop for presidential hopefuls. GOP candidate and former Hewlett-Packard executive Carly Fiorina will be speaking and greeting local supporters at owner Joe Faro’s popular Italian restaurant Wednesday at 11:45 a.m. The event, focusing on national issues and the challenges faced by businesses, is being hosted by Faro in conjunction with the Greater Salem Chamber of Commerce. But Fiorina isn’t the first to stop off at Tuscan Kitchen. Fellow Republicans Jeb Bush and Donald Trump made appearances there as well in the last few months. Bush also visited MaryAnn’s, known for years as the place where pancakes and politics stack up well. Christie received a key endorsement at MaryAnn’s on Friday. As for Trump, it was announced last week that his New Hampshire campaign would be co-chaired by Salem state representative Fred Doucette. Ayotte vs. Hassan? Speculation is increasing that N,H. Gov. Maggie Hassan will seek the U.S. Senate seat held by Republican Kelly Ayotte. Ayotte announced last week she will run for another term and announced Thursday her campaign co-chairmen will be former Gov. Stephen Merrill and Salem’s own Donna Sytek. Merrill served as governor for two terms while Sytek spent more than 20 years in the New Hampshire House of Representatives, including four years as speaker. Sytek’s husband, John, currently serves in the House. When asked Wednesday if she planned to run for Ayotte’s seat, Hassan would not reveal her future plans to The Eagle-Tribune editorial board. “I’m just totally focused on fiscal 2015 and the budget, “ Hassan said of the well-publicized stalemate. “I’m focusing on my job as governor and getting the best possible budget for New Hampshire,” she said. Meanwhile, Republicans in the Legislature have attacked Hassan, saying she is more interested in seeking Ayotte’s seat than reaching a compromise on the proposed $11.3 billion state budget. Staff writer Doug Ireland contributed to this report.

by Angela Markus 7/10/15. We have seen several videos of animals doing some pretty funny things. However, have you ever seen a puma sing? This video is sure to tickle your funny bone. A couple visiting a local zoo was in for a treat. Terrified to go close to the animal, Yazhi the female puma, surprised the couple and her keepers as she burst into song. Yazhi seems to have found her voice to the amusement of the couple and everyone else surrounding. She goes on for several minutes playing with different ranges and scales. Yazhi is also not camera shy. As soon as her eyes met with the video camera, she continues her set. Pumas are cougars, also known as mountain lions or catamounts. They are mammals of the Felidae family. They can typically be found in western Canada and the United States all the way to Southern South America. There is a small subspecie population found in Florida according the San Diego Zoo. They have a typical lifespan of 20 years. Oh, and most are avid singers like Yazhi. Our songstress Yazhi, is housed at the Wildlife Heritage Foundation, and now that she has found her voice, she can sing all day long. Pumas like Yazhi usual vocalization includes hisses, bird-like sounds, and growls. They can even purr like cats, although females can make some scratchy hair-raising screams. Eartha Kitt don’t have anything on Yazhi. She performs to the amusement of the couple who video records the entire performance. Watch as Yazhi sings! Don’t forget to SHARE the love, and pass it on. SALISBURY, N.C. — Someday, possibly in the very near future, Bruce Howard will call his 1,000th game as the Voice of the Golden Hurricane. Howard, director of Sports Broadcasting at the University of Tulsa since 1995 and TU’s play-by-play talent for football and men’s basketball since 1993, estimates that he has been on the mic for somewhere in the neighborhood of 930 games. Add in other sports and he’s “probably close” to 1,000. He’s also the 2014 Oklahoma Sportscaster of the Year as selected by the National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association, and on Monday night was honored as such with sportscasters and sportswriters from all 50 states and the District of Columbia at a black-tie awards gala at Catawba College. Howard also won the award in 2006. (Oklahoman columnist Berry Tramel was named Oklahoma sportswriter of the year. Tulsan Bob Carpenter, play-by-play voice of the Washington Nationals, was named D.C. sportscaster of the year.) Howard described how the broadcast industry has changed in the two decades he has been at TU. A greater online presence allows more sporting events to be live-streamed over the Internet, and an enhanced television package in partnership with the American Athletic Conference means more games on TV. Tulsa has better equipment and more efficient connections to keep up with the ever-evolving technology. But at TU, the greatest challenge hasn’t changed: manpower. “We just don’t have that many students,” Howard said. But that hasn’t slowed the explosive growth of athletic facilities on the TU campus during Howard’s tenure. “It started with (former president) Bob Lawless and (former athletic director) Judy MacLeod and the Reynolds Center,” Howard said. “When I first started broadcasting in 1993, we had an aging football stadium, no basketball arena, an intramural tennis facility at best, no place for soccer to play, no place for softball to play, no track and field — I mean, think about that. We had basically one home venue. And then you get the Reynolds Center, then the Case Tennis Center, the softball stadium was built, the soccer and track stadium, just the recreational facility over there. So that growth has been incredible.” The Reynolds Center in 1998, the addition of the Case Athletic Complex in 2007 and the Chapman Stadium/Skelly Field renovation in 2008 changed the game for TU athletics. “A sign of a university that’s forward thinking is to constantly look forward to that next thing,” Howard said. “What they do, as the smallest (enrollment) football institution in Division I, it’s remarkable.” Up next — possibly soon — is an indoor football practice facility that also will serve the student body. And new Golden Hurricane coaches like Philip Montgomery and Frank Haith are reaping the rewards. TU’s first basketball season under Haith, formerly head coach at Miami and Missouri, resulted in a 23-11 record, a second-place finish in TU’s first season in The American and a berth in the NIT. Montgomery, previously offensive coordinator at record-setting Baylor, hasn’t coached a football game yet but already has fans squirming over his vision of fast-paced, high-scoring offense. “I think Philip Montgomery’s come in and done just great work,” Howard said. “He’s got a lot of energy, and I think a lot of folks are just excited about the prospect of up-tempo football — kind of getting back maybe to what we saw a few years back when the team was setting records and that sort of thing. A lot of folks are excited about it. I know I’m excited about it.” Howard likes Montgomery’s straight-shooter persona. He recalls sitting with a friend during a women’s basketball game who, it turned out, was an old acquaintance of Montgomery. When Montgomery walked past on his way to a meet-and-greet with TU boosters, he stopped, sat down and visited for the entire second half. “That, to me, is an indication of what kind of guy he is,” Howard said. “Like, ‘No, I don’t need to be with the boosters or the big-wigs or whatever.’ ” Howard got a similar read after spending a year getting to know Haith. “Frank is a good guy to work with, easy to work with,” Howard said. “Media-savvy. And, I think, very underrated as a bench coach. I don’t think people give him enough credit for being a good bench coach. He knows what’s going on.” Howard said TU’s 12-game winning streak and 10-0 start to conference play is good evidence of Haith’s coaching skills. “I think they did a remarkable job of taking what was there and adding to it,” Howard said, “… of coaching them up and getting them — in a much more difficult conference — to where they were essentially one victory away from securing a regular-season crown, and then most likely an NCAA bid, who knows. “The joke was, for a team that can’t shoot and isn’t very tall, hey, we won 23 games. They did a good job overcoming their flaws.” Editor’s note: Tulsa World sports columnist John E. Hoover this weekend was in North Carolina, where he was presented the 2014 Excellence in Sports Medicine Reporting Award from the National Athletic Trainers Association.

A 41-year-old Midland man was arrested Friday night after allegedly assaulting a house member by slamming her head on the ground. Michael Benavidez was being held Monday on a $25,000 bond for the third-degree felony charge of assault of a family or house member with a previous conviction, according to police records. Midland police officers were dispatched to a residence off North Terrell Street in reference to a disturbance. Upon arrival, officers were advised by the alleged victim that a verbal argument between her and Benavidez had escalated to the point where Benavidez threw several items around the house, pushed her to the ground and began slamming her head to the ground, according to Benavidez’s arrest affidavit. Benavidez left the residence before officers arrived but was later apprehended walking along East Golf Course Road. He told officers that he engaged in the argument because “she doesn’t want to work,” according to his affidavit, however Benavidez denies ever physically assaulting her. If convicted of the third-degree felony, Benavidez could face up to 10 years in prison.

McKinney Police Chief Greg Conley called the actions of a police officer who’s been at the center of international attention because of his response to a weekend pool party as “indefensible” following that officer’s resignation Tuesday. Former McKinney Police Cpl. Eric Casebolt resigned earlier Tuesday amid an internal investigation into what transpired at a party Friday at a community pool in Craig Ranch on McKinney’s west side. A video that went viral after the party shows Casebolt throw a teenage girl to the ground before pulling his gun on two other party attendees. Conley, who took over as chief about six weeks ago, singled out Casebolt as the lone officer who acted in an errant manner in response to the party. “He came into the call out of control and as the video shows was out of control during the incident,” Conley said at a press conference Tuesday evening. “I had 12 officers on scene and 11 of them performed according to their training. They did an excellent job.” The entire community, and many around the state, nation and world, reacted to Friday’s events in recent days, some condemning Casebolt’s actions and others backing his ability to control the situation. Conley reemphasized that police were called to the party because of a “fight in progress and general disturbance.” Residents of the neighborhood said party attendees were also trespassing at the pool and climbing fences to access the party. “I do not condone the actions of those individuals who violated the rules of the community, showed disrespect to the security person on scene and to the officers who responded,” Conley said. “However, we as a department are held to a high standard of action as we do our jobs.” Because Casebolt is no longer a member of McKinney PD, the internal investigation is over, Conley said. He resigned while under investigation. The department will continue looking into whether there will be criminal charges against anyone involved, Conley added, but said it “will take a matter of time for us to work through all those allegations and those people who have come forward to us to complain.” Adrian Martin, a teenager who appeared to come to the aid of the girl who Casebolt swung to the ground in the video, was charged with interfering with police duties and evading arrest. Those charges have been dropped, Conley said. Mayor Brian Loughmiller, who also spoke with reporters Tuesday, said, “I don’t think that any one incident, any one individual, can totally define the community as a whole now or for the next year or for the next 10 years.” La’Shadion Anthony, a resident at Tuesday’s press conference who said he’s good friends with the father of Dajerria Becton, the 15-year-old taken down by Casebolt, asked the mayor whether those who wear a badge are above the law. “I do believe that we should hold our staff and our employees accountable,” Loughmiller responded. “And we do that.” Anthony said Casebolt’s resignation is “a victory for the city that we don’t have this guy on our streets anymore” and that he feels “safer already for our children.” “This is a great first step,” Anthony said. “But we still have a ways to go, because we still want charges pressed for the assault of a minor.” When asked if the incident would lead to any tweaks in department training, Conley said “we are always evaluating our training” and reiterated that 11 of the 12 officers on scene “did exactly what we would want them to do.” Moving forward and continuing to learn from the recent incident is what’s important now, according to Loughmiller. “There has to be an expectation and training in how you relate to police officers, as well, as an individual,” he said. “We’re going to work through all of that and try to … get past this and make our community stronger.”

LINCOLN COUNTY, Okla. – One person is dead and three others were injured after a seven car pileup that shut down part of the Turner Turnpike Friday night. The accident happened shortly before 5 p.m. near Wellston, forcing officials to shut down at least one eastbound lane of the highway, according to officials. In total, ten people were involved in the accident. Three were taken to the hospital, where they were treated and released. A fourth person, who officials have identified as Deborah Magness of Oklahoma City, died on the scene. Officials were forced to shut down part of the highway for almost three hours as they worked the scene. The cause of the accident is still under investigation. This is a developing story. With all the furor over the Confederate flag, lately I've found the "Dukes of Hazzard" theme song rolling around in my head. Just the good ol' boys. Never meanin' no harm. Beats all you ever saw, been in trouble with the law. Since the day they was born. Of course, it doesn't take much to get a song stuck in my head. TV themes, ad jingles, nursery rhymes I learned as a preschooler; my brain has devoted valuable storage space to every one of them. It's as if, just before the spirit that was to become Me took its first Holy Elevator Ride down to this planet, God asked whether I would prefer to be able to remember song lyrics or people's names and faces, and I said, "Song lyrics, heck yeah! Give me the 'Scooby Doo' theme over recognizing my husband's longtime coworkers at the grocery store any day." I swear, on my deathbed I will not recognize my own children, but I'll be able to sing the 1980s commercial about the ice-cold milk and the Oreo cookie. When a dark, delicious cookie hits an icy-cold sensation like the one and only creamy-center chocolate O-R-E-O ... Anyway. So I was thinking about them Duke boys right about the time Husband came home for lunch and noted that he'd seen a house with a flagpole and the Stars and Bars flying, high and proud. I mentioned I had seen a Washington Post article reminding readers that the flag was first raised over the capitol of South Carolina in 1962 as a visual "Bleep You" to the Civil Rights movement, and wondered aloud if the folks with the flag knew that. However, I said, I had been thinking about the Dukes ("Makin' their wayyyy — the only way they know how/That's just a little bit more than the law will allow") and I was pretty sure that most people around here connect the Confederate flag with that spirit, rather than the one that feels opening fire in a church full of worshipers is an acceptable statement on multiracial living. In a way, I understand. We all like to root for the underdog. We all like to see the Man get his comeuppance. We all like to think that were we in Hazzard County, we would be the ones gleefully distracting Roscoe P. Coltrane in order to help Bo and Luke pull a fast one on Boss Hogg (and then maybe catch a ride with them in the General Lee as they blasted out of town). In some ways and to some people who have never been in a position to know differently, it's that rebel spirit the Confederate flag represents — not a desire to exclude, oppress or outright slaughter people whose skin is a different shade. So I do understand. But as long as that deeper meaning exists too, I can't agree. However, I do want to suggest an alternative. I have the perfect flag in mind for someone who wants to say, "You can't keep me down," or, "No other country owns me," or even just, "Hey! I hold some truths to be self evident, here." It's our own Stars and Stripes, the one that thumbs its nose at England by its very existence. Ultimate Rebel flag, folks, still going strong. Just the good ol' boys. Wouldn't change if they could. Fightin' the system. Like a true modern-day Robin Hood. Something to think about as we move toward Independence Day. Jennifer Moody is the education reporter for the Democrat-Herald. She can be reached at 541-812-6113 or jennifer.moody@lee.net.

DiffbotBody: The battle in Energy Transfer Equity’s $53 billion bid for Tulsa-based Williams Cos. so far has been mainly behind the scenes, but it could spill out into a Wall Street fight in the coming weeks or months.
LabBody: Published: July 10, 2015. The battle in Energy Transfer Equity’s $53 billion bid for Tulsa-based Williams Cos. so far has been mainly behind the scenes, but it could spill out into a Wall Street fight in the coming weeks or months. The relationship between the two natural gas infrastructure giants has not gone officially hostile yet, but it’s no courtship either. Dallas-based Energy Transfer’s unsolicited offer, and Williams’ decision to reject it and seek strategic alternatives, has let the cat out of the bag, opened Pandora’s box and a can of worms. Pick your metaphor. The world for 108-year-old Williams has changed, analysts say. Read the rest of this story at TulsaWorld.com.

DiffbotBody: The window opens and closes at different times for each country, meaning some teams need to get their business finished earlier than their foreign counterparts Europe's top clubs are preparing for another busy summer of speculation, sales and signings as the transfer windows begin to open across the continent. The likes of Chelsea, Barcelona, Juventus and Bayern Munich will be looking to bolster their squads over the close-season as they look to build on their success of the latest campaign, while Real Madrid, Roma, Manchester City and other underperformers will be looking to make sure they come back stronger after a disappointing year. Big names such as Paul Pogba, Angel Di Maria, David de Gea, Harry Kane, Gregory van der Wiel, Edinson Cavani, Carlos Tevez and Alexandre Lacazette are all linked to moves away from their clubs this summer in what is expected to be another exciting window. The transfer windows open and close on different days for each country, though, so Goal gives you the times and dates by which Europe's top sides must have completed their business ahead of the new season.

Twenty years ago, John MacLean arrived in Keene to take on the job of running the city government, replacing longtime City Manager J. Patrick MacQueen. Last week, MacLean announced he’ll step down as of Oct. 1. During those 20 years, Keene has changed a lot, yet not that much. In that span:

DiffbotBody: Share this video Like our page September 2013 was a traumatic time for professional mountain biker, Martyn Ashton. After suffering from a life-changing injury, the world-record cyclist's career seemingly hit a dead end. His body was paralyzed from the waist down, and it wasn't looking good. Being paralyzed comes with countless struggles, but Martyn's cheery outlook on life helped see him through. Two years later with the help of his buddies, Martyn successfully mounts his bike and takes off down a mountainous trail. The saying, "it's as easy as riding bicycle" rings true in this inspiring video. The moment he takes off, it is clear that his skills are anything but rusty.

DiffbotBody: Share this video Like our page When you think of a fun homemade project to tackle with the family, you might get your hands dirty with a batch of cookies, maybe an art project, maybe even a DIY home renovation if you're feeling extra ambitious. But if you know the Thai Rocket Festival is approaching, why not get the kids together and put together an enormous pyrotechnic rocket that shoots spinning smoke trails? Every year around June or July, the residents of Laos and Thailand celebrate a rocket festival called Prapheni Bun Bang Fai. The festival is now a Buddhist celebration but has its roots all the way back to pre-Buddhist fertility rites. The Bang Fai rockets are charged with 120 kilograms of black powder and are scored by judges for beauty, heights and distance reached.

After dispensing with Maria Sharapova in the semi-final with the absent-minded effort you might employ in popping bubblewrap, the real game started for Serena Williams in her press conference on Friday. The rules are as follows: using all manner of linguistic ambushes, journalists attempt to ask about the significance of the Serena Slam; Williams, with weary resignation, bats them away. “I don’t want the pressure of that, and I’m not thinking of that. When you talk about it every time, you can’t help but think about it. It’s been OK just to free my brain from that.” Refusing to acknowledge it, however, does not make it any less real. History, as well as Garbine Muguruza, will be standing on the opposite side of the net on Centre Court on Saturday. As champion of the US, Australian and French Opens, Williams is one victory away from holding the set simultaneously, as she did in 2003, as well as completing the third leg of a calendar slam. Garbine Muguruza will be playing in her first grand slam final Rarely has a grand slam final thrown up such a disparity in experience. Muguruza, the 21-year-old from Barcelona, only recently entered the top 20; Williams has been world No 1 for 124 consecutive weeks. Muguruza has one title to her name (Hobart in 2014); Williams has 67. Muguruza has never previously progressed this far at a slam; Williams will be playing for her 21st grand slam title, one short of Steffi Graf’s record, 16 years after the first at Flushing Meadows. In the intervening period, Williams’s burning desire for victory in climbing the mountain was replaced by a pathological fear of defeat, of losing her place at the top of the rung rather than a fixation in passing a particular milestone. “I don’t think it’s got easier,” Williams said. “I just think I don’t feel as desperate to win. I think it helps me be relaxed. I was so desperate to get to 18, and ever since then, I’ve been totally relaxed. I’ve won so many grand slam titles. I don’t need to win another Wimbledon. I could lose tomorrow. Serena Williams goes into the final as the heavy favourite “I really hate losing. So I’m that kind of person that will work hard, work harder than anybody else to make sure I don’t get that. If I do, I learn from it better. That way I don’t have to do it in a long time.” It is that attitude that has elevated the 33-year-old to a pantheon of her own making in a sport in which most of her contemporaries have long since retired. “It’s strange because a lot of the people I grew up with are now on the legends tour. It’s like, ‘should I play legends as well as the main?’ ” Williams was very keen to remind everyone that she has lost to Muguruza, at the 2014 French Open, which she believes inspired an about-turn in her fortunes. “It was an eye-opening loss for me,” Williams said. “Some losses you’re angry about, and some losses you learn from. That loss I think I learnt the most from in a long time. I got so much better after that loss. Months later I started seeing the results more and more. “I don’t think she’s intimidated at all. She’s not that kind of person.” The Spaniard with the million-dollar smile accepts she must puncture the Williams aura if she is to put a spoke in the wheels of history. “Beating her is really important because it makes you see and realise that she’s also a person, she also has feelings, she is also nervous. To her, she knows that I can win against her, that I’m not afraid. I don’t think she’s really used to this. It’s true that it’s a very difficult match, but I think I have to believe I can do it.”

LabBody: Two suspects were injured in a deputy-involved shooting Friday night in the Village at Ellington subdivision on Brown Bridge Road near Covington, according to the Newton County Sheriff’s Office. Sgt. Cortney Morrison said the incident began after two deputies made a traffic stop in the subdivision. Authorities believed the vehicle had been involved in another crime, she said. During the traffic stop, a “situation” occurred in which deputies shot both suspects, Morrison said. Both have been transported to a hospital with gunshot wounds, she said. Morrison said the Newton County Sheriff’s Office Criminal Investigation Division is on scene and the Georgia Bureau of Investigation has been called in to investigate.

DiffbotBody: HAVE YOU ALWAYS HAD TROUBLE WITH MEDITATION? Has the language of meditation always seemed a little bit hokey, a little bit everything-is-wonderful for you? Those days are over. YouTuber Jason Headley has created a guided meditation for the people who have a little too high of a bullshit meter to take other guided meditations seriously. It’s called “F*ck That: A Guided Meditation,” and it is the zen you need to keep your head. Just remember: “Breathe in strength. Breathe out bullshit.”

A man and his small dog, EV, landed safely in Clearwater on Friday after they were found nearly 70 miles off shore of Hudson floating in a dinghy. Their sailboat had burned in the water next to them – a curse, turned blessing. "When we saw the smoke, I knew we found what we were looking for," Lt. Chanel Lee, a Coast Guard mission commander. The smoke gave the Coast Guard a clear target. "We were about 10 nautical miles [away] when I started to see the smoke in the distance, so I knew we were where we were supposed to be,” Lee said. The man and dog were about 100 yards from their burning boat, said rescue diver Erick Lieb, who was lowered from a helicopter into water to pull the man and dog to safety. "I disconnected from the hook, swam over to the boat and just had a quick little session with him where I assessed his condition and the dog,” he said. Lee was commanding her first rescue mission. "I'm glad, like I said, that were safely able to pick him up,” she said. “And I just wish him well in all of his endeavors." The man and dog were taken to a hospital. The crews says they were doing well.

COLUMBIA — Marquavius Lewis isn’t much of a talker. He doesn’t need to be. The statistics he brings from junior college do much of that for him. Those numbers are difficult to ignore, given how they clash with the totals posted last season at South Carolina, which suffered through one of its worst defensive campaigns on record. The Gamecocks as a team managed just 14 sacks in 2014, last in the SEC. USC’s sack leaders, Gerald Dixon and Jordan Diggs, tallied just two each in a year when maintaining pressure on the opposing quarterback emerged as one of the Gamecocks’ biggest headaches of the fall. Enter Lewis, a Greenwood native who last year was among the nation’s top defensive prospects out of junior college. The Jayhawk Conference Defensive Player of the Year finished with 11 sacks on his own, part of a season where he logged 63 tackles, 20.5 of those for a loss. Yes, they were tallied at Hutchinson Community College, which at last check isn’t in the SEC. But the 6-3, 265-pound Lewis was still so prized at USC that he was plugged in as a starting defensive end before he had even taken a snap in spring practice. “I felt like this is where I was needed,” Lewis, who chose USC over Auburn, said in the spring, “and that’s why I chose to come here.” In time since, he’s only solidified his position. Coaches and teammates alike have raved about Lewis’ quiet work ethic, about his lack of an ego, about how a player so sought after could immediately blend into a group. He won USC’s Defensive Player of the Spring award. Barring some shocking unforeseen development, big No. 8 will start at one defensive end against North Carolina on Sept. 3. “He’s very quiet,” said co-defensive coordinator Jon Hoke. “He just kind of goes to work, he works very well, so those are all great things to see in a guy.” Lewis is but one part of a defensive overhaul at USC that also includes the addition of Hoke, the installation of a 4-3 defense, a handful of player position changes and the influx of a number of new candidates along the Gamecocks’ defensive line. But Lewis — call him Quay — is the cornerstone of it all, a pass rusher unlike any South Carolina had last season, that missing piece which could separate a struggling defense from a competitive one. The debacle against Clemson aside, USC showed signs late last season that it might not be that far away from becoming the latter. Lewis could provide the Gamecocks with a healthy shove in that direction if he emerges as anything close to the pass rusher he was in junior college. He wants double-digit sacks. To have the impact USC coaches believe he’s capable of, he may not need that many. USC Top 10. JULY 3: No. 10 WR Deebo Samuel july 4: No. 9 LB Jordan Diggs july 5: No. 8 DB Rico McWilliams Monday: No. 7 OT Mason Zandi Tuesday: No. 6 DE Dexter Wideman Wednesday: No. 5 DE David Johnson Thursday: No. 4 OT Brandon Shell Friday: No. 3 QB Connor Mitch SATURDAY: No. 2 DE Marquavius Lewis SUNDAY: No. 1

LabBody: Life & Style.

When the Tragically Hip recorded their landmark 1992 album, Fully Completely, the music industry was a different world. Back in the glory days of CD sales, recording budgets allowed worthy bands to fly to internationally renowned hotspots, stay for weeks at a time and work with a world-class producer. For the Hip, after making albums in Memphis and New Orleans, recording their third full-length in London with Chris Tsangarides had the makings of a “grand experience,” recalled Hip guitarist Rob Baker. Off to England went Baker and his bandmates: singer Gord Downie, guitarist Paul Langlois, bassist Gord Sinclair and drummer Johnny Fay. It turned out to be a “pretty horrible place,” Baker added with a chuckle. “There were some definite good things about it, but it was cold and rainy and we were in the studio twelve hours a day. We’d get out of the studio but there isn’t a lot to do late at night unless you really know where to go and have transport. So we’d go back to our little flat that we were all sharing and we’d play Scrabble and drink port and watch Olympic highlights.” Fortunately, they made a terrific album, at a time when the industry could support the extravagance of an out-of-country recording experience. That doesn’t happen much anymore. “The industry has changed so much that a band that gets lucky might get $30,000 to make their record, and for that, they give up publishing, some live income, revenue from merchandise. They give up a lot,” said Baker. “That was our art budget for Fully Completely. We spent $30,000 doing the cover.” In those days, he explained, major-label bands like the Hip would get a budget of about $150,000 to make a record. If it broke even, the budget went up a bit for the next one. By Fully Completely, Baker estimates the budget would have been more than $185,000. The numbers would grow for another decade. “Our album budgets were rising into the $300,000 level at the same time the bottom started to drop out of album sales,” Baker said, pinpointing the 2002 album In Violet Light as the moment the balance tipped. “You know, I’d like to think it had something to do with the business imploding rather than us getting really s***ty but it’s probably a combination.” Fans can debate that one, but everyone agrees they were the hottest band in the country in the early 1990s. When the five Kingston lads flew to London, they were road warriors, logging up to 200 shows per year. Tsangarides buffed their raw energy with a studio polish that sent the album to the top of the Canadian charts. There were no fewer than six singles: Locked in the Trunk of a Car, Fifty Mission Cap, Courage (For Hugh MacLennan), At the Hundredth Meridian, Looking for a Place to Happen and the title track. The band celebrated the release of Fully Completely with a deluxe edition of the album, and have spent most of 2015 revisiting the music on tour. It’s made for a surprisingly intense show, reports Baker.
